Breaking Bad is a masterclass in television storytelling, offering a gripping narrative that dives deep into the complexities of morality and transformation. Created by Vince Gilligan, this series takes viewers on a tumultuous journey through the life of Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher turned methamphetamine manufacturer.

Plot: The show follows Walter White (Bryan Cranston), who, after being diagnosed with terminal cancer, decides to use his chemistry expertise to cook and sell methamphetamine to secure his family's financial future. As Walter descends deeper into the criminal underworld, he becomes entangled in a web of deception, violence, and moral ambiguity.

Performances: Bryan Cranston delivers a powerhouse performance as Walter White, capturing the character's descent from a mild-mannered teacher to a ruthless drug lord. Aaron Paul, as Jesse Pinkman, complements Cranston's performance with a raw, emotionally charged portrayal. The supporting cast, including Anna Gunn, Dean Norris, and Bob Odenkirk, adds depth and nuance to the series.

Writing and Direction: The writing in Breaking Bad is exceptional, with intricate plotting and well-developed characters. The show excels in character development and moral exploration, presenting viewers with morally gray scenarios that provoke thoughtful reflection. Vince Gilligan's direction ensures that each episode is meticulously crafted, with a perfect balance of tension, drama, and dark humor.

Cinematography and Music: The series features striking cinematography that enhances the storytelling. The use of color and visual motifs adds layers of meaning to the narrative. The music, including a memorable score by Dave Porter, underscores the emotional and dramatic moments, enriching the viewing experience.

Overall: Breaking Bad is an extraordinary piece of television that stands as a testament to the possibilities of the medium. Its compelling narrative, complex characters, and high production values make it a must-watch. The show's exploration of transformation and the consequences of choices leaves a lasting impact, making it one of the greatest television dramas of all time.

Breaking Bad is not just a TV show; it's an extraordinary experience that takes storytelling, character development, and tension to levels rarely seen in the entertainment industry. From the first episode to the final heart-stopping scene, the show grips you and doesn't let go, earning its place as a pinnacle of television history. If ever there was a series that deserved more than a perfect score, it's Breaking Bad-11/10, without a doubt.

The Storyline: A Flawless Descent into Darkness At its core, Breaking Bad is about the transformation of Walter White, a meek high school chemistry teacher turned ruthless drug kingpin. The genius of the plot lies in its unpredictability and pacing, perfectly balancing action, suspense, and psychological depth. Each episode builds on the next, constantly raising the stakes and pushing the characters into uncharted moral territory. Every twist feels organic, making the viewer question what they would do in similar circumstances.

What sets Breaking Bad apart from most series is its refusal to drag its narrative. It has a beginning, middle, and an unforgettable end, all delivered without filler episodes. Every plot point serves a purpose, contributing to the inevitable yet shocking downfall of Walter White.

Character Development: Unparalleled Few shows have managed to flesh out their characters as well as Breaking Bad. Walter White's transformation from a desperate man looking to secure his family's future to a cold, calculated criminal mastermind is nothing short of remarkable. Bryan Cranston delivers a once-in-a-lifetime performance, showcasing Walter's internal struggle, his ego, and the moral decay that follows his every decision.

Similarly, Aaron Paul as Jesse Pinkman is nothing less than stellar. Jesse's journey from a small-time drug dealer to a tragic figure full of regret and trauma is profoundly moving. His relationship with Walter evolves from mentor-student to one of the most complex dynamics in TV history.

The supporting characters-Saul Goodman, Hank Schrader, Gustavo Fring, and Skyler White-each have their own arcs that are equally compelling. These characters are not merely there to support the plot; they are fully fleshed-out individuals with their own goals, fears, and motivations.

Cinematography and Direction: Artistic Brilliance Visually, Breaking Bad is stunning. The cinematography is nothing short of cinematic excellence. Each shot is meticulously crafted, often filled with symbolism and hidden meanings. Whether it's the sweeping desert landscapes or the intimate, claustrophobic interiors, the setting always complements the emotional undertone of the scene.

Vince Gilligan and his team deserve immense credit for creating a distinct visual language that's both artistic and impactful. The iconic use of color, such as Walter's transformation from light to dark clothing, subtly tracks his moral descent. The use of time-lapse shots, first-person perspectives, and unexpected camera angles makes each scene visually engaging.

Pacing and Tension: Masterful Few shows manage to maintain high tension across multiple seasons like Breaking Bad. Every episode feels essential, each one building towards a larger, inevitable conclusion. The slow-burn style works wonders, particularly in scenes that are quietly intense, like when Walter and Jesse are making meth in the RV while knowing the police are closing in.

Even when the show slows down to explore character emotions or backstories, the tension never dissipates. You're always waiting for the next explosive moment, and Breaking Bad knows exactly how to reward that anticipation.

Iconic Moments and Quotes: Unforgettable Breaking Bad gave us some of the most unforgettable moments in television history. Who could forget "I am the one who knocks," or the tragic fallout of Jane's death? The show is littered with moments that stay with you long after the credits roll, whether it's a tense face-off between Walter and Gus or the slow realization of Hank in the final season.

The writing is sharp, full of memorable quotes, and there's a constant thread of moral complexity running through each character's decisions. The show never spoon-feeds you answers; instead, it leaves you to wrestle with its moral quandaries.

The Final Season: A Perfect Conclusion Breaking Bad concludes in a way few shows ever manage to do-perfectly. Every loose end is tied up in a manner that feels satisfying, rewarding long-time viewers with the closure they deserve. The final episodes are emotional, action-packed, and as dark as they come, providing the ultimate payoff for the journey the audience has been on.

Without giving away spoilers, the ending solidifies Breaking Bad as a series that stayed true to itself, never compromising its vision for the sake of shock value or fan service. It's one of the rare shows where the ending enhances the entire experience rather than diminishing it.

Verdict: A Timeless Masterpiece Breaking Bad is a once-in-a-generation television experience. Its flawless combination of storytelling, character development, and visual artistry makes it not just a show but an immersive, thrilling ride that challenges your perception of good and evil. From its iconic characters to its unforgettable moments, this series will continue to be talked about for years to come.

I've never experienced a show that feels as meticulously crafted as Breaking Bad. From start to finish, everything in this series seems to have a purpose, and it's evident that a lot of thought went into every detail.

One of the things that stands out to me the most is how well the setting and atmosphere contribute to the overall experience. The way the show uses its environment to mirror the characters' journeys is nothing short of brilliant. The desolate landscapes, the stark lighting-everything serves to enhance the mood and tone of the story.

The characters are another highlight. Each one is so distinct, with personalities that are layered and complex. Watching them evolve throughout the series is a treat; it's rare to see character development handled with such care. I found myself deeply invested in their stories, and it's their authenticity that keeps you hooked from episode to episode.

The music in Breaking Bad is another aspect worth mentioning. While there are other series with more iconic soundtracks, the music here perfectly complements the scenes. It's subtle but effective, adding to the tension and emotion without ever being intrusive. It may not be the most memorable soundtrack, but it's undoubtedly fitting for the series.

If there's one thing I could critique, it's that the show can feel a bit slow at times, especially in the early seasons. But even those moments have a purpose, building the foundation for what's to come. And trust me, the payoff is worth it.

Overall, Breaking Bad is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates thoughtful storytelling. It's not just a show; it's an experience that stays with you long after it's over. If there's ever been a series that comes close to perfection, this might just be it.

The series centers around Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher turned methamphetamine manufacturing drug dealer. Bryan Cranston's portrayal of White is nothing short of phenomenal, capturing the transformation of a desperate man into a ruthless criminal. Aaron Paul, playing his former student and business partner Jesse Pinkman, delivers a powerful performance, embodying a character filled with conflict and vulnerability.

What sets "Breaking Bad" apart is its intricate storytelling and character development. The series is a slow burn, meticulously building tension and complexity with each episode. It explores themes of morality, consequence, and the human capacity for change, often blurring the lines between right and wrong.

The cinematography and visual storytelling are also standout features. The show uses color, camera angles, and symbolism to enhance the narrative, creating a visually captivating experience.

The supporting cast, including characters like Hank Schrader, Skyler White, and Gus Fring, add depth and intrigue to the story. Each character is well-developed, with their own arcs and motivations that intertwine with the main plot.

While the show is intense and sometimes brutally violent, it's balanced with moments of dark humor and irony. This combination keeps the audience engaged and emotionally invested in the characters' journeys.

Overall, "Breaking Bad" is a masterpiece of modern television. Its compelling narrative, exceptional acting, and artistic direction make it a must-watch series that has set a high bar for TV dramas. It's a thought-provoking exploration of human nature and the consequences of our choices, leaving a lasting impact on its audience.

Breaking Bad: A Dark Masterpiece that Redefined Television

Breaking Bad, created by Vince Gilligan, is hailed as one of the greatest television series of all time. This critically acclaimed drama captivated millions of viewers from its first episode to its final thrilling conclusion. With its gripping storyline, complex characters, and masterful storytelling, Breaking Bad is a dark masterpiece that has revolutionized the medium of television.

Set in Albuquerque, New Mexico, the series follows the life of Walter White, a chemistry teacher turned methamphetamine manufacturer, brilliantly portrayed by Bryan Cranston. After being diagnosed with terminal lung cancer, Walter enters the treacherous world of the drug trade in order to secure his family's financial future. What initially seems like a desperate act soon spirals into a descent into darkness, as Walter's ego and desire for power gradually consume him.

Breaking Bad is known for its intricate plot, filled with unexpected twists and turns. Gilligan weaves together elements of drama, crime, and dark comedy, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats throughout the show's five seasons. Each episode is meticulously crafted, building up tension and leaving viewers craving more.

Central to the success of Breaking Bad is its unforgettable cast of characters. Alongside Walter, Aaron Paul delivers an outstanding performance as Jesse Pinkman, Walter's former student and reluctant accomplice. The relationship between these two characters evolves from a partnership to a complex dynamic, filled with betrayal, loyalty, and unexpected moments of genuine connection.

Giancarlo Esposito's portrayal of Gus Fring, a notorious drug lord, is equally noteworthy. Fring's calm demeanor and meticulous nature bring a sense of menace to the show, making him one of television's most compelling villains. The talented ensemble cast, including Anna Gunn as Walter's wife Skyler and Dean Norris as Hank, Walter's brother-in-law and DEA agent, further elevates the quality of the series.

Breaking Bad explores profound themes such as morality, identity, and the consequences of one's choices. It delves deep into the human psyche, forcing viewers to question their own moral compass and ponder what they would do if faced with similar circumstances. The show raises fascinating questions about the nature of good and evil, blurring the lines between right and wrong.

Furthermore, Breaking Bad showcases exceptional cinematography and innovative visual storytelling. The series beautifully captures the vast landscapes of the American Southwest, emphasizing the harshness and loneliness of Walter's journey. The iconic shots, clever camera angles, and symbolic imagery contribute to the overall atmosphere of the show.

In conclusion, Breaking Bad is an extraordinary series that has made an indelible mark on television history. With its compelling plot, unforgettable characters, and thought-provoking themes, it stands as a testament to the power of storytelling. Breaking Bad pushes the boundaries of what can be achieved in the medium of television and will be remembered as a groundbreaking masterpiece for years to come.

Bryan Cranston's resurgence is here. Once praised for his role in Malcolm In The Middle, he had yet to find a suitable platform for his unique talents. He possesses the rare ability to evoke both sympathy and manic energy simultaneously.

For those quick to dismiss this show as a Weeds imitation, consider that Breaking Bad is an entirely different beast. It delves into the same themes, portraying the realistic struggles of middle-class life in the United States, often leading individuals to extreme measures for survival. Take, for instance, the mother-daughter duo who robbed a bank. However, the weed-selling escapades of Showtime's hit series are nothing like "Bad." The pilot episode is as close to perfect as they come, with much of the credit going to Bryan Cranston's performance.

Cranston takes on the role of Walter White, a chemistry teacher. He has a loving wife, a child with cerebral palsy, and another on the way. On top of it all, he is battling terminal lung cancer, despite having "never smoked." With his finances in disarray, this once brilliant scientist turns to a life of crime to resolve his problems.

He begins producing crystal meth with a former delinquent student. From the very first episode, the show heads towards a dark, yet truthful place. This is a no-nonsense dark comedy.

For fans of Tarantino or the Coen brothers, this may be right up your alley.

**10/10 STARS - THE GREATEST TV SHOW OF ALL TIME**

I just finished binge-watching Breaking Bad, and I'm still reeling from the experience. This show is not just a TV show - it's a masterclass in storytelling, character development, and emotional manipulation. It's a work of art that will leave you breathless, confused, and ultimately, changed.

The show tells the story of Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher turned meth kingpin.

But don't let that summary fool you - this is not just a show about a guy who cooks meth. It's a complex exploration of morality, family, loyalty, and the human condition.

The writing is superb, with each episode expertly crafted to balance action, suspense, and drama. The characters are multi-dimensional and relatable, with even the most minor players bringing depth and nuance to the story.

But what truly sets Breaking Bad apart is its ability to tackle tough subjects with sensitivity and nuance. The show doesn't shy away from the harsh realities of drug addiction, poverty, and the consequences of one's actions.

I've never seen a TV show that has had such a profound impact on me. Breaking Bad is more than just entertainment - it's an experience that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

If you haven't seen Breaking Bad yet, stop what you're doing and watch it. Trust me, it's worth it. And if you have seen it, well, then you know exactly why I'm calling it the best TV show ever made.

Breaking Bad Is A Work Of Art On Television Breaking Bad is more than just a TV show - it's the pioneer of serialized storytelling as an art form that blew our minds. From its gripping pilot to the explosive finale, it is one of the greatest show for a reason - drama, character progression and thrill at their best.

Plot and Writing: The saga of Walter White's descent from a docile chemistry teacher to criminal overlord is an epic narrative rollercoaster. In fact, creator Vince Gilligan sets up a series of intricate plots and moral calamities which are every bit as unpredictable as they arc dependent; the storylines keep audiences pinned to their seats Every episode is a perfectly structured masterpiece, full of zingers and turns that stay with you after the fade to black. There's a seriously amazing cast.

This is the greatest show i ever watched ! Loved it 100/10.
These guys know how to write a story and make it in a movie. Solid 10 star. I never think I would come to see a TV show like this before. Pure geniuses in the art of making a movie.

This was recommended to me by a friend of mine. I never felt like watching it. I first checked it's IMDB ratings etc. And found it surprising that very few have such a good rating.

So now, I had to watch it. When I started it and finished first episode, I never felt like stopping until I had reached the last season and last episode.

Everyday it became a routine like watching 5-6 episodes. I was some serious binge watching watching so to try and finish it as soon as possible and maintain the continuity of entire series.

Even after the end, the season kept looping in my end, the characters, the situations, etc.

I would say everyone to watch it once. (But not with parents/kids together)

The first season (10/10) is original, interesting and develops the characters nicely, appearing to learn about each other and the industry they're entering.

The second season (5/10) is interesting but the fumbling character dialogue is tiring, the story is predictable and lost it's way from the originality of season one, perhaps I'm looking for The Wire but instead received a damp squid.

The third season (2/10) is slow, boring, off point, ineptitude character scripting and darn right annoying. I often found my self staring at the wall hoping for the episode to end and question why am I still watching this! You are saved by one or two interesting episodes but except to be dramatically let down immediately afterwards.

The fourth season (3/10) is an improvement on the third but still contains underdeveloped characters, do they not learn from their mistakes, is the script/dialogue written by a snail? It moves at the same pace! Bored.

This show is by and far, THE most overrated show I have ever seen. The amount of promoting that is done by fans of the show is unbelievably. At first I chose not to watch, simply because I tend not to sway with popular opinions. Then I decided to give the show a chance given its acclaim...

I was severely disappointed after watching the first season and a little concerned as to why I didn't like (albeit feeling guilty). I then proceeded to watch season 2; I was again disappointed in waiting for the big AH-HAH! moment of greatness. By season 3 I was in physical pain and enraged at everything about this show. I hated the characters, the story line and total lack of orgasmic satisfaction that had been promised by fans.

Like a stubborn mule, I watched the entire series beginning to end; pilot to finale. While I'll choose not to discuss matters pertaining to writing or plot quality, I would like to touch on a few notions categorically:

1) To fans: No, no...this show is NOT as good as or even REMOTELY close to The Sopranos -- please stop dramatically making such drug-induced proclamations.

2) Every character is so damn hatable, it is actually amazing. I hated all-of-them. (yes including the Walter Jr.) I have never felt physical anger towards characters on any show before BB.

3) Bryan Cranston and Aaron Paul have amazing chemistry together and I sincerely hope they work together sometime in the future. Despite my hate for their characters, the acting by these two was quite gripping. Beyond a doubt, Cranston especially has proved his abilities to act beyond comedy. He deserves recognition.

After having completely finished the series, I can't help but feel disappointed. I went in expecting a phenomenal show and ended up forcing my self through its entirety. However, I realized that much of this disappointment stems from the brutal constant over-hyping of the series. But I can't say I will ever re-watch the show seeing as how that would be point-less.

So my sincere advice to any potential subscriber to the Breaking Bad series is, stop; don't watch it. Come back in a few months when the hype has completely died and rid yourself of all expectations if only to give your self a fair chance of un-tainted judgement.

I do stand by my original judgement, this series does not belong amongst the likes of The Soprano's. To suggest that this show is better would be asinine.

Life time review ,Breaking Bad" is called one of the greatest TV series ever made. Bryan Cranston's portrayal of Walter White is phenomenal, matched by Aaron Paul's powerful performance as Jesse Pinkman. The supporting cast, including Tuco, Mike, and Gustavo Fring, adds massive depth and intensity. Set against the stark and stunning backdrop of Albuquerque, New Mexico, the locations add a unique visual appeal. The series' music perfectly complements its dark and gripping tone. With brilliant writing, unforgettable characters, and exceptional production quality, "Breaking Bad" resonates deeply and stands as a masterpiece, captivating even world wide audiences.

Suspense and its meaning and the suspense of something indescribable.

It is one of the most beautiful series and you can not forget it.

It is possible to watch more than once because of the performance and the most wonderful work.

One the best series I have seen in my entire life!! The production values of "Breaking Bad" are consistently top-notch. The meticulous set design, realistic depiction of the methamphetamine production process, and attention to scientific accuracy (thanks to the involvement of a chemistry consultant) contribute to the show's authenticity. The cinematography, particularly in iconic scenes like the "Breaking Bad" RV, is both visually striking and narratively impactful. One of the series' greatest strengths lies in its character development. Walter White's evolution is a masterclass in storytelling, as the viewer witnesses his descent into the moral abyss. Cranston's nuanced performance adds depth to the character, making Walter both sympathetic and detestable, creating a complex and unforgettable protagonist.

Breaking Bad is the one series where it is hard to find any ligament flaws. Every episode has something that will spark a sense of thrill in you.

As the show goes on it keeps getting better, however it also knows when to quit as to not drag on, unlike some other shows. The character develop in new and exciting ways as to not get boring nor static.

While the production of the show isn't no slouch either. The cinematography, editing (especially in the cooking scenes), sound design, and sets all provide for an amazing experience.

Not to mention this show has some of the best acting in TV history. With characters having emotions ranging from neutral to expressive while still being entirely believable.

It is no surprise to anyone that this show is a 10 out of 10. Making it for me the greatest show of all time.

I finished the show about 3 weeks ago, and I have to ask... Why does everyone seem to love it so much? In my book, it never came close to leaving a mark on television history. The only reason I finished it is because I was persuaded into doing so.. And admittedly, I was a little curious about how it would end with Aaron Paul's character. Which by the way, is a fantastic actor. And the same thing could be said about the rest of the crew.

So I'm not saying that the acting is bad, neither is the writing. In fact, it's brilliant. The whole concept is brilliant in it's very own way. It had a very realistic touch to it. So I don't blame the actors, I don't blame the writing team or the producers.. I blame this generation!!!

You're not supposed to watch television solely because of the acting or the story.. You're not supposed to watch television because of the realism.. You're supposed to watch it because you want to escape the boring everyday routines that haunts us all, aka real life!!

Despite the brilliance of this show, it was barely entertaining at all. It had some moments that's worth remembering, but overall I found it dull and boring.. Probably the most overrated show of the century. Cheers!

I honestly can't say enough good things about Breaking Bad. From the very first episode, I was hooked. The way the show slowly transforms Walter White from a regular high school teacher to a full-on drug lord is absolutely insane - in the best way possible. Bryan Cranston's acting? Next level. You feel every ounce of his struggle, anger, and ambition.

Then there's Aaron Paul as Jesse Pinkman. His character goes through so much, and Paul's performance makes you feel for him even when he's screwing up. The chemistry (pun intended) between Jesse and Walter is just perfect and keeps you on the edge of your seat.

The writing and direction are top-notch. You can tell everything was thought out down to the smallest detail. The tension builds slowly, but when it hits, it really hits. There's no filler here - every episode matters and adds to the bigger picture.

If you haven't watched Breaking Bad yet, do yourself a favor and start it ASAP. It's intense, emotional, and will definitely leave you thinking about it long after it's over. Hands down, one of the best TV shows ever made.

After I finally finished watching whole five seasons of this series I have to say I have mixed feelings about it. Some things about it I like, some I do not.

Let me start with what I like. I liked characters and acting. Also camera work sometimes was outstanding and there was a lot of twists and turns in the plot. I was impressed by the actor who played White Junior, RJ Mitte, and his character, I was sad that he could not stay in love with his father, but what Walter White character did it is very logical that he had to break with his father. Hovewer, I really liked the sweetness of the character and the actor RJ Mitte. Do not think wrong about all of it, I liked other actors and the work they did, but somehow he jumped out of the ordinary.

What I did not like? I did not like too much violence. I did not like the length of the series. It was just too long. I think 3 seasons would be better then 5. I did not like unrealistic plot. It just was too unrealistic, I do not think that 10 per cent of it would of been possible in the real life. I just do not like that. It seems that New Mexico is not that of a happy state, as far as I can tell from the series and I would probably be not very happy there, or am I wrong?

All in all some of you might like the whole thing, I just did not that much.

"Masterpiece... To be honest, I avoided this series for several years, arguing, 'I'm not ready to see Hal cooking meth.' Big mistake. When I finally decided to watch this TV series, after the first episode, I didn't even remember that character. That's why Bryan Cranston is a magnificent actor, just like his co-stars. This series demonstrates quality from its first to last scene, and that is more than gratifying. The script and main plot evolve into a poetic justice that permeates this legendary story and manages to empathize with characters that are often abject yet infused with so much humanity that it forces us to reassess our morals repeatedly. Like many people, I wish I could erase this series from my memory to experience again the television masterpiece that Vince Gilligan gave us, making us feel as alive as Heisenberg was with his 'baby blue.'"

Yep, this show deserves the top spot. I reviewed a bunch of episodes as I watched them, but now I want to say that the entire show was FANTASTIC!! Even though it is not my personal favorite show, I have to agree that it is one of the best, if not THE best. Everything just WORKED perfectly. The cast, the acting, the characters, the writing, the story, the themes, the ENDING. I cried and laughed and cheered many times. It brought out so many emotions and questions about humanity. My favorite character was Jesse, but all of the characters were great, even the ones I hated (Todd). Every season got better and better as it went on, which is rare for a show. I think five seasons was the perfect amount, and Felina (the finale) was my favorite episode. Everything from the beginning paid off. Watch the show from beginning to end, you will not be disappointed. It is very violent and intense, so make sure you know what you're going into before watching it, but it's so much more than just two people cooking meth in an RV. AMAZING show! 10/10.

I borrowed Season 1 and 2 of Breaking Bad from a friend after hearing the rave reviews and the 9.5/10 star rating on IMDb. I had high expectations for this show, thinking it would be on par with a show like Dexter. Unfortunately, it failed to deliver.

I watched 10 episodes in total. The entire Season 1 and the first three episodes of Season 2. It just failed to grab me. I felt like the episodes were slow, dragged out ideas that the writers attempted to stretch out for as long as they possibly could. There are hardly any background story lines going on, so you only see the main story line, stretched out so much it's really boring.

Normally after I watch episodes of a new show, I am left with anticipation for the next episode. Like a good book you can't put down. Breaking Bad didn't do this to me. In fact, I was so bored that I stopped Season 2 after three episodes. I couldn't torture myself anymore.

If you're interested in Breaking Bad, I suggest you give it a go. But don't have high expectations because you'll probably be let down.

Breaking Bad is amazingly engaging and is one of the few shows that makes you feel like you are the characters. When it ends, you will want to re-watch it for the rest of your life. Breaking Bad is a show so good that it is the greatest show on television, and it's spin-off show is right behind it.

......after I had finished watching it and it took me some time to concentrate on another series. The problem was that I felt I had just watched the best ever and I was never going to see anything as good again. I still believe that but I've come to terms with it.

I genuinely envy people who have yet to watch it and have that experience to come.

You know when you wish you could unsee something? In this case it would be be because I'd love to see it again.

Having said that I haven't been able to bring myself to watch it again.

It just wouldn't be the same second time around.

I do actually know people who said that they started watching it, didn't like it, and gave up on it, including close family members. I can't comprehend why someone wouldn't like it.

But the series itself is magnificent. Bryan Cranston's Walter journey as Walter White from family man to all consuming narcissist is as subtle and gradual as it is masterful. And the other actors in his universe give powerful performances and only add fuel to his fire.

The show's writer, Vince Gilligan, has consistently stated that there will not be another season which fans kinda understand, considering how the show ended, and they would not want to see the show's legacy tarnished. Having said that there isn't a man, woman or child who wouldn't watch another season on the edge of their seats.

I started to watch reruns of Breaking Bad because I had never watched it before. How did I not find this show earlier, I don't know. I am proud to say that not many television shows, or even films, handle a concept like this with such amazing depth and great writing.

I remember that whenever Bryan Cranston would win the Emmy award again and again I would seriously wonder what was so great about this man. Of course, things like this always happen. I can say that Cranston is giving one of the best performances to ever hit the small screen. The writers have given him a character that rises and challenges him and he has very admirably risen up to the challenge. He is undeniably powerful. I also want to give a shout out to Aaron Paul, who next to Cranston plays very well and has also risen above to create probably the most unforgettable and sympathetic druggie in a long time. The rest of the supporting cast also is great and are able to handle their characters magnificently well, especially Anna Gunn who has to deal with Cranston's always-erratic behavior.

The direction and writing in the show are top-notch and one is really surprised by how much you care and are involved by the characters. The cinematography is of the quality of an Oscar-winning film, as is the editing and the other technical aspects of the show. I do not see myself ever leaving this show because I know that the writers will never let me or any of the other fans down. Long live Breaking Bad, and AMC for creating some of TV's best stories.

"Breaking Bad": A Masterpiece of Modern Television

"Breaking Bad," the groundbreaking television series created by Vince Gilligan, is an undisputed masterpiece that has left an indelible mark on the landscape of modern television. Spanning five seasons from 2008 to 2013, this show stands as a testament to exceptional storytelling, character development, and moral complexity. In this review, we will delve into the intricacies that make "Breaking Bad" a triumph of the medium.

The show's premise is deceptively simple: Walter White (played brilliantly by Bryan Cranston), a high school chemistry teacher diagnosed with terminal lung cancer, turns to cooking and selling methamphetamine to secure his family's financial future. What begins as a desperate act born out of a dire situation evolves into a compelling exploration of morality, ambition, and the consequences of one's choices.

Central to the show's success is the transformation of Walter White from a mild-mannered, law-abiding citizen into the ruthless drug lord known as Heisenberg. Cranston's portrayal of this character is nothing short of extraordinary. His nuanced performance captures Walter's descent into the criminal underworld, making the audience both sympathize with and abhor him. Walter's journey forces viewers to question the nature of morality and how far one can go in pursuit of personal goals.

Equally essential to the show's brilliance is the supporting cast. Aaron Paul's Jesse Pinkman is a revelation, providing the perfect foil to Walter's character. Jesse's moral struggles and growth throughout the series mirror those of the audience, as we witness his attempts to break free from the cycle of crime and addiction. Other standout performances include Giancarlo Esposito as the chilling Gustavo "Gus" Fring and Jonathan Banks as the stoic enforcer, Mike Ehrmantraut.

The writing in "Breaking Bad" is a masterclass in storytelling. Vince Gilligan and his team craft a narrative that is meticulously plotted, filled with tension, suspense, and unexpected twists. The show consistently challenges viewers' expectations and keeps them on the edge of their seats. Each season builds upon the last, with consequences from earlier actions rippling through the entire series. This attention to detail and continuity sets "Breaking Bad" apart from its peers.

The show's exploration of moral ambiguity is one of its defining features. It presents a world where characters constantly grapple with ethical dilemmas, blurring the lines between good and evil. This moral complexity forces viewers to confront uncomfortable questions about their own values and judgments. As we witness Walter's gradual transformation, we are compelled to consider how far we might go when faced with desperate circumstances.

"Breaking Bad" also excels in its visual storytelling. The cinematography, with its sweeping desert landscapes and stark imagery, adds depth to the narrative. Symbolism is used effectively throughout the series, from the iconic blue meth to recurring motifs like the pink teddy bear. These visual elements serve to enhance the story's impact and underscore its themes.

The show's thematic depth extends beyond morality. It explores themes of family, power, and the American dream. Walter's motivations are rooted in his desire to provide for his family, yet his actions tear that very family apart. The corrupting influence of power is a central theme, as characters are drawn deeper into the criminal world, often with tragic consequences. In the end, "Breaking Bad" is a cautionary tale about the pursuit of ambition at any cost.

In conclusion, "Breaking Bad" is a tour de force in television storytelling. With its outstanding performances, intricate writing, and thought-provoking themes, it has set a high bar for what television can achieve. Vince Gilligan's creation is a testament to the power of the medium to challenge, provoke, and entertain. It remains a cultural touchstone and will undoubtedly be studied and celebrated for generations to come. If you haven't experienced the journey of Walter White and company, it's a journey well worth taking.

Starts VERY well but descends into utter ridiculousness. Walter Sr. is, quite simply, utterly unbelievable as a "bad guy", which taints the entire show.

When I read the synopsis a few years ago, already I felt that the storyline lacked interest for me and did not watch any of the series. Then recently some friends were so enthusiastic about the series that I finally got started on it.

So I watched all of episode 1 series 1 and then reflected. Now, it is not as if I am the kind of person who has trouble finding things funny that other people do. But I would say that let's say only half of the material out there that people will find funny will affect me that way. However, this material failed continuously to amuse or excite me in any way except for the suspense of the opening scene not being resolved until late in the episode.

I think of the first episode of a series as the pilot - therefore it sets the level of interest for an entire series. Which meant that after that I simply gave up on the whole series.

So what went wrong? Although jokes are never funny when explained, there exists an anatomy of humour that one can correlate to any given snippet. The general profile of something funny is that it has some element of surprise - it builds up a picture and the moment of laughter is when the viewer or reader is forced suddenly to see things another way. And generally that other way has to have a level of originality for the effect to work.

So I think the problem actually lies in the construction of the screenplay. As much as the ideas appear to be original, they do not unfold in a way that produces the comic effect. Nor therefore is there much occasion of suspense.

So for me the real question is why do so many people find it funny? I think that for me will remain a mystery.

I started watching Breaking Bad when it was quite unknown (in Germany), basically because I finished up another series and looked for a new one to kill some spare time so I was rater impartial and picked it because I enjoyed Brian Cranstons performance in "Malcom in the Middle".

But while Breaking Bad became more and more popular through media, I was astonished, that unexpectedly many people started watching this series - which seems rather usual - but in Germany it is a big deal, when a Series, which does not run on TV, nor is available in German language, breaks through to the crowd of people, that are not really interested into movies or series, but only watch stuff that is easy to understand and does not require any previous knowledge on character or story. For example Game of Thrones or The Sopranos, are only known by a "few" people that are interested in good series in general, but not by the ones that like so sit on the sofa an just simply consume what is on the screen at that particular moment.

So I asked myself why Breaking Bad attracted so much general interest, while e.g. Game of Thrones did not. Is it the topic, so the the whole drug business thing? Is it the characters that matter? Or was it just a kind of "happy accident", that especially this series became so popular? Without a doubt, the writing and the screenplay and just that whole series as such is one of the best ones ever made! But I like to imagine, that people tend to oversee things and in this case those "things" are other brilliant series. Being said, that Breaking Bad was the first real drama series that made its way to public audience, it is self-evident that people are blinded by the light of a really good series. Of course the most of the people, that saw Breaking Bad, mentioned it as "the best series ever made", but I say that this is the only thing the most people are capable of saying.

What I mean is, that everyone loves Breaking Bad, because there were simply no other series to compare with. If you for the first time eat at a fast food restaurant, it is only natural to say, that "this was the best burger ever!", but to determine if it really was the "best burger ever" you will have to eat several burgers at several restaurants.

My personal problem is, that you can not claim something for "the best thing ever" if you have never seen something like it. I am clearly not willing to say, that you have to know everything about a thing to enjoy it, but the hole swarm of people that glorifies Breaking Bad so badly that you as a big fan start to question the whole series really grinds my gears.

So all in all it is a incredible masterwork and worth admiring, but you should - as always - think twice.

It seems to me that everyone loves this show on here, but I can't be the only one who sees big problems with Breaking Bad. First of all, how can anyone possibly think this show has great writing!? I have to admit that the first season had promise and I thought it could and should get better with the second season, but it turned out I was way off. Every single character is a stereotype! I'll start with the "bad guys". Tuco and his cousins? What is that!? Tuco's acting and actions are way over the top to be anywhere close to being believable. As for his cousins.. every time they came on screen, I just wanted to laugh out loud with how ridiculous and cheesy they were(lol at the dragging the axe scenes straight out of a horror B-movie). Gus anyone? Another way over the top stereotype of a business-man/gangster character who you want to punch in the face to get that stupid look off his face. The "good guys" are not much better. Starting with Pinkman and his unbelievably stupid actions and arguments with Walt that make absolutely no sense and seem to be put in there to make some sort of suspense between the characters. Although Hank is getting more interesting as the seasons go on, in the first 2 seasons though he was somewhat of a comic relief type with jokes that failed miserably. Now we have Saul replacing him, who's failing even worse. Skyler is just very annoying. Another thing to be seen across the reviews is good acting. I'm sorry I just don't see it, excluding Bryan Cranston/Walter White. Who is the only interesting character that made me watch 3 seasons of this ridiculous over the top storytelling and acting.

It started interesting but lost steam pretty fast and around season 2 or 3 the story started going in circles and resorting to all the tricks writers use when they run out of inspiration, never-ending problems, characters acting like parodies of themselves, any conversation was a shouting contest, heavy doses of annoying drama were introduced, tension was artificially created in a not so subtle way and once in a while the plot was moving forward, occasionally. The last season actually raised the level back up a little, but the previous one felt extremely tedious.

The production quality remained higher than a really low-grade cash-cow week-day afternoon show so it was still watchable without too much fast-forwarding, but the ingredients of a tired idea producers want to squeeze to the last drop are so obvious to me that its unbelievable, passionate success is a true mystery to me. People are not very demanding.

I can't find any fault with the show, even the least impressive episodes still were engaging and even thought I felt that the 4th Season was superior to the 5th Season, I still thought that the 5th Season was sublime because it shows the downfall of Walter White.

As for the progression of the show? It improved with each season, building on the rise, dominance, and downfall of Walter White. We see him go from a pathetic loser to a drug dealing criminal mastermind and his eventual fall from glory by the final season.

Quintessentially, this is a perfect tv show. No flaws, no issues, and so well composed that even the least interesting episodes are still engaging to watch because the show was planned out with a beginning, middle, and end. Each episode is crucial to the plot and everything is strong.

The show follows the story of Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher who turns to a life of crime, producing and selling crystal meth, after he is diagnosed with cancer. My favourite aspect of the show is its extremely tight writing, but its complex characters and exceptional performances, especially Bryan Cranston as Walter White are a close second.

I've rated Breaking Bad a 10 out of 10 as it is an absolute marvel of television storytelling that kept me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. The show's combination of humor, drama, and suspense is masterful, and its character development is unparalleled by any show I've ever seen. The show's themes of power, morality, and redemption are explored in such intensive depth, that it makes Breaking Bad not only a thrilling ride, but a thought-provoking meditation on the human condition. If you're a fan of television drama or even television series in general, Breaking Bad is a must-watch series that I believe would leave a lasting impression on anyone who watches it.

Breaking Bad is as close to perfection that seems possible. It seems like we have been lead to believe that to have it all is not possible. You can have good writing and poor acting. Great acting supporting a flimsy plot. Great writing and acting but ineffective direction.

This show delivers on everything. The direction has a clear vision and is expertly and artistically executed. The acting from every character is superb, truly superb. The buddy comedy elements are subtle and engaging.

The writing deserves special note. In Shakespeare's tragedies the plot is always a decision or event from which everything organically stems. Every event in the show follows a stream of logic. There is nothing that is dredged forth to progress the plot, it is all the outcome of a few decisions. Breaking Bad is the same. There is no convenient plot devices or deus ex machina. No magic to dig the writers out of a corner like in Lost or characters acting out of character.

I honestly cannot think of a fault in this program. It is truly lightning in a bottle.

Great characters and a great script, if it wasn't so needlessly long. This series could have been reduced by about 50% and been an amazing action packed show. I get it, people love it. For me, it took about one and a half seasons to start getting interesting, kept me relatively engaged until a couple episodes into season 5 - after that, I was ready for it to be over. There are some great scenes all throughout, including season 5, but lordy, it's slow.

I was a late watcher of Game of Thrones, absolutely incredible and rated slightly lower on IMDb than this, so I went into this with high expectations. Cranston's acting and character is really great, but the writing or storylines or whatever it is just had me bored.

Also character Skyler White is extremely annoying. I read articles where Gunn said its 'sexism', but to me that is such a cop out statement and such BS. At first I saw her as the concerned wife, but then it turned into nagging, meddling, and making everything about herself even after Walton revealed his sickness. Then when Walton finally came around and gave her the attention and presence she'd been looking for, she wanted to act like a brat pretending to be so unbothered and uninterested. That is such immature feminine behavior as oppose to handling it all like a real woman, and has nothing to do with sexism. Give me a break. I couldn't help but roll my eyes every time her scenes came up.

Anyway, that's my two cents.

Of course one would have to be living under a rock these past few years to not have heard about Breaking Bad. Many suggested I see it, but the idea to me was absurd to watch a mild mannered science teacher descend into the world of drug dealing, while having his soul wither away. Well, we can all be wrong, and this was a call I missed. What on earth about the above premise could make for good and entertaining television? Everything. The acting, the directing, the writing, and every damn thing associated with this phenomenal show. My husband and I watched this on a "binge", the first show we ever did this with. Aside from having to get up for work the next day, we would debate at four am....."well, one more"? It draws you in, it hooks you, it makes you care. For the "good" guys, and the "bad" guys. Which, by the way, the lines between get very blurry. I'm waiting a year or so to watch in entirety again. I'm sure there is much I missed. And I'm not the only one I know who says they could not "shake" it when the show was over. I actually got a sense of depression! "No Walter tonight". "No Jesse tonight"! Whatever will I do!! In all my years of TV watching, I've never felt that. I even would occasionally relate to a character. Upon exiting my car one morning, someone almost came up on me quickly and cold have hit me. I had to BITE my tongue not to have the words " Yo! Bitch......." fly out of my mouth. To finish, Breaking Bad was the most unlikely program I would every imagine I would consider to be hands down the best television show I have ever had the pleasure to watch. And I'm confident I'll enjoy as much, if not more, the second time around. One last note. Some reviews referenced the brilliant soundtrack --which it was. Being a 1960's music aficionado, I almost jumped at the screen when an exquisitely placed "Crystal Blue Persuasion" just came out of nowhere. But...that's perfection.

Breaking Bad is undoubtedly one of the most gripping and masterfully crafted television shows of all time. From its captivating storytelling to its impeccable performances, it is an absolute triumph in the world of television.

First and foremost, the writing of Breaking Bad is truly exceptional. The show takes audiences on a thrilling journey that explores the transformation of Walter White, brilliantly portrayed by Bryan Cranston, from a mild-mannered chemistry teacher to a ruthless drug lord. The character development throughout the series is meticulous and compelling, as we witness Walter's descent into darkness and the moral dilemmas he faces along the way. The writing is consistently sharp, intense, and thought-provoking, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats with each episode.

In addition to the exceptional writing, the performances in Breaking Bad are nothing short of extraordinary. Bryan Cranston delivers a career-defining performance as Walter White, displaying a remarkable range of emotions and creating a character that is both sympathetic and deeply unsettling. Aaron Paul's portrayal of Jesse Pinkman, Walter's former student and partner in crime, is equally mesmerizing, capturing the complexities and vulnerabilities of his character with raw authenticity. The chemistry between Cranston and Paul is palpable, adding another layer of brilliance to the show.

Moreover, Breaking Bad boasts impeccable direction and cinematography. The visuals are stunning, with each shot meticulously composed to enhance the storytelling and create a distinct atmosphere. The use of color symbolism throughout the series is particularly notable, as the shifting color palette reflects the characters' transformations and the moral ambiguity they grapple with.

One of the most commendable aspects of Breaking Bad is its unwavering commitment to realism. The show does not shy away from the harsh realities of the drug trade and the consequences of the characters' actions. It explores the ethical and moral implications of Walter's choices, forcing viewers to confront their own values and beliefs. This commitment to authenticity, combined with its gripping narrative, elevates Breaking Bad to a level of storytelling that is truly exceptional.

In conclusion, Breaking Bad is a masterpiece in every sense of the word. Its impeccable writing, exceptional performances, and meticulous attention to detail make it a groundbreaking show that will undoubtedly stand the test of time. Whether you are a fan of intense dramas or simply appreciate outstanding television, Breaking Bad is an absolute must-watch.
All time favorite TV series of mine in world. "I am the Danger". I am speechless after watching last episode of this TV series.

Series definitely among the best in the world, without any doubt.

It is so noticeable that the series was written all together and that its writing is not dictated by box office. The connections there are between the first and last episodes are noteworthy.

The actors play one better than the other, the director does not miss a beat, the director does not dare beyond what he can do, but what he can do he does perfectly.

A TV series that is probably unrepeatable given today's film economics systems that dictate a lot of the unfolding of TV series, which a breaking bad on the other hand does not exist at all.

The series could have a sequel, which although it would leave its fans embarrassed would collect the millions, but instead it does not come out, it does not come out because breaking bad is not like other series.

Breaking Bad is just one of those shows that is intelligently written with brilliant acting. Everything about it is top notch. Bryan Cranston who is well known to TV audiences for his role in Malcolm in the Middle is cast against type as anti-hero Walter White. Aaron Paul nails it perfectly as small time criminal Jesse Pinkman.

Walter White (Bryan Cranston) is an overqualified high school chemistry teacher who is struggling to make ends meet with his loving wife Skyler (Anna Gunn) and his son Walter Jr. (RJ Mitte) who has to live with cerebral palsy. When Walter is diagnosed with Stage 3A inoperable lung cancer, Walter must find a way to ensure his family is financially secure after he passes away. Walt embarks on a career of drugs and crime by forming an uneasy alliance with Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul), one of Walter's former students turned small time criminal. Together with Walt's brilliant scientific knowledge and Jesse's street smarts they both start manufacturing and selling a unique "blue sky" methamphetamine which proves to be a success in the drug market. Walt must also keep this hidden not only from his family but his brother in law DEA Agent Hank Schrader (Dean Norris) and his wife Marie (Betsy Brandt) who is also Skyler's sister. Under the pseudonym "Heisenberg" Walter transforms from a moral, mild mannered citizen to a ruthless, intimidating criminal.

Bryan Cranston was a true deserved recipient of every accolade and award for his role as Walter White. He was fantastic and without a doubt this will be a very memorable moment for the rest of his career.

Aaron Paul as Jesse Pinkman was a breakout role for him. Previously known for bit parts in an assortment of movies, Breaking Bad certainly put Aaron Paul on the map. Here he shines alongside Bryan Cranston.

Creator Vince Gilligan who cut his teeth on The X Files has produced a brilliantly intelligent TV series that has never had one dull moment. There's plenty of dark humour, shock moments, mature themes that explore the ugly side of the drug lifestyle, and non-stop moments that will make you smile. The show still retains a lot of realism and believability and nothing is over exaggerated nor over the top in order to entertain and attract viewers. The cinematography was also brilliant and captures not only Walter White and Jesse Pinkman's interactions, but also the supporting characters that hold up the show. Breaking Bad was also well known for being (in)famous for putting Albuquerque, New Mexico well and truly on the map. Albuquerque is also well known for attracting a large number of loyal fans of Breaking Bad with fans spotting Walter's house and Jesse's house as well as certain spots where Breaking Bad was filmed.

Breaking Bad is definitely one of the finest shows of all time and well and truly deserved every single acclaim. Even though the show ran from 2008-2013, there are still many fans of the show that still sing its praises. Bryan Cranston and Aaron Paul will also be remembered for their best roles of their respective careers.

Breaking Bad is still a pleasure to revisit, and those that have not seen the series yet are missing out on top notch television at its finest.

A well deserved 10/10.

I heard amazing things about the show from friends who are on the latest series right now. so i started looking into the show and seeing what it was like and i read so many good things on IMDb and other review sites saying it was the greatest show ever so naturally i was very excited about it.

So i brought season one and started watching and i even text my friend after episode one saying how amazing it was so i sat there and watched like episodes 1, 2 and 3 all in one go and LOVED it. but then i got onto episode four and i was bored, the show went from being super entertaining to watching a guy on screen doing absolutely nothing. I have no idea why people like this show. I cannot find a single redeeming trait, not one. The acting is horrible, the characters unlovable, the story-line crap, the directing idiotic, nothing about this show works for me. I have tried to watch it so many times because so many love this show, but honestly the show gets worse for each try I make. I seldom hand out a one (1), I save those for the worst crap ever made such as The Flash, so I will give this a 2, but that feels too much.

I have no clue how this show dropped from a 9.5 to a 9.4 but I can guarantee this is the single best show ever created. There isn't a time where an element doesn't work. This show has amazing actors, characters and a story that has many twists and turns but still manages to be believable with the best and most satisfying ending to any show I have ever watched.

Hopefully there will be better series in the future, but not up till now. The GARBAGE that is Game of Thrones season 8 and the way that season ruined the entire series made me appreciate BB all anew. The best series hitherto, easily.

This is a very good show, don't get me wrong... but it's not on par with several HBO shows like "The Wire" or "The Sopranos"... or even "Boardwalk Empire"

The main problems I have are that many of the decisions made by the main characters are too illogical... the character arcs go up and down and don't feel realistic... Jesse is by far the worst, it feels like Walt should be alot smarter than he actually is... and the two sisters Marie and Skylar are infuriating.

Then other characters like Hank and Walter Jr. Are well written and feel so much more realistic... in fact that goes for everyone besides Walt, Jesse, Skylar and Marie... they go from inspiring sympathy to absolute hatred from episode to episode.

The best shows on HBO through the years relied on realism and well written characters and the quality difference is enormous from shows on AMC.

A good show, maybe the best show for a cable channel... but this doesn't compare to HBO.

One of the best series to be ever made for TV. This drama made with a calculated budget unlike game of thrones was never boring. Kudos for the great story by Vince Gilligan. By the time i finished the final episode i am spell bound. The camera work, music, editing and what not - everything worked for breaking bad. Walter played by Bryan Cranston will make you feel for him and at times will even turn you bad. He blurs the line between good and bad. The script is so solid that you can hardly find loopholes in any episode. All your feelings, emotions, attitude are brought to life by this guy. Watch the series to understand what it is to be alive. Don't miss this one.

After the last and utterly disappointing season of Game of Thrones it's finally crystal clear that Breaking Bad is the greatest TV show ever made. Vince Gilligan and the fellow incredible writers of Breaking Bad please save Game of Thrones and team up with HBO to remake the utterly disappointing season 8. We can only dream that much though. Breaking Bad on the contrary with Game of Thrones ended on a very high note that complemented the quality of the previous seasons and even surpassed them. Breaking Bad is a monolithic milestone of television and cinematic art form in general and quite possibly the greatest character study and arc ever presented on the cinematic medium. Breaking Bad serves as an enchanting vignette of sin, the importance of family, power and its corrupting influence, envy and regret, evolution and decay, rise and fall and this seamlessly intertwined amalgamation of brilliant direction, impeccable writing, gorgeous and stylish cinematography, excellent soundtrack, incredible pacing, intricate plotting, captivating story, very extensive thematic depth, rich characterization and exquisite performances put on by its stellar cast, all contribute into making one of the greatest and pieces of cinema ever made with some of the finest characters ever written. With GoT out of the way Breaking Bad solidifies itself as the greatest TV show of all time with the Wire being a close second on my list.

I've never seen anything like this before. These so far two seasons about a man, a father, a husband, a chemical-teacher who gets cancer and start to try out as a drug dealer is a step-by-step-analysis of which consequences this decision can have on your life, family and friends. It's a emotionally roller-coaster ride without big gun shoot-outs or explosions though it shows that many mean things are getting to control your life.

This show doesn't fill every clich√©d that is connected to a drug dealer story so it can reach it's sure audience. No! It tries to figure out (and of course it never can be reality, but it's trying to get as close as it can) how to deal with these chliches when they're suddenly entering and ruling your ordinary, normal, average life.

You cannot call this a movie, though you'd like to, because it's the only thing that you can relate to that ever reached such quality. And this is why I don't want to devalue Breaking Bad just to a TV- Series that can be seen randomly on TV. Again: No! It's 15 Hours of high quality. It's 15 Hours of the best thing made out of picture and sound ever made. It's 15 Hours of Art. Art in Directing. Art in Cinematography and especially Art in Writing and Acting.

I love it!
A masterpiece of a serie and without even thinking 10/10.

I although agree that the show is great, and watching it is a fun, yet I do not agree that the story is not unnecessary stretched.
