After a few years after it started, a friend of mine recommended this show to me and I finally watched it. I was blown away. I have never watched a series more addictive or gripping in my entire life. After each episode, you'll just be wanting more and more. This show has everything such as perfect writing, unforgettable scenes and a top notch soundtrack.

Score: 10/10

John Wayne once said that the hallmark of a good actor is for the audience to watch an actor and not feel that they are actually acting. The screenplay/writing was beyond clever. It was brilliant. And the top notch acting combined by all the actors made this probably the best series I have ever watched over the last 22 years with the exception of the mini series Lonesome Dove which I would call a draw. Better than Alias, better than Dexter...both of which captivated me completely. Let me just put this into perspective. One of the greatest actors of our generation, Anthony Hopkins sat down, just as I did and did a marathon viewing of the show and praised not only Bryan Cranston (as one of the greatest actors he has seen) but the whole cast as one greatest acting ensembles ever gathered. I can't believe this came out of AMC.

They say that there are no new ideas, that everything has already been done once or twice. No, this wasn't the same old tired series, it wasn't a recycled good show. It proves that creativity hasn't died and that repeats and remakes are no longer completely necessary laziness. It showed that fresh creativity still exists. This show sucked me in to the characters, good or bad and made me sympathize with each of them. It made me feel like a hero and a low life criminal, a victim, a cop, it made me look at each side of me and blurred the lines between right and wrong. There was no black or white. Only shades of Grey and a narrative of the main character and others going from white to dark Grey and descending into total hell . Enough to conflict my soul for a long long time. Total excellence. :)

Emotions 11/10 Feeling 10/10

Directing 10/10 Screenplay 10/10 Acting 11/10

Cinematography 6/10 Soundtrack 7/10 Editing 7/10 Production Design 6/10

I certainly couldn't describe to anybody what Breaking Bad has meant to me. This show has made me laugh, made me cry, made me afraid, like no other show ever has. This is absolutely AMC's finest work. Now that it's over, I have got no clue what show I'll go to next.

I've got a ton of options: American Horror Story, Hell on Wheels, Dexter, Under The Dome, True Blood, The Bridge, The Killing, or Sons of Anarchy. I'm currently watching AMC's The Walking Dead, Low Winter Sun, and HBO's Game of Thrones. But I feel like I'm just replacing Breaking Bad, which is almost impossible.

The only reason I even watched this show was because season 3 of The Walking Dead had just ended. I needed another show to hold me off until season 4. I skimmed through Netflix and stumbled upon Breaking Bad, which got really great reviews. As it turns out, I liked Breaking Bad just a bit more than Walking Dead.

I watched season 1 just to see how it was. I loved it, so I watched season 2. I kept watching and watching and watching. I realized I was addicted/hooked when I watched all of season 3 in one day.

When season 5B started, I watched it every Sunday night. And now it's over. I have decided that Breaking Bad is the best show I've ever seen in my life. The final episode of the series was so gripping, so dramatic, almost painful to watch.

I truly recommend Breaking Bad to everybody who enjoys a good TV show.

This is my first review.

I have been waiting for something as big as Breaking Bad to write it.

This show is the best I have seen. The way Vince Gilligan plays with us, making us create theories about how next episode will be, shows that it really gets you hooked. Almost every episode leaves you wanting more.

I really like how this series use psychology and chemistry in a very amusing way, making you sometimes feel awkward or bad for the characters, that, by the way, are perfectly worked.

Today this series ended with Felina, that is the most satisfying ending the show could had.

I've seen so many headlines, so many articles, surveys, whatever, all say that Breaking Bad is the best TV series in history, and well I got to say, it is truly a masterpiece, I fell in love with absolutely every character, so magnificently written, amazing pacing and one of the greatest plots on a tv series I've seen, and don't get me started on the cinematography, every scene, every frame it's an absolute masterpiece.

Now when it comes to the Fly episode, I must say I've read so much saying it's the worst episode of the series, and it probably was one of the episodes I was most excited to watch (along with Ozymandias and Crawl Space), I enjoyed the fly episode, such shots and expression due to this fly, I analyzed it, wondering if the fly was even real, people who hate this episode can't tell what's going on unless it's shown explicitly on screen. Overall 10/10 The only readily I would put it a 9 it's because it's over. Amazing show, can't get enough of it.

This could easily have been done in two episodes with a little stretch maybe three. However, I get it that the creator and writers found a gullible audience and rightfully chose to milk it. Hurray to capitalism! Too many instances all throughout the show the situations are so ridiculously unrealistic as if the writers are saying: "In your face! You gullible audience (which equals lacking intelligence), eat this yet another bogusly impossible situations and outcomes because we got you captivated. We will twist and turn for another three seasons even though we are certain you can already predict the ending. But we'll come at you with excruciatingly brain numbing drama coupled with hyper extended slow character development. Just when we're finished painting the picture of a dimwit, we will make them carry out some out right spectacularly unbelievable MacGyver like witty narrow escape or some plainly uncharacterized heist."

Yeah! I allowed myself to be gullible, endured the insult on my intelligence because of some of the very little sound bites of science (Chemistry) and was hoping for a plot twist. Oh! Yes, the writers almost got the twist right a couple of times but quickly missed the opportunity by killing off the right characters for the plot twist. What a shame, had they gotten it right I would have been ready for a lot more seasons. BEWARE!!! If you are easily offended by shows that appear to insult your intelligence, this one is not subtle in that regard, find something else.

The wrong, most boring and repetitive characters were kept to the end. What a waste of time.

Truly a fantastic show with an epic build up. It's definitively one of the best shows to exist. Everything about this show is great. The build up of each character is fantastic. It has it's funny moments, it has drama and the epic violent moments that keep you watching. Every detail in the show is important and all the cliffhangers are totally worth it. The acting is fantastic and the plot is great. You really get to know and feel for the characters. Everyone did a fantastic job on this show and I'm definitely glad that I got to experience such a brilliant show.

"Nothing stops this train!".. you realize early on how accurate those words are, and the intensity only ramps-up as the episodes go by... unavoidably and ultimately heading towards a very dark place (and you start to make an educated guess how it is all going to end). It's a highly acclaimed, award winning show... with production values that are very high, and acting across the board that is outstanding. Bryan Cranston and Anna Gunn are pure gold.. his transformation to an uncontrollable monster, and her attempts at having to deal with all goes with it, is unquestionably remarkable work. There's really only a couple main characters in the entire show that are at all likable, the rest are drug-dealing criminals and low-life's, or damaged personalities. It was most disappointing to see the alluring Krysten Ritter.. bit.ly/15r7d1Z .. depart after so few episodes.. most fans would have truly liked to see her continue for another season or two. It was a loss for the show, having such a dynamic female character excised so quickly. Once she left, the only reason to stick with the series is to see how all plays out between Skyler and Walt. What is most at issue is the writing. The story just has numerous obvious and unbelievable elements that cannot be overlooked, although it appears most viewers are unabashedly willing to do so. It's not enough of a reason not to watch (although the recurring violence could really be a deal breaker for many). A solid 5-stars, not to say, it could have been better with just some minor script alterations.

What a sublime and religious experience it was to watch this series. Bryan Cranston has become a great favorite of mine. The series portrays him as a chemistry teacher Walter White, who is making ends meet by also working as a cashier in a garage after school hours.

One day he collapses. He finds out that he has lung cancer and not long to live. He decides to set aside a large sum of money for his family before he dies - partly to satisfy his ego and partly for the love of his family. He gets his inspiration from Hank Schrader his wife's brother-in -law who is a DEA agent. Hank invites Walter to a drug bust where he spies a dropout student of his Jesse Pinkman(Aaron Paul) discretely sneak away. Walter follows Jesse and tells him of a plan to start-up a meth lab and make a lot of money for themselves. They make a vow of complete secrecy.

The series then deals with unforeseeable events that arise when it comes to selling the meth discretely without drawing the attention of the DEA. Walter wants to sell the meth in large quantity, but Jesse tells him not to rush it and keep selling it in small amounts while still making a good sum of money. Walter keeps on pushing Jesse and we see the first tragic consequence of that action. From then onwards, it is a roller coaster ride full of highs and lows till the inevitable end of the trip.

The series is filled with colorful characters that you will remember for a lifetime, and an ending that will take your breath away...

More TV shows to see: Tales From The Crypt 1989, Masters Of Horror 2005, Fear Itself 2008, Tales From The Darkside 1983, The Twilight Zone 1985, The Outer Limits 1995.

A super realistic, naturally dramatic depiction of how drug dealing ensnares everyone around you. Every episode is either good or great with a few standouts (Ozymandias, Felina, Full Measure). The only reason it's not a 9 or 10 is because of some purely Hollywood moments that made little sense, a few decent plot points that made no sense, and mundane dialog that greatly extended the runtime (unnecessarily). The best example of this is Episode Fly, nearly all the episodes could have shaved 15 minutes off the runtime without losing any detail.

A friend told me I had to start watching in 2011. I watched first two episodes and quit, thinking...not really my cup of tea. I didn't understand what all the rage was about. Then in 2014 I decided to give it a real shot. The upside, I got to watch all the way through. By S1 E5 I was hooked, binged in 5 straight days. The character development is sensational. I cannot think of another show that let me feel the characters, truly feel them, as Breaking Bad did, and I've pretty much watched them all. People probably don't remember Brian Cranston as the Dad in "Malcolm In The Middle" and probably not much of anything he did before or after Breaking Bad, and it's not because he's not a fine actor. Once you climb the highest mountain, not much else seems that interesting. Do yourself a favor and watch now. I've done it thrice!

Completely by coincidence I began watching Breaking Bad, one of my friends posted a random facebook status, where he mentioned how he thought Breaking Bad was "king and season 5 was awesome"

I knew that the show existed because I continuously saw Bryan Cranston's very intense face on Netflix, but I never took further notice of it, and just went on seeing some other show. But after I saw that post on my timeline, I just gave the show a chance and decided to see the Pilot, which was the least I could do¬Ö. And man, was that a turning point, I mean outstandingly amazing Pilot, that just captures and overwhelms you.

A couple of minutes ago I finished all seasons and 1st half of season 5 which will be the last season. I am literally anxious to see the second 2nd half. Breaking Bad is the most intense, exciting, breathtaking, well-acted/directed TV-show I've ever seen, like really¬Ö ever. In the beginning, after I read the plot, I was a little unsure on how they were going to make this show anything but average. But they most certainly could.

I never heard of Bryan Cranston before Breaking Bad, I later found out that I saw him briefly in 'Argo' but that was it. So I didn't know what I could expect acting wise, I guess I wasn't that quick to appreciate his significant performance throughout the first season, because well, I don't know. But somewhere a long the road of season two, I just became more or less speechless of his stunning talent and so terribly convincing acting. The way Walter White changes through the series made me reflect back on season one where I found him so innocent, and thinking this thing with cooking will pass sometime soon, but of course it didn't Bryan Cranston breaths new life into everything he touch as being Walter White, and this character just gives me a roller- coaster ride. I went from thinking he was innocent and trying to help out his family, to completely have nothing left for him and I have like zero sympathy for him anymore. He is manipulating everything around him, I mean everything, but my mind is really torn on how I want this show to end, I don't really have an opinion, like I believe Vince Gilligan has the best ending in his sleeve ready for us.

Aaron Paul as Jesse Pinkman, was just amazing. I think Aaron Paul is really, really talented and the chemistry between him and Cranston is unquestionably the best I have seen for a while. I loved the character of Jesse from second one, he gives the show the humorous side of it, and his waterfall of talking and phrases is just brilliant. He begins the show like a bit of a around-on- the-floor-type-of-guy, but I mean that he changes into something that he can be proud of, I mean the man got his challenges, who doesn't? But he is the human of the show, or at least he develops into. He is the character who cries the most, I mean red-eyed, tear dropping crying, and who is like affected about all the craziness that is going on: The numerous victims and sacrifices and the feeling of almost getting caught, and always have to get something out of the way, or constantly fighting for your life. His focus goes from being wealthy to not really care about being rich at all, like he has realized what stuff that ‚Äì indeed - means something. I am really glad, that he didn't get cut off the show. I mean where would it have been without Jesse Pinkman and Aaron Pauls tremendous portrayal of him.

This is so well-written, and so credible story that just keeps getting stronger season for season. Which I believe is very unique, how many times have I not been sitting back watching a really good series fall apart because it keeps going on for no reason? This does not fall apart. It only gets better, stronger, more intense and more exciting through all seasons. This story could be, it actually could be realistic in some aspects, and this just shows how a life really can hit a turning point that changes you and your surroundings forever, and that is realistic.

The cast, the entire cast is incredible, and the writers, directors, everyone involved in this project have created a legend in form of Walter White, and not to mention that they have created one of the best show the world has seen (according to me of course) I have to mention Aaron Paul again, because he is also a very big reason for this show success. He is just unbelievable good.

I'm excitingly waiting for the last 8 episodes. I'm sad that I have to say goodbye to Jesse and Walter but I guess its for the best. Vince Gilligan has made a masterpiece, that I guarantee will be remembered, and every single award this show has received, every piece of critical acclaim it has received, has been very much deserved.

Breaking Bad is a work of art. It is always going somewhere. It seems that from the beginning they planned it to be five seasons long because everything falls into place and everything is pointing towards an inevitable ending.

Every character in the show is fantastic. The worst ones (as in antagonistic) are filled with redeeming qualities, and also the protagonists are filled with flaws. They all change throughout the series and this is also something that makes it worth watching. This makes your allegiance towards them change, and having such a strong arch makes even some of the secondary characters as complex as some of the best you've seen on film.

It has a tendency to always go in the direction you never expected, but this always works better for the story and it fits into place with more grace than you've ever imagined.

I've been watching Breaking Bad ever since AMCTV announced the beginning season in 2008. I was intrigued by the plot line. Once I viewed Episode 1 of Season 1, I was hooked.

First, I can't praise Breaking Bad enough. Everything about the series is absolutely tops. The script (hats off to Vince Gilligan) delivers a consistently high quality, and suspenseful, drama episode after episode and season after season that keeps us viewers on the edge of our seats. The acting is phenomenal. Almost all the actors were unknowns to me. And yet every one of them came across as totally believable as human beings in every scene where they occurred. Every one of them delivered a spot-on performance and I mean even the minor characters like Jesse's buddies, Skinny Pete and Badger. No weak acting in any scene. And the direction and cinematography were outstanding. Anyone who understands films knows all these elements‚Äïscript, actors, director, cinematography‚Äïall play a vital role in making a great movie. And they're all there in Breaking Bad, and I might add, all consistently there season after season. Especially the script and the acting.

As an aside, Hollywood badly needs to take a lesson from Breaking Bad. More and more of the movies coming out of Hollywood rely heavily on an exorbitantly paid movie actor to pull the crowd, CGI, blasting loud music, and shoot-'em-up / blow-'em-up scenes. Watching the trailers of such movies, I find myself wondering how many automobiles suffered a horrific death to make the movie.

From the beginning in Season 1 we've watched the principal character, Walter (aka Walt) White, start out as a dedicated family man and high school chemistry teacher in Albuquerque, New Mexico. One day while working at his car-wash job, he passes out. At the doctor's he discovers he has intractable cancer. He's a decent man, mild-mannered, and dumped on by many people, including the Romanian-American owner of the car wash where he works part-time to supplement his meager teacher salary.

Walt's a guy who so loves his family that he really wants to leave them enough money to survive after he's gone because he doesn't make enough money teaching chemistry and working at the car wash to afford better life insurance. One day his brother-in-law, Hank Schrader, a DEA agent in Albuquerque, takes him along on a meth bust. A fatal turn in Walt's life. He notices immediately that most meth cookers aren't chemists and he knows he could do a far superior job if he set his mind to it. The beginning slide down the slippery slope.

While along on the bust, he sees a young man clamber out of a second story window of the adjacent house, drop to the ground, and scamper away unnoticed by the DEA agents. But not unnoticed by Walt, who recognizes him as a former student in his chemistry class and who wasn't exactly what one would call a stellar student. Enter Jesse Pinkman. And another fatal turn in Walt's life. It was Pinkman's lab that was busted by the Feds, and Walt seeks out Jesse and propositions him. Walt'll cook the meth and Jesse will run the distribution operation. Walt figures he can make enough money this way to provide for his family when he's gone. Soon he's producing an extremely high grade of crystalline methamphetamine quickly known in the trade as "blue sky." By the end of Season 1 he's been forced to murder a young man and feels very distraught about it. But of course this is another fatal turn in Walt's life and a further slide down the slippery slope. Soon bodies are falling all around him right and left. Some murdered by him personally and some murdered at his behest.

It's made clear in Episode 1 (summer 2013) of Breaking Bad that Walter White is still alive at season's end. He's a disheveled, worn-out, desperate man on the run. He's returned to his fenced-in, abandoned house in Albuquerque. He says hello to his former neighbor, Carole, who is so startled by him and by his appearance that she drops her load of laundry and holds her hand up to her mouth in utter shock.

Walter White doesn't die a physical death, at least not by the season's finale. Along the way from being the good high school teacher who wanted to provide for his family to becoming Heisenberg, the greatest meth kingpin ever, he's warped his soul more and more into an unrecognizable human being to the people who love him. In this season's Episode 2 standing directly in from of Walt but staring blankly into space Hank mumbles, "I don't even know who I'm talking to." Walter White has died spiritually. He is no longer the Walter White Hank affectionately called the brainiac. But who is he?

He's a man who's traversed one end of the spectrum of good and evil to the other end. In this season's Episode 3 we hear Jesse Pinkman's voice-over warning us: "Mr. White, he's the devil." But no human being, no matter how evil they've become, is completely evil. They still preserve a residue of their humanity. A tiny glowing ember of what's left of their soul. They can still feel emotional pain. They can still love their family and long for them. They can still show compassion. And that in the end is what makes human beings so unique. We can never venture totally beyond good and evil. The Old Testament expresses it well: Behold, the man is become as one of us, to know good and evil. Genesis Chapter 3:22. But it's not enough to know good and evil. We are bound morally to use this knowledge to prevent our desires from driving us to utter destruction. For our own sake, for the sake of our loved ones, and for the sake of humanity. As brilliant as Walter White was, he failed to grasp this crucial moral imperative.

So, I am writing a no spoiler review for the show, AFTER THE FINALE AIRED. There are a few shows I could consider perfect, well, currently only two....the Sopranos and Breaking Bad. OK in no way am I trying to compare the two, except they both exceed my expectations. Before watching Breaking Bad, there is two things you should know, 1) The description "A chemistry teacher who makes meth." is not what the show is about, that is just the first episode character development plays a huge role, 2)the entire series takes place in about a two year period of time (ruling out some rare flashbacks), basically seasons 1-someof 5 are in one year and sometime in 5-finale have bigger time gaps.

Breaking Bad is a marvelous show, it has dark humor and very dark events, so there are some shocking scenes. It just kept getting better and better is a great summary for the show, because when events happen in Breaking Bad, it is shocking, the violence isn't overused and the writing is phenomenal, the thing about this show is that no one is really off limits, anything can happen to anyone at anytime.

Another thing that makes this show great is that tension builds, and when things fall apart you can only watch in horror and shock. The story follows Walter H. White, a father, a husband, a person who doesn't take charity. He earns his money, he has to earn it, for his family......speaking of family, Walt has a brother-in-law in the DEA, I understand that the double life thing seems a little overplayed, but it really works great here.

The cast is perfect, Hank, Walt's brother-in-law really reminded me of someone I know in real life, he is funny, sometimes racist, but he has a place in his heart for family. Then there is Skylar, she is Walt's wife and Anna Gunn does a fantastic job playing her, then there is Jesse, but you'll have to watch the show.

From the hooking beginning to the final episode (which was glorious) Breaking Bad just keeps getting better and better, though I am sad it ended, it was a great run.

Cranston became my favourite comedy actor in Malcolm in the Middle, his timing is impeccable and his physicality brought a freshness to his performance. In Breaking Bad he proves that he is not limited in any way to comedy. Supported by a great cast of more than competent actors (with a special mention for Aaron Paul) Cranston is riveting as a terminally ill chemistry teacher who turns to the dark side to provide for his soon-to-be bereaved family.There are elements of comedy in Breaking Bad-very,very black comedy but comedy nonetheless and that too strikes just the right note in the writing and performances. Not one bit of this story would work if any of the writing,direction or acting was wrong. Everything is spot on. The characters are not written or played as stereotypes and the script is tight and drives the story along. The whole enterprise is about as absorbing as drama can be and one cannot wait to see what happens from one episode to the next- and what happens is never predictable. As for the people who throw up their hands in horror and say that a programme like this glorifies drug dealing and drug use, then watch the damn thing!! If ever a programme shows what drugs do to people then BB does. A real cautionary tale.

I am into series 2 now and hope that the standard continues in the third series. A terrific example of what can be done with TV drama when playing it safe is off the agenda.

Breaking Bad is an American crime drama television series created and produced by Vince Gilligan. The show originally aired on the AMC network for five seasons, from January 20, 2008 to September 29, 2013. The main character is Walter White (Bryan Cranston), a struggling high school chemistry teacher who is diagnosed with inoperable lung cancer at the beginning of the series. He turns to a life of crime, producing and selling methamphetamine, in order to secure his family's financial future before he dies, teaming with his former student, Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul). The show was set and produced in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

Throughout the series, Walter produces and sells meth to earn money in order to secure the financial future of his family: his wife Skyler (Anna Gunn), and children Walter, Jr. (RJ Mitte) and Holly (Elanor Anne Wenrich). The show also features Skyler's sister Marie Schrader (Betsy Brandt), and her husband Hank (Dean Norris), a Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) agent who is determined to solve the case involving the meth empire. Walter teams up with lawyer Saul Goodman (Bob Odenkirk), who helps him get into contact with drug kingpin Gus Fring (Giancarlo Esposito). In the fifth season, Walter heavily involves himself with Mike Ehrmantraut (Jonathan Banks), Todd Alquist (Jesse Plemons) and Lydia Rodarte-Quayle (Laura Fraser).

In 2014, Breaking Bad entered the Guinness World Records as the highest rated show of all time.

This will grip you on in the first episode I'm now obsessed with it. It's genius I love every shot, every millisecond. You think you know where it's going: you don't, you think it's just another show: it's not

Pure art. Pure suspense. Pure thrill. Pure comedy. Pure story. Pure meth!

You know what movies (particularly drama), show us? Actors playing some story making the audience, think it as a real life experience. But whatever movie/TV series it is, at some point of time, you get disengaged with grip of the reality of drama and think, that actually is a movie. Of course, who am I kidding! it is a movie. But do you want to get an experience where you wouldn't feel like you're watching a movie, but rather to have a kind of immersion in the story and get all the excitement and suspense you'd get in your life, if Breaking Bad's story happened for real? Then, don't turn your back on this.

From beginning to end, you feel like you're watching the one that happened to be in television's most dark and thrilling adventurous storyline you'd ever experience as a real one in life.

For people who say the play is slow and dull - First of all, you people don't get the sense of an art of making a movie. For the watcher, to believe, director should develop a storyline to be real. So I suggest, while you're watching this, and if you get bore, then rethink. Because that part of the scene will be a prerequisite for rest of the plot. Every frame, every scene, pays off!

For people who say the play consists uncanny bloodshed and obnoxious language - Yes, it does. But, do you want to get the reality of situations the actors face according to the plot? If no, then don't watch.

I am not exaggerating here but I'd say this - If I ever get a supernatural power to erase a part of memory from my brain, then I'd delete the memory what is considered to be the experience I got from breaking bad. Just because, I can watch it again. Nevertheless, no matter how many times you watch, you just scratch your head, how brilliant this is.

Finally, for people who haven't seen it yet - I envy you guys. But, only if you want to watch. Breaking bad is a benchmark. I doubt any TV series surpasses this in the future.

To provide for his family (pregnant wife Anna Gunn and teenager son RJ Mitte)'s future after he is diagnosed with lung cancer, a chemistry genius called Wlter (Bryan Cranston) turned high school teacher teams up with an ex-student named Jesse to cook and sell the world's purest crystal methamphetamine proves to be remarkably proficient in this new world as he begins manufacturing and selling Methamphetamine with one of his former students . Though his talent for chemistry appears to be wasted at the high school level , Walter does seems to enjoy bringing science to young minds . He join forces with Jesse (Aaron Paul), a former student of Walter White's at High School , he is now a producer and occasional user of Meth, known in the area as "Cap'n Cook." This affinity for teaching and respect themselves can be seen in the relationship between Walter and Jesse . As Walter thrust into a partnership with an irresponsible, burn-out criminal . The Meth makes them very rich very quickly, but it attracts the attention of his DEA brother in law , Hank (Dean Norris) , who is always hot on his tail.

A main plot point of Breaking Bad concerns the main character, Walt, being a bona fide chemistry genius being accompanied by Aaaron Paul as Jesse who is the classic underachiever , he clearly possesses talents, but is lacking dramatically when it comes to common sense and follow-through . Amusing as well entertaining relationship between Walter/Bryan Cranston and Jesse/Aaron Paul, this paves the way for a classic Odd Couple dynamic as the conservative middle-aged teacher . Very good acting by all cast such as Walter , a mature chemistry teacher at Wynne High School in Albuquerque, New Mexico , he is diagnosed with lung cancer and given approximately two years to live , Aaron Paul as Jesse , he grew up in a somewhat privileged home, the oldest child of an upper middle class Albuquerque family, Jesse was ultimately kicked out of his home due to repeated drug use ; Anna Gunn as Skyler , she is no shrinking violet , she is fiercely protective of her children will do whatever she can to keep them shielded from dangerous influences , she is a patient woman, but that patience will become tested as Walter descends deeper in the seedy world of the meth trade and Dean Norris as an agent with the Drug Enforcement Agency in Albuquerque , he is married to Skyler White's sister, Marie, finely performed by Betsy Brendt , he has a somewhat stereotypical personality for an officer of the law, a gruff, mans man who is cynical about criminals and has aspirations to climb the ladder in the DEA, perhaps moving to a larger department or to headquarters in Washington. Other import characters of this series are the followings : Bob Odenkirk as Saul Goodman . Steven Michael Quezada as Steven Gomez , Jonathan Banks as Mike Ehrmantraut and Giancarlo Esposito as Gustavo 'Gus' Fring . Sony and AMC producers of the series were initially reluctant to cast Bryan Cranston because of his previous comedic roles and considered both John Cusack and Matthew Broderick for Walter White. When they both declined, Vince Gilligan got to cast Cranston .The actor who portrays Walter Jr. in the series (RJ Mitte), actually has cerebral palsy like his character on the show. However, his real life affliction is much milder than his role's, and he had to learn to walk with crutches and slow down his speech to play the part. Rating : 7.5/10 . Above average. Essential and indispensable watching.

When I heard the learn'd astronomer, When the proofs, the figures, were ranged in columns before me, When I was shown the charts and diagrams, to add, divide, and measure them, When I sitting heard the astronomer where he lectured with much applause in the lecture-room, How soon unaccountable I became tired and sick, Till rising and gliding out I wander'd off by myself, In the mystical moist night-air, and from time to time, Look'd up in perfect silence at the stars.

Simply put, this is the greatest show I have ever seen. If you haven't started it yet and are still unsure, believe the hype. OK, so a show about an underachieving, middle-class family man deciding to sell Meth with a drop out student of his doesn't sound like the formula for the best TV show in history, but you'd be surprised what a little psychotic alter-ego can do to a man who secretly wants to be king (albeit a meth-king).

The performances, writing, directing, camera work etc are all sublime. It all culminates in creating a world of characters with so much depth, so much attention gone into them that so many of them will surely go down as iconic. What separates this show above all else for me is how all 5 seasons really do feel like one long episode. There are no continuity errors, everything is meticulously planned, even the smallest throw away line or action will come back to haunt someone later on.

Some episodes are slow and some episodes feel like you're watching a bomb go off in slow motion, but the payoffs in this show are like nothing else in TV history. I could binge watch my way through this show again tomorrow...you know what, I just might!

Created and produced by G. Vince Gilligan OBE's going his way - just like the late Spike Milligan. Well, now then lets see where on earth do I begin? I guess you can definitely say that this bloke is Breaking Bad. Why he was willing to throw away all that he as ever had. Walt wants to give a fine financial future for his family. Mr White knows they will turn on his actions angrily. Walter had a job as a chemistry teacher in high school. Also in a car wash called A1 not too particularly cool. That name should get them to the top of anybody's list. Top of the Boss's list was to make Walt miserably pi***d! Now his main aim is Making Meth in the mobile RV. Doing the deed gets done where nobody can see. Only ending in one way I'm sure you'll agree. Would it be a dreadful D - I - V - O - R - C - E? Or more tragically a trip to the Hospitals A&E? So why did this guy turn to a complicated life of corrupt crime? Did he want to live life differently - this time be more sublime? It all starts when a Sir called Walter White finds out he is dying. His treatment costs so much money - now there is no denying. We certainly can't condone - for this gent is only trying. It's unlawful what he's making it really is high flying! "Blue Ice" is so pure the meth heads can't help buying! While the whole time this Master Meth maker's bare faced lying! Causing many people heartache they only end up crying. At times his acts are barbaric and seem totally unfair. Is the reason because the treatment has zapped out all his hair? Though his needs are a must so who can really blame him? It's not like us humans don't divulge in the odd sin. Walter seems to take the news of Cancer in his stride. If you ask me it is a big deal and can be tricky to hide. Walt seems to be enjoying this repulsing roller coaster ride. Guilt is way too much but it's really a small price to pay. All his loving family and friends in Albuquerque he'd betray. Especially his brother in law - Hank who is in the D.E.A. Hank gives Walt insight on how to keep the feds at bay. Helps him keep one step ahead thus avoiding any feds raids. Mr W. is involved in one of the biggest illegal drug trades. Shouldn't think it will bring this mad man many accolades. Fortunately Hank hasn't a clue - not one little idea. At times it's like the end of these shenanigans are near. Walt's decided to cover his identity with just one major word. Came up with the name of a chemist called - Heisenberg. Of course he needed a right hand man with know how and nouse. Jesse Pinkman's who it is he ends up losing his way and a house! Some would say he was a degenerate scumbag or simply a louse. Walter liked his guts and also that he could be as timid as a mouse. Named Captain Cook Jesse knew all ins and outs of the game. So to him it's simply second nature though to us it's quite insane! This pair tettered on the edge of fear never a day that's mundane. Do you think Heisenberg really wanted to cause his family so much pain?

Breaking Bad is an American crime drama television series created and produced by Vince Gilligan. Set and filmed in Albuquerque, New Mexico, the series follows Walter White (Bryan Cranston), an underpaid, overqualified, and dispirited high-school chemistry teacher who is struggling with a recent diagnosis of stage-three lung cancer. White turns to a life of crime and partners with a former student, Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul), to produce and distribute crystal meth to secure his family's financial future before he dies, while navigating the dangers of the criminal underworld. The show aired on AMC from January 20, 2008, to September 29, 2013, consisting of five seasons for a total of 62 episodes.

Breaking Bad is a meticulously crafted and perfected piece of art

This series follows Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher who is diagnosed with terminal lung cancer and decides to partner up with a former student named Jesse Pinkman to cook meth in order make enough money for his family before he dies.

In the first episode of the series Walter White says "Chemistry is the study of change" This is the main theme of the series, change. Watching his descent into evil or how the creator of the series (Vince Gilligan) put it "You take Mr. Chips and turn him into Scarface" is one of the most riveting things I have ever experienced. Bryan Cranston plays him to perfection. He has received 5 Emmies total and all were for this series, 4 of those 5 were for his performance. Anthony Hopkins wrote him a letter saying that he gave the best performance he had ever seen. Not to mention Aaron Paul was just as phenomenal as Jesse Pinkman, who is easily the most tragic character I have ever witnessed. At the beginning of the series, though was very likable and funny especially with his constant use of the word for a female dog, he was not very bright. But as the series continued he became more mature because of everything he goes through. Their conflicting relationship was one of if not the best thing of the whole series. Clearly this series in a very good way takes lots of inspiration from classic westerns. In particular ones that were directed by Sergio Leone. The cinematography from Michael Slovis is beautiful the series has a very distinct look from other TV Shows. Vince Gilligan said in an interview that film noir was a source of inspiration for the series, which makes sense considering that many of the shots are very noir esque.

But overall, Breaking Bad is without a doubt the greatest TV Show of all time because of the fantastic acting, directing, writing, character development, cinematography and so much more.

I heard about this show a lot by my friends and colleagues so I finally watched it, and yes it was the best decision of my life lol.. I can confidently say that it is an absolute masterpiece and a show that truly stands the test of time. From the moment I started watching, I was hooked by the gripping storyline, the phenomenal acting performances, and the impeccable execution of every aspect of the show.

Breaking Bad excels in every department. The acting performances are nothing short of extraordinary, with Bryan Cranston's portrayal of Walter White being a masterclass in character development. His transformation from a mild-mannered high school chemistry teacher to a ruthless drug lord is utterly mesmerizing. Aaron Paul's performance as Jesse Pinkman is equally brilliant, and the chemistry between Cranston and Paul on screen is simply outstanding.

The show's writing is top-notch, with each episode leaving me on the edge of my seat, eager to find out what happens next. The drama, suspense, and thrill are perfectly balanced, creating a rollercoaster of emotions throughout the series. The character arcs are well-crafted, making us deeply invested in their journeys and choices.

Breaking Bad's attention to detail and storytelling finesse are unparalleled. Every plot twist and turn feels natural and unexpected, keeping the viewer engaged and constantly surprised. The character-driven narrative ensures that even the supporting cast leaves a lasting impact, adding depth and complexity to the overall storyline.

In my thought, Breaking Bad is a timeless gem that will be remembered as one of the greatest shows in television history. Its exceptional performances, intense drama, and well-crafted storytelling make it a must-watch for all generations. It is a show that will stay with you long after you've finished watching. Personally, I wholeheartedly give it a solid 9 out of 10, reserving that one point as a tribute to its unforgettable impact on the world of television.

Rabid fans: just because you don't agree doesn't mean the review is unhelpful -- that's not what the "No" option is for. For those who can think critically, read on.

I was on the hype train when it was still on the air. I think everyone was amused by the premise and especially getting to see Bryan Cranston take on such a serious role. (Before BB, he wasn't necessarily an obscure actor, but nobody knew him from anything besides "Malcolm in the Middle.")

Looking back, having rewatched the entire series at least four or five times since it ended ten years ago, it comes off as a show designed to trick stupid people into thinking it's smart (I was one of them.) You can find countless pieces of media debunking virtually everything the Walter White character does. My problem with this is the fact that the show deals with actual chemistry and science accessible to all people, and not made-up fantasy science. But the show handles science as if it IS magic.

Some defenders of these errors might claim that it's "just fiction", but I resent that because one of the show's selling points was that it appeared to be very realistic. The people involved with this touted their consultations with real chemists as a testament to its authenticity, so what are we supposed to think? I think this is harmful in the long run because it only makes people more ignorant to how things really work, and the American public is already painfully ignorant to the fundamentals of science and nature itself.

The way BB alternates between realism and comic book style nonsense is very strange, and I suspect this was not intentional. I understand the pressure on writers to come up with suspensful and exciting developments in a story, but I don't think you can have it both ways. Is it realistic or is it a cartoon? I don't think the writers were able to make up their minds. The reason this is so detrimental to the show and its internal logic is because once you know and understand the errors -- nothing that happens can be taken seriously. It's like the character himself says (to paraphrase): in science or math, it's either right or it's wrong.

Take the train heist for instance. The whole premise of it is laughable once you know that the kind of methylamine they would realistically need would be anhydrous, not aqueous. See what I mean? If you're going to do a show about a genius chemist, you might need to take it more seriously. Errors this large would be unthinkable. It seems like the writers attempted a cursory understanding of maybe one aspect of the science, and then rushed into writing a story without thinking it through.

Everything from the manner in which Walter causes an obnoxious guy's car to explode (by laying a squeege on the battery) -- to the way he gases the thugs in the RV -- to the bathtub incident, makeshift RV battery, etc. Is impossible. All the way to the end of the show, everything that happens is impossible. Probably the only accuracy is the production of the meth, but even that is flawed -- because the writers demonstrated a fundamental misunderstanding of methylamine from the beginning to the very end. (You can make it with household chemicals...) Also -- Giancarlo Esposito's Spanish is horrific. He sounds mentally disabled to anyone who speaks the language, so the thought of any of these cartel people taking him seriously is hilarious. Seriously, if it was this bad he should have been written to speak English only. And his character being Chilean makes absolutely no sense whatsoever. Have the showrunners ever seen a Chilean?

Despite this, my biggest problem with the whole affair is in the narrative. These characters are downright awful -- characteristically and in terms of writing. Yes, you are mostly dealing with bad people, but there's no silver lining or any warmth. The story and characterizations make no sense. It feels very contrived and manipulative, as if the writers were so desperate to make you pity this character that they had to construct an implausible scenario consisting of one-dimensional stereotypes, shallow explanations and questionable motivations.

You're telling me this guy is that smart but he couldn't find a better profession than high school education? We're even shown in the first episode that he has a Nobel Prize framed on the wall. The show teases throughout that something went wrong with a research start-up between Walter and his colleauges, but we're never given an explanation, and I suspect the writers didn't know either. It was also a baffling and idiotic creative decision to establish a clear connection between Walter and his high school chemistry lab (for which he was the only one who had the keys) via the gas mask found in the desert -- as early as episode two -- and nobody suspects him despite his background in chemistry? How stupid is this version of reality the story takes place in? I know people like Hank in real life. He would have been suspicious immediately and even if he wasn't -- the DEA would've suspected Walter -- and Hank would have been taken off the case as a potential conflict of interest.

His family is an odd, Hollywood contrivance that is supposed to make us feel bad, but they only serve to irritate. It seems like the writers hold a disgusting view of lower middle-class American families. In the commentaries, they even admit to decorating the set of the White household intentionally tacky and garish, which is really a reflection of how insufferable Skyler is (Walter's wife.) Maybe Skyler wouldn't have been so maligned if you had actually written her as a human being. She irritates before Walter even considers cooking meth. And then there's the son, Walter Jr., who has cerebral palsy, which is an obvious inclusion to make you feel that Walter is justified and was dealt a bad hand. But the problem is that his personality is as strange as Skyler's, almost as if the characters were written by aliens.

If they just HAD to produce a show about a desperate man who turns to manufacturing drugs, they could have written the characters -- and especially the family -- as real people. I would never argue with the notion that American society is sick and the way we live is odd compared to the rest of the world, but there's still good people here, and nobody I've ever interacted with behaves the way this family does. If you wanted to make me feel bad, you would write this wife as a sweet and loving person with depth and convictions of her own.

If they wanted to justify the unjustifiable, maybe raise the stakes. Maybe Walter's son needs an operation and he has three or four more children, which would make sense because he's fifty. Upgrade him to at least a community college or backwater university lecturer. Have him be conflicted about doing this and really explore the psychology of this criminal activity. It doesn't make sense how he just unleashes this monster as soon as he is diagnosed with cancer.

The drama is also very forced and has an edge or frequency that is like having too much coffee or something. People bark things at each other through gritted teeth, Walter's lying is not smart enough for someone of his intelligence and many things are left unsaid for no reason. This show is like misery porn which Americans disturbingly can't get enough of. Even more disturbing is the way people root for Walter. I've even come across discussions online where fans are saying they would engage in this kind of activity under similar circumstances -- if they knew how and could get away with it.

I'll never understand why people are obsessed with darkness. This darkness is not even appealing or convincing anyway. None of the material is nutritious food for the mind, spirit or intellect. When it's over -- what are you left with?

Breaking Bad: Best Features

Gajendra Gautam Tell me the best thing about breaking bad we series

"Breaking Bad" is widely considered one of the best television series of all time, and there are many reasons why this is the case. Here are some of the most highly regarded elements of the show:

Complex characters: The characters in "Breaking Bad" are richly drawn and multi-dimensional, making them both relatable and unpredictable.

Tight storytelling: The writers of "Breaking Bad" did an excellent job of pacing the story and building tension over the course of the series. Each episode leaves the viewer wanting more.

Exploration of morality: The show asks thought-provoking questions about the nature of right and wrong, and the consequences of our actions.

Cinematography: "Breaking Bad" is visually stunning, with cinematography that captures the beauty and harshness of the Southwest landscape.

Acting: The performances, particularly by Bryan Cranston as Walter White, are universally acclaimed.

Attention to detail: The show's creators took great care in creating a believable world, and the little details, such as the costumes, sets, and props, help to bring the story to life.

These are just a few of the many reasons why "Breaking Bad" is such a beloved series, and why it continues to be held in high regard years after its final episode aired.

Breaking Bad is a groundbreaking television series that offers a thrilling and tense look at the consequences of one man's descent into criminality. It is expertly crafted, with powerful performances from its cast, slick cinematography, and a well-written script that consistently surprises and captivates its audience.

The show's appeal lies largely in its ability to create nuanced characters who are both relatable and deeply flawed. Protagonist Walter White, played by the immensely talented Bryan Cranston, is an underachieving high school chemistry teacher who is diagnosed with terminal cancer. Through a series of unfortunate events, he turns to manufacturing methamphetamine to provide for his family's future after his death. What follows is a gripping tale of morality, corruption, and ultimately, redemption.

The series is also notable for its attention to detail. From the music cues to the intricate world-building, every aspect of Breaking Bad has been carefully crafted to create a complete and immersive story. Even minor characters are given fully-fleshed-out backstories and motivations that add depth to the show's narrative.

Overall, Breaking Bad is a must-watch for anyone who loves gripping dramas and complex storytelling. Its legacy will undoubtedly continue to inspire and captivate audiences for years to come.

Breaking Bad is one of the most iconic TV shows of all time, and for good reason. The show, which originally aired from 2008 to 2013, follows the story of Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher who turns to cooking and selling methamphetamine to provide for his family after he is diagnosed with terminal cancer.

The show is a masterclass in storytelling, with each episode building on the last to create a complex and compelling narrative. The characters are all fully realized and multi-dimensional, with even the smallest roles given depth and complexity.

Bryan Cranston's portrayal of Walter White is nothing short of remarkable. He manages to capture the character's transformation from a mild-mannered high school teacher to a ruthless drug kingpin with incredible nuance and subtlety. Aaron Paul is equally impressive as Jesse Pinkman, Walter's former student and partner in crime.

The show is also visually stunning, with expertly crafted cinematography and editing that adds to the tension and drama of each scene. The show's use of color is particularly noteworthy, with each episode's color palette carefully chosen to reflect the mood and themes of the story.

One of the show's greatest strengths is its willingness to explore complex moral questions. Throughout the series, the characters are constantly forced to grapple with their own moral compasses and the consequences of their actions. The show never shies away from the darkness of its subject matter, and the result is a powerful and thought-provoking examination of the human condition.

Overall, Breaking Bad is a must-watch for anyone interested in exceptional television. The show's superb acting, intricate storytelling, and thematic depth make it a true masterpiece.

Breaking Bad is a testament to the power of television as an art form. It pushes boundaries and challenges the conventions of traditional storytelling, leaving a lasting impact on its viewers. It has rightfully earned its place among the greatest television series of all time.

In conclusion, Breaking Bad is an extraordinary television series that deserves every ounce of praise it has received. With its compelling characters, intricate storytelling, and outstanding performances, it stands as a landmark achievement in the world of television. Whether you're a fan of drama, suspense, or simply appreciate superb storytelling, Breaking Bad is an absolute must-watch that will leave you craving more with each episode.

So, i just finished all five seasons over the course of about a month. I really expected more based on the hype. The premise was good, and of course Cranston's acting was great. But the over-the-top stupidity of nearly every action taken by the characters was so distracting as to make the first 4 seasons almost unwatchable. Season five definitely ended with some great closure, tying up all the loose ends, and the final scene was satisfying (which earned it 4 stars instead of 1). But when so many characters, particularly Walter, Skyler, and Jesse, repeatedly make the most moronic decisions and show such an inability to behave in any way rationally, it undermines any affection we might develop for the characters. I found myself saying "That was so stupid, you deserve to die" multiple times in virtually every episode. Even the most bumbling, moronic person could lie better than these idiots! And making Skyler a raging hateful lunatic throughout the series made it impossible to believe that Walter would go through any trouble for her whatsoever. Meh, good riddance to this mediocre show.

I'm not joking, this is one of the best TV series ever created....only bettered by Mr Robot and maybe The Madalorian. The problem with it is (and it is a problem) the scenarios take a lot of setting up, like pushing a boulder up a hill. Sure when they reach the crescendo all hell breaks loose and it's excellent, you just have to sit through an aweful lot of sub plots... It is amazing, totally believable and pure madness/genius. The performances are top rate and the whole setting is a beautiful backdrop. I watched the entire series back to back in a few days, best way to do it as there's a lot to digest. So don't miss out on the excellent series. Like I said, one of the best ever produced. Oh and look out for the Pizza scene...that was a fluke and kept in for effect...you'll know what I mean!

Breaking Bad is a masterpiece in television history. The show's brilliant writing, exceptional performances, and breathtaking cinematography make it one of the best shows ever made.

Bryan Cranston's portrayal of Walter White is nothing short of iconic. He takes us on a journey from a struggling high school chemistry teacher to a ruthless drug kingpin, and every step of the way, we are completely invested in his character. Aaron Paul's portrayal of Jesse Pinkman is equally fantastic, and the chemistry between Cranston and Paul is one of the main reasons the show is so compelling.

The show's supporting cast is also excellent, with standout performances from Giancarlo Esposito as the terrifying Gus Fring, Anna Gunn as Walter's wife Skyler, and Bob Odenkirk as the sleazy lawyer Saul Goodman.

Breaking Bad's storytelling is expertly crafted, with each episode leaving us on the edge of our seats, eagerly anticipating what happens next. The show's use of symbolism and foreshadowing is also masterful, and the attention to detail in every aspect of the production is impressive.

Overall, Breaking Bad is a must-watch for anyone who loves great television. It is a modern classic that will be remembered for years to come.

Breaking Bad is not just a TV series; it's a rollercoaster ride through the moral shadows of a man's soul. This groundbreaking show, created by Vince Gilligan, doesn't just break bad - it shatters conventions and expectations. From its intense character development to its mind-bending plot twists, Breaking Bad is a tour de force in the world of television.

Breaking Bad doesn't shy away from exploring the dark recesses of human nature. It delves into the consequences of choices, the thin line between good and evil, and the moral decay that can consume even the most ordinary individuals. The writing is sharp, the cinematography is striking, and the soundtrack complements the tension perfectly.

Each episode is a cliffhanger, leaving you on the edge of your seat and craving more. It's a high-stakes game of cat and mouse that will keep you guessing until the very end. Breaking Bad isn't just a TV show; it's a masterfully crafted journey into the heart of darkness that will leave you breathless and haunted.

Breaking Bad is a masterpiece that has and will always live up to its hype. The story is extremely well-executed, the characters are complex and relatable, even despite their heinous acts, with a few exceptions ofc (looking at you S4-5 Waltuh), the setting is unique and interesting, and the pacing is top tier. That being said, some episodes are kinda slow or uneventful, but as a whole the series is bound to keep you at the edge of your seat, building suspense and tension that will always make you excited for what will happen next. Additionally, it explores a bigger theme of trauma and masculinity and explores how said themes influence the events and the characters themselves. As unsympathetic as Walter does become towards the end, he is still somewhat understandable due to being an underappreciated and ignored despite his brilliance (tho one could argue that it was at least partially self induced). The same counts for characters like Jesse, Saul, Gus, and Mike, who are forced into the lifestyle due to problems beyond their control. Overall, this is a masterful and influential show, and while I may or may not rewatch it, I will always treasure it and hold it close to my heart.

Breaking Bad is easily my favorite TV show and is objectively the best one out there. I've never been more captivated by a show than this one. It's filled to the brim with excellent writing, directing, cinematography and acting. Props to Vince Gilligan, he really did create something that feels like lightning in a bottle. The acting, man, there is not one bad or mediocre performance in this show, everyone is fantastic, the standout of course being Bryan Cranston as the chemistry teacher turned drug kingpin, Walter White/Heisenberg. Cranston really was the perfect choice to play this role. Aaron Paul as Jesse Pinkman is excellent in this show as well, and there are a few scenes with him in the last season that nearly made me tear up.

The show is undeniably slow, it takes its time with its story and characters to add more depth to them, and it has the potential to be boring, but when the scenes are this well written, this well shot and this well acted, I was never bored. And the characters are extremely well written to keep you invested in the story. But then it also explodes on you with shocking and badass moments that are definitely worth the wait.

The main premise of the show is a chemistry teacher. Diagnosed with lung cancer, who gets into drug dealing to make money to provide for his family before he dies, but it's so much more than that. It's about change, how a person can become entirely different from who they were due to greed. It's about the price a person has to pay in order to do something they want to. It's about a person trying to do something that will help his family, but instead leads to the destruction of it.

Overall, an absolute masterpiece of a show that I think everyone should see at least once in their life. It's one of the few shows that has consistently stayed phenominal from start to finish.

This is quite possibly the best drama series I have ever seen. It is even better than The Sopranos. Every episode is compelling. The characters are phenomenal and the acting is even better. It is also well written.

It will hook you from the very beginning and you won't be able to stop watching with all the twists and turns the story takes. 100% recommend this show to anyone who hasn't seen it.

This is my one and only review so far on IMDB and I just had to say something about Breaking Bad

To start... a perfect cast, that acted perfectly. Bryan Cranston portrayed his character so unbelievably well.. because he was so believable & relatable, emotional, expressive, good/evil. Truly amazing, he should have won all the Emmy's. Same with Aaron Paul. The whole cast complemented each other so well.

The writing is top tier drama and action... to paraphrase 'A chemistry teacher with cancer decides to cook meth to provide for his family."... to turn this brief synopsis nto the show we see today, is remarkable. The details in each episode drove the plot forward and made a fictional story seem realistic and possible. The plot had clear moments of rising action, a climax and a fall that lead to an actual conclusion (unlike other tv shows)... Truly an overall complete story. Hats off to the writers, specifically Vince Gilligan

Lastly, the directing and cinematography is brilliant. It ties the acting in with the writing. The unique camera angles lighting, sounds, lighting and wardrobe (that changed as the plot thickened) added depth, suspense and made the show much more gripping.

Overall... there is no other show that competes with Breaking Bad. Thank you for making this for my enjoyment!

Breaking Bad, a television series that defies conventions and leaves an indelible mark on the landscape of modern storytelling, stands tall as a groundbreaking achievement in the realm of television drama. With its unparalleled depth, emotional intensity, and meticulous craftsmanship, Breaking Bad captivates audiences, searing its narrative into their hearts and minds, making it an unparalleled masterpiece that continues to resonate long after the final episode fades to black.

At the core of Breaking Bad lies an extraordinary narrative that delves deep into the human psyche, exploring the transformation of Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher turned methamphetamine manufacturer. It is this journey of a desperate man facing adversity and succumbing to darkness that renders Breaking Bad a truly exceptional series. The character development is nothing short of extraordinary, with Bryan Cranston's portrayal of Walter White reaching the heights of virtuosity, providing viewers with an intense, multi-faceted performance that is utterly mesmerizing.

The brilliance of Breaking Bad lies not only in its storytelling but also in its immaculate attention to detail. Every frame is a meticulously composed work of art, showcasing the show's commitment to visual storytelling. The cinematography expertly captures the desolate landscapes of Albuquerque, New Mexico, emphasizing the stark contrast between the characters' internal struggles and the harsh reality they inhabit. The use of color, lighting, and symbolism further enhances the emotional impact, heightening the tension and immersing viewers in a world fraught with moral ambiguity.

One cannot discuss Breaking Bad without acknowledging its exceptional ensemble cast. Aaron Paul's portrayal of Jesse Pinkman, Walter White's former student turned partner in crime, is a revelation, delivering a heart-wrenching performance that tugs at the audience's heartstrings. The chemistry between Cranston and Paul is unparalleled, drawing viewers into their complex and often tumultuous relationship. The supporting cast, including Anna Gunn, Dean Norris, and Giancarlo Esposito, each bring a unique and compelling dynamic to the series, elevating the storytelling to new heights.

What sets Breaking Bad apart is its relentless ability to challenge and subvert expectations. With each passing season, the stakes are raised, and the consequences of Walter White's choices become more dire. The writing is a masterclass in tension and suspense, expertly balancing moments of heart-stopping action with contemplative introspection. The series consistently surprises, making bold narrative choices that leave viewers in awe and ruminating long after the credits roll.

Beyond its narrative brilliance, Breaking Bad is a thought-provoking exploration of morality, identity, and the human condition. It holds a mirror to society, reflecting the consequences of greed, ambition, and the pursuit of power. It poses profound questions about the choices we make, the lines we cross, and the ramifications of our actions. Breaking Bad is a cautionary tale, a Shakespearean tragedy, and a paragon of storytelling excellence all rolled into one.

In conclusion, Breaking Bad stands as an unparalleled masterpiece, an epitome of storytelling that will be remembered for generations to come. Its emotionally charged narrative, meticulous craftsmanship, and exceptional performances make it a shining example of the heights that television drama can reach. Breaking Bad is an experience that immerses viewers in a world where the line between good and evil is blurred, where the consequences of one's choices reverberate with unrelenting force. It is a series that leaves an indelible mark, forever changing the landscape of television and capturing the hearts of audiences worldwide.

Breaking Bad is a masterpiece that will forever hold a special place in the annals of television history.

The show's central character, Walter White, portrayed flawlessly by Bryan Cranston, undergoes a mesmerizing transformation from a meek, high school chemistry teacher to a feared and respected methamphetamine manufacturer. Cranston's performance is nothing short of astonishing, effortlessly capturing the multifaceted nature of Walter's psyche. His nuanced portrayal balances vulnerability, determination, and an increasingly dark and morally ambiguous path, leaving viewers both mesmerized and haunted by his descent into the depths of his own creation.

The writing on Breaking Bad is a masterclass in suspense and tension-building. The intricate plotlines, expertly crafted by showrunner Vince Gilligan and his team, keep you on the edge of your seat, constantly questioning the characters' choices and motives. Each episode is meticulously constructed, weaving together moments of nail-biting intensity, shocking revelations, and profound character interactions.

Breaking Bad not only delves into the gritty world of drug trafficking and the consequences it wreaks upon society, but it also explores the profound effects on relationships and the human psyche. The complex dynamics between Walter and his former student-turned-partner, Jesse Pinkman ( by Aaron Paul), provide the series with emotional depth and an exploration of the consequences of one's actions. Their chemistry on screen is unparalleled, delivering some of the most powerful and heartbreaking moments in television history.

The attention to detail in Breaking Bad is astonishing. From the breathtaking cinematography to the meticulously chosen soundtrack, every aspect of the show contributes to its overall impact. The visual aesthetics, symbolic motifs, and clever use of color effectively enhance the storytelling and evoke a range of emotions, creating an immersive experience for the audience.

In conclusion, Breaking Bad is a true television gem that sets the bar exceptionally high. With its outstanding performances, intricate writing, and powerful exploration of the human condition, it remains an enduring testament to the power of storytelling. It is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates exceptional television and is ready to embark on an unforgettable journey into the dark side of brilliance.

It's an old serie but I actually just managed to watch it! And so glad I did since it's bad ass, ground breaking and entertaining ass hell. Walter is such a strong main character and it's truly entertaining to see the character grow. Acting is truly skilled and there is dry comedy springled a cross the episodes. There some episodes where you feel like they are repeating stuff for sole purpose of coming up story, but it's a very small flaw in the glass.

All of the characters in BREAKING BAD are flawed (many very deeply), and they all make mistakes and, sometimes, baffling choices. The line between good and bad isn't clear; in fact, nobody comes off looking particularly good here, including Walt's DEA agent brother-in-law, Hank (Dean Norris), who's brusque and often insensitive. Some episodes move a bit slowly, while others have more momentum -- sort of like Walt himself, as he tries to cope with the mess his life is becoming.

Cranston's phenomenal performance is the best thing about the show. Forget the spacey, clueless dad of Malcolm in the Middle. Walt may be tired and beaten down, but Cranston manages to bring enough dignity to the man that it's possible to believe him when he's acting like an idiot and being socially responsible at the same time (such as when he narrowly escapes the bad guys, then tells his drug dealing partner, "We have to clean this up")

Breaking Bad is genuinely the best... piece of media that I have consumed ever. You grow with all the characters, it's funny, you hate Jesse the first season or two, he's annoying, full of himself, rude etc. You're more rooting for Walter, he has cancer, he's doing what's right for his almost family of 4, but, on the final episode, that's changed. Jesse is the only one you cheer, the only one who's outcome makes you happy. But Walter, you're glad his fate is what it is, you hate him, he's evil and immoral, very far off from the beginning of the show where he was terrified with the fact of taking a life. It get's to a cutoff where the show barely revolves around the production of meth, it's more the people who make them and who they associate with.

I say this final part confidently, if you are to watch this show, LOOK UP NOTHING ABOUT IT, your enjoyment will increase tenfold if you do, I am not kidding, research nothing.

This is considered as one of the greatest television shows of history. Critics and fans alike love this show.

Me personally was blown away by it.

It is created by one of the "X-Files" creators, so there is no surprise.

But this is one of the most uniquely dark television drama on a man's journey to perdition and we see it's inception.

We see madness, internal struggle, violence and drugs.

This reminds of Tarantino, Rodriguez, Ritchie and Joe Carnahan. A dark comic take on violence.

Bryan Cranston as Walter White is amazing. One of the best television experiences so far.

Overall - 4/5

Heisenberg is the greatest character in TV history. I loved Tony Soprano but Walter White took the top spot from him. The character development is excellent. There are so many layers, it can be difficult to decide whether you're rooting for or against him. I personally never stopped rooting for him. Don't let the "slowness" of the first season turn you away. They take their time in building the character and it's worth it.

Cranston's portrayal is genius. Even among some great writing, incredibly interesting characters, and an intense multi-layered storyline, Cranston's acting is what most commonly stood out to me the most. Several times I just shook my head and stated out loud what a talented actor he is.

Giancarlo Esposito (Gus), Jonathan Banks (Mike), Aaron Paul (Jesse), Bob Odenkirk (Saul), Raymond Cruz (Tuco), Dean Joseph Norris (Hank) are all excellent in their roles and Mark Margolis as Hector Salamanca is one of the most underrated / under appreciated acting jobs I've ever seen.

The relationship and banter between Heisenberg and Aaron Paul's character really carry the show throughout and is never not entertaining. This dialogue alone makes the show worth watching.

The reason I give this show a 10 when others of superb quality got less is because there is an ending. A real one where loose ends are tied up. There's nothing worse than investing in a series just to be left sitting there looking like a fool after some open ended finale. You don't have to worry about that here.

Breaking Bad is, without a doubt, one of the greatest television series of all time. From its captivating plot and complex characters to its exceptional production and execution, this AMC series has everything it takes to be a masterpiece of television.

The protagonist, Walter White, is masterfully played by Bryan Cranston, who brings to life a character that undergoes a dramatic transformation over the course of the series. As White immerses himself in the world of methamphetamine trafficking to earn money for his family, his life and character change dramatically, and Cranston handles this transformation convincingly and thrillingly.

The supporting cast is also solid, with standout performances from Aaron Paul as Jesse Pinkman, White's partner in the meth business, and Anna Gunn as Skyler White, Walter's wife. The supporting characters are also interesting and well-developed, adding depth and complexity to the overall plot.

The production of the series is also top-notch, with stunning set designs and photography, as well as an impeccably selected soundtrack. Each episode is a visual and technical masterpiece in its own right.

Overall, Breaking Bad is a series not to be missed. Each episode is thrilling and full of unexpected twists and turns. It is an epic story about ambition, loyalty and betrayal, and is undoubtedly one of the best television series ever produced.

From the moment I started watching Breaking Bad, I knew I was in for something special. This groundbreaking TV series captivated me from the very first episode, taking me on an emotional rollercoaster ride through the dark and twisted world of Walter White and his transformation from a mild-mannered high school chemistry teacher to a ruthless drug kingpin.

As a viewer, I was consistently amazed by the depth and complexity of the characters, as well as the phenomenal performances of the entire cast. Cranston's portrayal of Walter White is nothing short of extraordinary, and Aaron Paul's portrayal of Jesse Pinkman, his troubled former student and reluctant partner in crime, is equally as impressive. The chemistry between the two actors is undeniable and provides the backbone of the show's emotional core.

Throughout my time with Breaking Bad, I found myself constantly on the edge of my seat, gripped by the series' masterful storytelling and expertly crafted suspense. The intricate plotlines and unexpected twists and turns kept me guessing and fully engaged from one episode to the next. Moreover, the stunning cinematography and memorable soundtrack served to further immerse me in the show's intense atmosphere.

One of the most striking aspects of Breaking Bad is its ability to delve deep into the human psyche, exploring themes of morality, ambition, and the consequences of our choices. I found myself questioning my own moral compass as I sympathized with, and even rooted for, characters who engaged in morally reprehensible actions. This thought-provoking aspect of the series is a testament to its powerful storytelling and the skill of its creators.

Breaking Bad is a masterpiece! Recommend it? Absolutely! Imagine a mild-mannered chemistry teacher, Walter White, turned methamphetamine kingpin. Bryan Cranston's performance is mind-blowing, and Aaron Paul as Jesse Pinkman is simply top-notch. The plot twists are jaw-dropping, leaving you on the edge of your seat. The character dynamics are intense, and the cinematography is a visual feast. It's an emotional rollercoaster, from nail-biting tension to heart-wrenching moments. If you haven't watched it yet, brace yourself for a wild marathon. The show's impact is undeniable, and you'll find yourself hooked from the first episode. Trust me, you won't regret it, buddy!
