Growth. Decay. Transformation. This is the foundation on which the show built it's own empire. The tale of an ordinary man and his death sentence. From the beginning, it is clear that the protagonist you're watching won't have a happy ending. Viewers were just not sure how severe on the spectrum that judgment would fall. However, as much as the show is praised for it's unique story telling, characters, and acting, the real prize for fans is in the details. Breaking Bad's success is fueled by its re-watch-ability as viewers will continue to find countless connections and theories. Although most of these are a product of over analyzing, there is still enough to make you question legitimately whether these clues were on purpose. I give it a perfect score. There are hundreds of reviews that do the same. You have to agree with the rest of us, it just feels so good to be bad.
Best series Especially the fourth and fifth season

There are just two series so worth watching: this, and the Wire. The main characters are totally anti-heros and almost pitiful, there is a lot of violence, and some scene are Tarantino-worthy. It's a slow excruciating and torturing crescendo until the last final episode that just keep you glued to the screen. It makes you wanna scream, cry, swear. And if you have the chance to watch it all over again....You'll do it. Brilliant.

The best story builds up and characters making that I ever seen. Firstly, I didn't like it too much. I liked it. But not much. But from the fourth season, I was getting interested in it. I really like the way that Vince Gilligan build up the characters as well as the story. It's really seamless. You can't think what's gonna happen next. I really liked it.

And the next main thing is I don't count Walter White as a villain. He is sort of a Hero as my point of view. He is a coward, selfish & A- hole as well. But he is one of my heroes.

Jesse Pinkman is my favorite character along all of them. Because he is the most innocent guy in the entire show. He is trying to keep peace every time. But I really like the dialogs of Saul Goodman. The every single word of this show is from Vince Gilligan's mind. That was remarkable.

The second main thing is the editing style of it. As a video editor, I learned so many things from this. I've watched some scenes again and again. Still, I can watch them.

America is a great country and a Worst country. And my dream country. America is suffering from this kind of diseases. And America helps for those who raised their hands for against them in every possible way.

I'll tell you now, if you start with episode one, you won't be able to stop, it will just sink your whole day away. Absolutely amazing show, great acting and superb story. Prepare for a fantastic ride! I started watching the show when season 5 began. And within the start of season 5 episode one, I was caught up and watching episode five on TV. I was hooked from start to finish. The acting all the way through the show was great. Right up to the very end of the show I guarantee you will be craving more and more and never want it to end, but sadly, every show has to end at some point and instead of drawing it out and possibly making the story become boring and dull they finished it with an absolute perfect finale. Thank you so much Breaking Bad for giving me some great memories due to watching your show.

If you have not seen it, do yourself a HUGE favor and rent the first season so you'll know what's going on, and you can see the transition of the characters. This show is beautifully written with plot twists coming in refreshing ways, and at just the right times. Some of what is shown I was surprised they put it on television,... and that's a great thing !! The acting is brilliant, and the themes are amazing, timeless and timely, and are presented to us in thought provoking ways that leave me pondering philosophical ideas long after the show is over. Yeah, this is a TV series !!! On AMC !! Hard to believe. This is one I'm raving about to everyone I know, and hope keeps going for a long, long time !!! okay, so recently i was recommended a show. it was called dexter. i got so hooked on it that watched the first 5 seasons in 5 days. 12 hour a day sessions. i was like seriously hooked on it. once that finished i decided it was the best show i had ever seen... the same man who recommended that show then said "watch this"... and gave me seasons 1-4 of breaking bad. "its the dad from malcolm in the middle being a bad ass...". i was sceptical to say the least. i stuck it on and watched the first 3 eps. it was OK, but seemed a little disjointed. but i persisted and am so pleased i did. because after that it just took off. had me totally hooked. cranstan is just brilliant as the chemic genius walter white. but he is backed up by the even better arron paul as the street wise yet quite stupid jesse pinkman. the chemistry (excuse the pun) between the two is incredible and you get engrossed in the relationship that develops between the two as much as you do with the story itself. brilliantly written. beautifully acted. and dare i say... better than dexter... pfffffft..... its a bold statement but i think it may be you know... :)

I first came across this show when I first got Netflix about 5 years ago because I was only 12 when it was actually being broadcasted on television and plus it wasn't really on British television, but I'm grateful every time I go back and start watching it all over again because it's just one of those things: you HAVE TO watch it! With Bryan Cranston being a comedy actor you wouldn't expect it to work with its dark, deep seated dramatic nature but it does! He IS Heisenberg!! Then there's Jesse who is probably the character I relate to most, the young mistreated, misguided tortured soul who has no one to care about him and as a result he always seeks solitude and connection with the wrong people or actions. I believe every character is relatable in at least some way. The pacing of the show is also absolutely spot on. Walters secret becomes known to Skylar in perfect timing but we didn't expect it because HE didn't tell her! She told HIM she knew and that came as such a shock because I thought she thought he was having an affair. It's just so well written and put together, I would give anything to have Walter White survive the finale so we could have another series like how prison break did because it just feels like it could have so much more avenues to explore.

Though I don't think we will, I'll just have to keep rewatching it over and over again, I started again about a week ago and I think this is the 10th or 11th time I have done so ( I know I'm either obsessed or addicted right? )

That's just it though! It is so well written and acted that it's as addictive as the drug it's based on. You just can't turn your back on the characters you fell in love with from the first time.

Trust me if you haven't watched this yet and you're dwindling around STOP kidding yourself and jump on the BB bandwagon because unlike most pathetic people who think they're part of something special just because they watch that stupid RU Paul's drag race rubbish or whatever that's just about people with major mental health problems who need professional therapy and help, THIS is actually a part of popular culture that you SHOULD be a part of!

Not for the squeamish. However it serves as a good deterrent for getting involved in the drug world, not just meth.
In my opinion if you have patience for first two seasons then you're going to be more than satisfied with what it has to offer next.

It doesn't happen very often that I'm not sad when a TV show ends: I'm not sad just because Breaking Bad could not have been done better. There are 5 season, and each one is good. They succeeded in keeping an high level for the whole TV show duration. It is never expect, never trivial. There are no good or evil men, no black or white, but everything is gray, every character is perfectly built. Bryan Cranston...what could I say? I think him to be one of the most talented actors in the world. You don't know if to love or to hate him. The most part of today TV shows are full of nudity, violence etc., but Breaking Bad had a great success also without these elements: there should be a reason, don't you think? If you want to find out what it is, just watch it, you will not regret this! Enjoy it!

I usually don't write reviews, but I felt i HAD to for this epic series. For the past 3 years my brother has been bugging me to watch Breaking Bad, and finally I got around to it after moving to a Greek island, thus having more free time on my hands. All I can say is WOW. I can't believe what I missed the past 5 years! After watching the full 5 series in less than 2 weeks, I was left speechless after most episodes, and wanted more, sometimes taking me into the night until 2-3 am. Every episode is brilliantly written, directed, & produced. What can I say about the acting? Every single actor in this series deserves the highest awards. This show will go down as one of the all time greatest (if not THE BEST). HEISENBERG forever!

I am not exaggerating, this show will go down as one of the best shows ever. Try to point out a flaw? It has the best writing I have ever seen. It has amazing and interesting characters who you get connected to. I am very sad that there will never be another episode of this series. It is a gem. A show like this comes around only once in a lifetime. Don't miss out on this opportunity, watch this show! A show about meth? How do you like that? I wondered the same thing before I began to watch it. After a few episodes you will realize that it is much, more than that. Experience the "growth, decay, and transformation," of Walter White AKA Heisenberg. Witness the great tale about the family man chemistry teacher who broke bad!

Breaking Bad is my favorite show, and in my opinion, one of the best TV shows ever. This show has been made from the ground up to create something so amazing, that it's going to get a prequel some time this year to keep things going. Basically, it's like nothing is going to stop the train (you'll get that reference later).

The character development in this show is mind-blowing. It can make a completely sane person in the show go into a deep state of depression, or someone who is a horrible person who has done horrible things. Yes, that's an important factor in any show, but in this show, you get to compare these characters from the beginning of the series to the final season and not recognize them. Not only physically, but in their emotional state, as well. The story plays a much more important factor in that, as well. So many plot twists, and so much creativity that you just wish other shows were just like this one. After you're done watching this, you'll be left wanting more. It's basically like drugs.

Overall, this show is what other shows strive to become. It excels in everything; the story, the characters, the depth, EVERYTHING. With this, I can proudly say that this is the best show AMC has ever had. Yes, it beats The Walking Dead, and yes it beats Mad Men.

At first I kept delaying this series because it had lot of episodes,but after I completed the whole series. I couldn't compare any other series with this,they were of no match the brilliant acting by Bryan Cranston and Arron Paul . After finishing the series I couldn't watch any other series for some time and just kept watching Breaking bad for second time then watched 'better call saul' prequel of Breaking bad.But this series is just irreplaceable and no other series is been neither a match nor close to Breaking bad.Breaking bad always stays on top of my list of best web series I have watched. No offence to any other series fans I just reviwed on my opinion I liked breaking bad more than any other series.

For at least a year I had people coming up to me and trying to talk about Breaking Bad. I said yeah yeah, sounds great but it's not a pay channel - therefore there's no nudity, gore and F bombs. Not for me. Boy, was I wrong.

This show is so good you don't mind the slight censorship. There's enough swearing, chicks and blood to satisfy you. We all know that Bryan Cranston knocked his role out of the park, but he's not the only one. I loved his brother in law and Aaron Paul was really, really good. Jonathan Banks was super as well.

This is the only show where I can say that I got a big kick out of every single episode. It's like the writers know what you want to see and they bring it every time. Not too much, not too little, just the perfect pacing for a story. I was sorry to see it end.

This is my first review, however I thought I had to mention what a great show this really is! The first season is great, the second, in my opinion, is probably even better, and the third season is a little slower but some of the episodes are especially well written and acted. The way the characters develop throughout the show is nothing short of a masterpiece. The acting is top drawer. I never really rated Bryan Cranston before I saw him in this show. However I obviously overlooked what an amazing actor he really is. Aaron Paul as well plays the role brilliantly and provides a stunningly powerful performance, especially in season 2. To anyone reading this who is hoping to stumble across a GREAT show and hasn't decided whether they should give this show a go, all I have to say is please do, you will not regret it. Unfortunately this show has been slow to come onto UK TV, but this is probably THE best American TV show I have watched. Its better than any film because the characters are truly given time needed to develop.

Why you ask? Because it had me hooked from the start. I just finished watching it over for the second time. And still, knowing what was going to happen, I could not wait for the next episode.

Sure it's not for everyone.. If you'd rather have an action packed show filled with gun fights and tits in your face, this isn't for you. But when you do have the patience and understand what's going on.. This show will not disappoint you.

Characters are very well acted out by the very good actors. You really feel for them. Whether they do good or wrong. They had me hating some people on the show with so much passion.. My point, you can really get in to it. Relate with them.

If you haven't seen the show yet, I'm jealous because you're in for one hell of a ride. Definitely a must see show!
If you didn't watched it till now. You are missing something.

I can easily say that, Breaking Bad is one of the best TV series I have ever seen. Set in Albuquerque, the series follows the life of a high school chemistry teacher, Walter White (brilliantly played by Bryan Cranston), who was diagnosed with terminal cancer at the beginning of the first series.

Breaking Bad tracked Walt's transformation from a decent, excellent high school teacher to criminal mastermind and the transition of his character. The mild-mannered high school chemistry teacher Mr. White comes to that point where he thinks that life can't get any worse. Learning that he has terminal cancer, and realising that his illness probably will ruin his family financially, Walt becomes desperate to secure his family's future before he dies, turning to a life of crime, making/cooking and selling methamphetamine, as a result, he ruined his own family and the lives of several others in the process. However, in the tensioned final half hour, somehow he won back a measure of both sympathy and respect - not least by surrendering the pretence that he's done it all for his family. At last Walt told Skyler: "I did it for me," "I liked it. I was good at it." "I was ALIVE!"

One way or another, Heisenberg ticked off every item on his unfinished business list, while the scenes slipped by at their customary stately pace, wasting his enemies, settling a score with his old rivals, freed his prot√©g√©, apologised to his wife and ensuring that his children would - someday - get the drug money he believes they deserve.

The series delivered everything that has been great about Breaking Bad: tension, emotion, pathos, brutality, humour, jaw-dropping shocks ‚Äì and last, but not least: resolution.

Jesse Pinkman's character, intensely played by Aaron Paul, giving a memorable performance in the show and building a natural chemistry with the lead character, Mr. White ‚Äì and exceptional play of an Exceptional actor: Bryan Cranston.

Beautifully written by Vince Gilligan, carefully directed by a great team, with plot twists coming in refreshing ways, brilliant acting, absolutely great cast ‚Äì couldn't get any better.

Breaking Bad might not be perfect, but is definitely a great piece of art.

I was pressured for a very long time to see this show. I kept hearing how amazing it is. Basically, the pinnacle of television. I put it off for a long time to make sure I have enough spare time to appreciate it, and also I've been a bit bored lately, so I finally decided to give it a shot. I went in it completely blind as I somehow have managed to avoid seeing any spoilers for it since it has come out.

So let's start with the positives:

The acting and dialogue are amazing! 10/10. The scenes feel very naturally flowing and I can feel myself being pulled into them as if I'm in the same room. The interactions between the character are organic, the issues they are facing feel familiar and down to earth, making it very easy to empathize with them. Bryan Cranston in particular is amazing at portraying all the feelings and struggles of Walter White.






Now onto the not-so-good parts:





It pains me to say this, it really does, but it seems "Breaking Bad" is a victim of the emperor has no clothes phenomenon. Don't get me wrong, it is a decent show with some really strong points, but it's being pulled down by a lot of issues people seemingly don't want to talk about. So much so that I got tired of waiting it to become good and eventually dropped it halfway through Season 2 and only remembered to write this review 2 weeks after the fact.
I just finished this show and I really wish I could delete it from my brain and watch it again because it's one of the best shows that I've ever watched in my entire life if not THE BEST.

I sincerely believe that everyone here has lived through one of the greatest shows in the history of TV. I highly doubt another series will surpass Breaking Bad - the calibre of the show was just unbelievable. The acting; breathtaking. The plot; riveting...heartbreaking. The writers; genius. The soundtrack; compelling. The character development; unparallelled. Everything about this show was unforgettable, and there's a huge breaking bad shaped void in my life that I will never be able to fill.

Thank you to everyone involved in the making of Breaking Bad, because it was, quite simply, perfect.

Breaking Bad has always been my favorite TV series but I never felt like writing a review about it or something, since many many people already said before me just what I wanted to say: it's without a doubt, the best TV series ever. That's something only a person who has followed plenty of TV shows in his own life could say, and I am that kind of person. I've seen The Sopranos, Dexter, The Walking Dead, Game Of Thrones, Twin Peaks and many other arguably defined "best TV shows ever", and Breaking Bad is definitely the best among them. The only one that's only SLIGHTLY inferior is HBO's best, Six Feet Under. Sure, I still have to try out shows like Mad Men and The Wire, but I doubt they could even go close to this AMC masterpiece. Breaking Bad is a perfect mix, since it has comedy, tragedy, action, horror and cop stuff, and no movie or show has ever integrated so many different genres in such a perfect way. Everything about it is excellent: the soundtrack, the directing, the montage, the metaphors, the little details, the acting, the writing, the twists... I never could describe it with words without missing important features it has, because it's a complete show, maybe the only one ever. 10/10

The first episode of Breaking Bad will make you wonder is it really the highest rated TV show but as the story progresses in its own turtle pace, you'll realise why it is so popular even though the final season aired years ago.

It brings you a master piece that takes several Youtube videos to realise how great the show really is. The casting, the foreshadowing and especially the character development is mind blowing. The show has the 2 best character developments ever seen on TV (in my opinion) in Walter White and Jessie Pinkman.

The show revolves around a theme US never gets bored of : drugs. As you see a simpleton High School teacher progress to become a Drug Empire's core you begin to like the protagonist as he taps into the darkness present in everyone (classic entertainment industry move) and then just like you'd expect, he gets too dark. Meanwhile you feel sympathetic for his sidekick, curse his wife and wonder was his son just physically handicapped.

The show unfolds it plots quite slowly. However at the end of every episode it leaves you a trail of serotonin forcing you to sit on your couch for yet another episode shot with yellow filters because apparently it's Mexico.

The actors have done their part really well as you end up not just judging their stupid and weird behaviour but also feel their pain. (Yes you feel a lot of their pain). The tragedies that takes place in every character's life is complimentary to the theme of the show. The dialogues carry their weights and the color gradient is immaculate. It doesn't come up with a musical score that you'd call absolutely gorgeous, but you'll stick around for an entire episode with no story progression or character development because it's worth it.

Breaking Bad is one of the best shows ever made. It is justified. It is beautiful. It is a masterpiece. It is SATISFYING, it is worth your time!

ps: El Camino: a Breaking Bad movie is the icing on the cake.

In my entire life, I've never seen a TV show that good. I've seen many TV shows and can count how many of them came close to be as good as Breaking Bad. Everything about Breaking Bad, the acting, directing, writing it's all top notch. The tone of the show was kept consistent throughout it's five seasons.

If you watch the first season now, you'll probably be shocked by how much the story and characters evolved through it's runtime. Walter and Jesse, became such nuanced characters throughout the seasons. Bryan Cranston gave me one of the most believable performances I've ever seen, as well as Aaron Paul. I keep telling my friends, you guys gotta watch Breaking Bad it will change the way you see TV shows. And they don't believe me. I don't blame them, cause at first I never pictured that Breaking Bad could be as good as it is.

This show is different in every sense, it's very special. Two of my favorite episodes ever, Ozymandias and Felina are bars that I have set for TV episodes. I still look for episodes as good as these. The Laws of Gods and Men, from Game of Thrones, Hero, from Attack on Titan, Who Goes There and Form and Void, both from True Detective. These are a few examples of episodes that came close to the greatness of those two.

This show is special, and I honestly recommend this to ANYONE. If you despise TV shows, don't think they are as good as Cinema or Anime, whatever. Breaking Bad will most likely change your mind. Watch this, it's not only entertainment, it's art.

PS: I also recommend Better Call Saul if you fall in love with this universe.
I can't imagine a better series than this. Big respect to Bryan Cranston and Aaron Paul

Breaking Bad

This was my choice for a quarantine box set as I missed it at the time.

Much was brilliant, a gathering storm up to the end of series 4, it then perhaps seems the case it was a victim of its own success. Series 5 became baggy and unfocused and really was quite unrecognisable from what had gone before.

Walter had clear motivations behind his actions, following the death of Fring everything just fell into an abyss of contrivances.

The cast universally were quite brilliantly played. I would say that Aaron Paul was the right man at the right place in the right part and perhaps of the entire cast the weakest actor, but still gave a mesmeric performance.

If I was to put my finger on the key brilliance of this show I would say it lays in the meticulous planning and nuance of the script, and really striking new ground in the breadth and scope of TV drama.

Overall I loved it

Category; Timeless Masterpiece; Adventure beckons, become drawn into the life of Walter White. His evolution into the Heisenberg persona from schoolteacher to Meth cook.

How his character evolves in the choices he makes, and how countless others become swept into his chaotic wake. The double life, the betrayal of his own family and the battle for his and his family's survival in the complicated world of drug running, pits each of these into a spiraling vortex that keeps you on edge from beginning to end. It's 10 out of 10 on every count. The script is imaginative and compelling, it's believable and astounding. The acting is unsurpassed and therefore able to form a connection with the viewer. I synced with this series for good after the third episode series 1 , from that moment I was on the roller coaster!!!

Just finished binge watching the 5-series over 5-days of the acclaimed TV series. I was less interested in it when it was on originally, due to the fact that it was another drug related serial and others that followed in its wake, i.e. Ozarks. But, having to quarantine for last two weeks allowed opportunity to see it all together. Yes it is masterfully made, with exceptional acting & sensational story plots, right down to its climax. So, I have nothing against the programme itself, but I reflect upon the idea that it's based upon, of drug cartels, manufacturing, distributing, with help & protection from highest echelons of power, all geared towards targeting the most vulnerable in the society. All of it for ego, entitlement & greed that is never satisfied, regardless of how many lives are destroyed in sacrifice to make few people rich, that are morally corrupt without any care for humanity. The serial is exceptional in its depiction of the journey of one man, but what could have been highlighted in more detail is the impact it has upon the underbelly of the world that starves & scrapes for drugs instead of buying food or to be healthy. Sensationalism of drugs is the last thing that we need in a country like USA where the Federally legalised drug manufacturers already rip-off the patients with overpriced medication; not to mention the opioid epidemic that they have created for their greed to be drug kingpins of the world. Alarmingly the corporations are in bed with the congress, the senate, the politicians that are elected to serve & protect their constituents, and they all have made a never ending web of exchanging money for power & power for money at the cost of millions in USA & around the world that suffer due to such deplorable deeds of people in public offices. If anything there should be more light shed on such scenarios instead of making programmes about glorifying drugs in any manner. All said & done, it's an exception programme & glad to have experienced it with gratitude.

If you are a bit like me you might think that a TV series on drugs can't be very interesting. However I've been proved wrong. This show is the most intense, profound and brilliant show I have ever seen.

Describing this show is not easy though. What makes it this special? To me it is the psychological depth of the characters, the progression of life stories and the small and large scale snowball effects in response to choices being made.

I'm not a professional in filming techniques, but even I can see that Breaking Bad is also unique in camera work. Unusual angles are used to shoot a different than usual series and little imperfections are cherished instead of polished away. This series shows wrinkles, body hair and moles. Just as it shows people making little normal daily mistakes, that don't add to the story but make it look so much more natural.

To conclude I'd say if this TV series was a book it would be literature, so it is definitely a must watch!

"Breaking Bad" is a gripping, intense, and flawlessly executed drama series that undeniably revolutionized television storytelling. Created by Vince Gilligan, it aired from 2008 to 2013, spanning five seasons that showcased an unparalleled journey into the depths of human morality, choices, and consequences.

The series centers around Walter White (played phenomenally by Bryan Cranston), a high school chemistry teacher diagnosed with terminal lung cancer. Faced with the reality of leaving his family in financial ruin, Walter turns to manufacturing and selling methamphetamine to secure their future. He partners with former student and small-time meth manufacturer Jesse Pinkman (portrayed brilliantly by Aaron Paul), setting off a chain of events that unravels the complexities of their characters and the morally grey world they inhabit.

One of the show's standout strengths lies in its character development. Walter White's transformation from a mild-mannered teacher to a calculated drug kingpin is enthralling yet haunting. Cranston's portrayal is nuanced, portraying Walter's descent into darkness with a depth that's both chilling and empathetic. Aaron Paul's Jesse Pinkman is equally compelling, evolving from a troubled addict to a character burdened by guilt and seeking redemption.

The writing of "Breaking Bad" is nothing short of exceptional. Each episode is meticulously crafted, delving deep into moral dilemmas, ethical boundaries, and the repercussions of one's choices. The tension is palpable throughout, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats as the characters navigate a world fraught with danger and moral ambiguity.

Visually, the show is a work of art. The cinematography, use of color symbolism, and meticulous attention to detail elevate the storytelling. From the vast New Mexico landscapes to the cramped, tense interiors, every scene is crafted to evoke emotion and immerse the audience in the characters' world.

What sets "Breaking Bad" apart is its ability to explore complex themes without compromising on entertainment value. It doesn't shy away from the harsh realities of the drug trade, human nature, and the price of ambition. It challenges viewers to confront uncomfortable truths about the choices people make when faced with dire circumstances.

The supporting cast is exceptional, adding depth and richness to the narrative. Characters like Saul Goodman (Bob Odenkirk), Hank Schrader (Dean Norris), and Gustavo Fring (Giancarlo Esposito) contribute to the show's brilliance, each with their distinct motivations and impact on the story.

The final season serves as a masterclass in storytelling, with a culmination that is both satisfying and thought-provoking. The series finale delivers closure while leaving enough room for interpretation, ensuring that "Breaking Bad" remains a topic of discussion and analysis long after its conclusion.

"Breaking Bad" is undeniably one of the most outstanding television series of all time and a personal favorite of many viewers, including myself. With its meticulously crafted storyline, brilliant performances, and unparalleled character development, the series stands as an absolute masterpiece.

The plot of "Breaking Bad" is captivating and gripping from start to finish. The journey of chemistry teacher Walter White's transformation into a methamphetamine cook and drug lord immediately hooks the audience. The suspense and unpredictable twists keep viewers on the edge of their seats, eagerly awaiting each episode.

The acting performances are phenomenal. Bryan Cranston shines in his role as Walter White, delivering a performance for the ages. His portrayal of the character's evolution from an unassuming family man to a ruthless criminal is both impressive and nuanced. Aaron Paul also excels as Jesse Pinkman, adding an extra layer of emotional depth to the series.

The character development in "Breaking Bad" is exceptional. Each character is carefully and thoughtfully crafted, allowing viewers to understand their motivations and conflicts. The moral ambiguity of the characters and the exploration of the concepts of good and evil make the series even more compelling, leaving room for intense discussions and reflection.

The visual design and directing are also remarkable. The series' dark and gritty aesthetics mirror the depths of its characters and story. The cinematography and shot composition are cohesive and enhance the emotional impact of the scenes.

"Breaking Bad" is a series that leaves a lasting impression. It tackles themes of power, morality, and human nature in a thought-provoking manner. With its gripping storyline, outstanding performances, and excellent character development, the series unquestionably deserves a rating of 10/10. "Breaking Bad" is a timeless masterpiece that continues to be regarded as a pinnacle of television even years after its initial airing.

Breaking Bad is a protracted Macbeth. It tells the same story, it just takes much longer to get to the point: relatively average man by all accounts has the opportunity to benefit from an evil deed, so he does the evil deed. But then he learns that sin corrupts and blinds the intellect, and evil deed after evil deed, evil becomes more and more easy to commit, and eventually is just about the only thing the person is capable of.

The show-- although this goes unreported-- issues many challenges to materialist philosophies and the like. Although modern, it is also very anti-modern in important ways.

Took away one star because there's some smut the show didn't need. Otherwise, the gold standard.

Season 1:

Overall, Breaking Bad (Season 1) is a very solid start to a show that I've got high expectations for. This season essentially sets the scene for the following seasons. Bryan Cranston is superb as lead character, Walter White. He adds that sympathetic element to his character and he brings the show to life with every episode. There are many solid moments with each episode, that are thrilling and heartfelt. It's a very graphic show, but I feel that does serve the narrative for what is happening, but yes some small parts may be slightly unnecessary. But yes i do feel the show will only get better, and I can't wait to see where it goes. Jesse and Walter, love it!

Season 2:

Well this season kicked off big time and I'm starting to feel this is when Breaking Bad comes alive. This season never put a foot wrong in any department, the story of this season was fantastic and I loved how the writers added that thrill aspect all the way through. More characters are introduced that will no doubt become prominent figures, the writing is great and as I said in my review for the first season, the show is only gonna get better. I like where it's going and can't wait to see what happens next. My personal favourite episode was 9, 11 and the finale was outstanding.

Season 5:

This season just solidifies Breaking Bad's status as easily one of the greatest TV shows ever made, with a strong argument to say it is the greatest. This season builds on all the previous ones that came before it and goes the extra distance. The consistency that Vince Gilligan, the cast and crew manage to show throughout this whole journey is, for me, the main reason why it's the best show, just pure genius. But specifically this season had it all. Tears, drama, more tension and a finale that perfectly wraps up this quite unbelievable show.

Aaron Paul's portrayal of Jesse Pinkman is equally impressive, bringing a vulnerability and rawness to his character that is captivating. The show's attention to detail and cinematography is unparalleled, capturing the grittiness and beauty of Albuquerque, New Mexico. Breaking Bad is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates exceptional storytelling and exceptional performances.

Though I may be very late (more than 4 years); but as soon as i got into the show, I watched the entire 62 episodes within a fortnight. Such an impressive job was done by the stellar cast, especially Bryan Cranston aka Walter White (also known as Heisenberg), that now I treat his character as a real life person out of fiction. The way he comes to know about his inoperable lung cancer and considering how much troubled his life was at beginning of season 1, it was pretty much clear that he had to do something off the charts to earn huge amount of money before he dies(to provide for his family). Here enters the other half of famed duo, Jesse Pinkman. He's a former student of Mr. White who is completely into drugs.Both of them are imperfect but are in sync when doing their common job i.e. coooking meth. Walter, being highly qualified chemistry high school teacher, makes purest meth which even surprises DEA. Everyone is after his famed 'Blue Sky' meth and the sales department is under Jesse. As we later progress into the series Walt and Jesse face many obstacles and enemies like Tuco Salamanca, Gus Fring , a Neo-Nazi group and even Walt's own DEA agent brother-in-law Hank Schrader. But Mr. White outsmarts everyone, either by trickery or total chaotic violence. At the end Walter dies , but on his own terms.

This is by far my favorite show so far. I've always kind of shyed away from shows like this but it was totally different than what I was expecting it to be. The two main characters Walter and Jesse are so incredibly written. Their opposite personalities make it so captivating to see them interacting with eachother.

It feels like there is never a time when they act out of character and I know it's because the writing is excellent, but the actors are perfect as aswell. They play their parts so incredibly well, it feels real. Aaron Pauls performance was absolutely amazing. And his acting in the last season was phenomenal. When he portrayed Jesse's despair it was truely gut wrenching.

And Walter is an amazingly written character. It's clear from episode one that he want's more from life, and we see him discover himself, for better or worse. Bryan Cranston did an amazing job at playing Walters character. You truely feel just how cruel Walter really is, you can feel his manipulation, almost as if his intentions were to manipulate the audience.

Anna Gunns performance was also incredible. I truely sympathized with her character during every season. She is a heartbreaking character, and Anna plays the role of Skylar perfectly. Her character in my opinion is also beautifully written. There is a lot of controversy on the likeabilty on her character, but for me she is my second favorite.

There are also other many amazing characters in the show but I'll spare the details as I don't want to give away spoilers. All I can say is that this show is definitely worth the watch. I'd give anything to watch this masterpiece for the first time again.

S1E3... Krazy-8 called it right there and then. "Your real problem is sitting upstairs." Jesse... Jesse mofo Pinkman. Now... BrBa isn't something new, and there have probably been doctorates written about it already. So I'll just summarize my emotions about the conclusion. I won't mark it as a spoiler, because it isn't. Besides... no matter how I describe Jesse - the truth is always worse.

To start off, BrBa reminded me of the final episode of Riget, another all-time cult classic, something that had a more abrupt ending and a far worse legacy, thanks to Steven bloody King. In that episode, the main actress was chasing someone and had to take an elevator down. And the elevator went to floor 0... -5... -10...-25...-50....-80.... It was an elevator to hell. That's what BrBa is. It's in the name, after all. No matter how tough do you think the situation where the protagonists find themselves in is - the worst is yet to come. It's not even seasons... it's almost like every episode is a floor down... to the last episode's abyss.

The cast is stellar. I mean, sure, there are some prime Hollywood stars that you can just put into anything and that'd be it, like Freeman, Willis, Depp etc, and I wouldn't say that I'd chase the cast of this show wherever else they'd star in. Well, maybe Cranston, he deserves that much. But the cast did their roles, and did them incredibly. Now, almost every character is unlikeable. In fact... only the secondary character are likeable. Steve Gomez, Gus, Lydia... Pretty much the entire main cast are basically mutations of humanity. There's Walter's wife, who really does an excellent job of being the least loving wife imaginable, let alone caring mother. There's their son, who tries his best to be sweet, but who is, after all, a literal r-tard. It's in the script. The DEA brother-in-law, Hank, a piece of work that really goes beyond even his pathetic agency, his wife, basically a mental criminal, who needs separation from society and placement into an asylum, but who is, after all, "family" and who is married to a DEA agent... I'm glad they don't have kids. This pair... deserves to be sterile. But no matter how terrible they are, Jesse, one of the protagonists, takes the cake.

Now, there were two actresses, whom I hated. Well, I mean, hated their characters. Because they were just too good. Marcia Harden from Mist... made the movie, which is quite basic by itself, pretty much unwatchable. Really incredible acting. And Kate Mara. The faces she made in FF2015 and Transcendence... You can't look at them without wanting to him her. Especially because she is female. But Aaron Paul... man. This guy... I'm not sure I'll be able to watch anything else he'd star in. Even that upcoming BrBa movie, if he'll be the lead. I... I really hate his character. He just gets the cake. The absolute monstrosity. The real villain. Hiding in plain sight. It wasn't Gus. It wasn't Walter or Hank. It was Jesse. And no, this isn't a spoiler, this is merely an opinion.

He went from being useless to more useless, from a mess to an even bigger mess. Somewhere in the middle of the show, when he sort of "steeled" himself - I thought they are going to develop him into something. Nope. Still a pathetic, useless shamble. A waste of life, literally. No lessons learned, ever. No effort, no effect. I mean, sure, there were a couple of moments with Gus, where he has sort of done something. I guess the writing can account to that much. But beyond that - he was the absolute antithesis of Walter. No matter what they do to Walter - he is an old man. He goes through hell so much that Dante would tip his hat. Yet he, from the beginning to the end... cares. He has an agenda, and this agenda is love.

Hank... he's an animal. A pig, a proper choice of an actor. Just literally a pig sniffling out his treat. Meticulous, narrow-minded, selfish. For a moment I hoped they'd develop him into anything resembling a human. But no... And yet, even foregoing Hank - Jesse is the real antithesis. A person, who cares for nobody. Well, he does get tantrums about children... not that he ever wants to make one, not unlike Hank. But beyond these tantrums - he is an empty shell. There is no loyalty, no care, no reason, no love, no logic, no comprehension. From the very first episode to the very last - his on-screen purpose is to be a parasite to Walter. A literal parasite.

Of course, the writing is sloppy. You can see the cracks from the very first season. Gilligan did a lot of work, and it is commendable, and I wouldn't do it any better, and that's something you can't say about most Oscar-winning movies nowadays. But still.... he had to tie just SO many loose ends, so many stories. Every character, every detail, every action - needed a consequence, if not a backstory. And so you begin to see the forced writing. I mean, obviously in the real world Hank's first guess would be Walter, come on. Doesn't take a genius. And even then - all of the "solutions" to their problems were forced. Krazy8's plate, Tuco's family\house, Gus' relationship with the Cartel... It's not documentary, but you see how many things are just "too much" of a coincidence.

And it's the worst in the last season. From Walter basically "Dark Knight Rising" himself across the country... to "book" that just happened to be... there... to that... pack of cigarettes... I mean, wow. Poor Gilligan really had to tie up everything and within a schedule. And I'll admit, again, he did it fine. Few shows and movies can brag about a proper ending, and I'd say I'm satisfied. It just felt a bit rushed. While, obviously, the story goes down stage by stage, and it couldn't overlap... "something" could've been done to make it more coherent. Less things left to chance, more things actually discussed or dealt with.

But then again, you realize two moments: "everyone lies". And Walter often makes a complete fool of himself, and I don't mean his "certain moments", forcing an unpleasant outcome. So when everyone lies - you can't seek reason or logic. When Jesse doesn't think, learn or improve, EVER... There is no other way. It could've been written better, but could it really have ended better, without dislodging the narrative? No. It is... Breaking Bad. And you can't break something bad without... breaking it.

Still, if there was something I'd give 10 stars without looking back - that's BrBa. Perhaps the last thing I should add - is how well the director operated, the style of the show. It's all.. REAL. I mean, I remember only once scene where CGI or special effects were used... you know, the Face-off. But other than that? It's all actually real. Filmed not on some 8k IMAX Red Digital Cinema. And such directing, coupled with proper writing and, again, stellar acting - makes this show actually palpable. That's something you really, really miss with modern movies, even Oscar ones. Everything is shot with green screen, stunt doubles, quality is replaced with CGI, writing - with pandering to the lowest common denominator. The fear of a 50 IQ kid\adult not understanding something, and thus requesting a ticket refund - is way bigger than the fear of making a joke of a picture. A joke can sell for a billion, Marvel can attest to that. But a work of art? Eh, it could rot in hell with all those 50 IQ kids not understanding it.

This show is not afraid to be brutal, depressing, nihilistic, outright burdening. I'm not sure fans of most shows\movies would like it, regardless of age. That is - I wouldn't mind showing it to a 10-year-old kid, assuming that this kid is raised properly. Because it would be a great lesson. But I'm not sure about showing it to my aging mother. She likes Vikings and stuff like that, semi-historic with dress-up and special effects. But for something to go dark, like pitch dark... Hell, even my friend of the same age doesn't quite feel like continuing to watch. And I can't blame him... but I can blame Jesse. That sonnova...

Breaking Bad is nothing short of a television masterpiece that leaves an indelible mark on its viewers. Created by Vince Gilligan, this critically acclaimed crime drama series first aired in 2008 and quickly captured the hearts of millions with its gripping storyline and exceptional character development.

The series centers around Walter White (played brilliantly by Bryan Cranston), a mild-mannered high school chemistry teacher who, after being diagnosed with cancer, ventures into the dark world of methamphetamine production to secure his family's financial future. What unfolds is a rollercoaster of moral dilemmas, unexpected alliances, and the transformation of an ordinary man into a complex anti-hero.

One of the show's greatest strengths lies in its ability to delve deep into the human psyche, exploring the intricacies of good and evil. Walter White's character arc is a tour de force, as viewers witness his gradual descent from a sympathetic, desperate man into a ruthless criminal mastermind known as "Heisenberg." Cranston's portrayal of Walter White is so captivating that it earned him multiple Emmy Awards, solidifying his status as one of the greatest actors of our time.

The series also introduces us to a rich ensemble of characters, each with their own flaws and virtues. Aaron Paul's portrayal of Jesse Pinkman, a small-time methamphetamine user turned Walter's partner-in-crime, is equally compelling. Their complicated relationship forms the emotional core of the show, making it not just a crime drama but also a poignant exploration of human connection.

Beyond its outstanding character dynamics, Breaking Bad also stands out for its meticulous attention to detail. The writing is sharp, the cinematography is visually stunning, and the soundtrack effectively complements the intense storytelling. Every episode leaves audiences on the edge of their seats, as plot twists and unexpected turns keep them yearning for more.

Breaking Bad's exploration of the consequences of one's actions, the cost of ambition, and the impact of choices is both thought-provoking and harrowing. As viewers witness Walter White's transformation, they are forced to confront their own notions of morality and ethical boundaries.

Furthermore, the series doesn't shy away from addressing social issues and the impact of drug-related crime on communities. It serves as a cautionary tale, shedding light on the devastating effects of the drug trade and the toll it takes on individuals and society as a whole.

In conclusion, Breaking Bad is an extraordinary series that remains unparalleled in its brilliance. It has rightfully earned its place among the greatest television shows of all time. Whether you're drawn to compelling character-driven narratives, intricate moral dilemmas, or simply seek an enthralling viewing experience, Breaking Bad is an absolute must-watch. Prepare to be enthralled, disturbed, and profoundly moved by this unparalleled masterpiece of television storytelling.

"Breaking Bad" is the best TV show I've ever seen. A TV series that doesn't need words to describe the splendor that this show represents. I was stunned by the characterization and change of characters during the 5 seasons, which are one more beautiful than the other! Walter White I think is one of the best protagonists in the history of cinema and is definitely one of my 3 favorite. Jesse is one of the best deuteragonists that cinema has ever presented, a perfect character. A character that I think is underestimated for the importance it has is Flinn, I love him. I loved Hank Schrader so much and I hated Skyler. Marie is a good character, but I never liked her. Mike is a great character that I can't wait to deepen with "Better Call Saul", and with him also Saul Goodman that I love so much. The various antagonists in the series convinced me a lot, especially Gus Fring, one of the best characters in the series. Gilligan's direction is sensationally beautiful and innovative, he had an incredible idea. The plot is a bomb and his writing is phenomenal. The level of photography is incredible, the images are iconic. EVERYTHING IN THIS TV SERIES IS ICONIC IN THE CINEMA WORLD. I have no words about the actors' interpretations: Bryan Cranston among all played one of the best interpretations of the story, but as he did an excellent job Aaron Paul, Anna Gunn, Dean Norris, Giancarlo Esposito, Bob Odernik, RJ Mitte and all the rest.

Now I talk about each of the 5 seasons: -The first season is in my opinion excessively hated. I loved it! The first episode is amazing and introduces the TV series flawlessly. Everyone says that the first season is very boring and is the worst: in my opinion it is anything but! It's a magnificent first season because it should be seen as an introduction to the huge and perfect story that will develop! It only serves as an introduction, and it does. Perfectly.

-In the second season much more things begin to happen. We are beginning to see the dangerous side of drug trafficking and the troubles that the protagonists will have to face. This season introduces the character of Saul: FUNDAMENTAL!. It took such a weird character to animate the whole thing, and he does it perfectly. I really enjoyed Gus Fring's introduction here. I also liked Jane who gave Jesse a moral boost.

-the third season animates things a lot: you can see the radical change of Walter who realizes that sometimes you don't have to use half measures. It deepens the character of Gus that interested me immediately and I loved the greater family involvement in writing.

-The fourth season, on the other hand, is on the level of perfection: here we can really see that the issues are no longer just related to money but are also beginning to enter the threatening and dramatic side of the series. I loved Jesse's biggest burn and his dramatic deepening. Hank is becoming more and more central in the story and I really liked this choice. This penultimate season I enjoyed a lot.

-I don't want to talk about the fifth season: PERFECTION ON THE SCREEN.

This TV series overwhelmed me, it gave me emotions that I had never felt before. I would pay to see it again as if it were the first time.

Every element of this show leaves me awestruck. Over the top performances, spectacular cinematography, mind blowing plot and steady pace with faster ending makes this an all time favorite. Breaking Bad is the most exhilarating, fast paced show you will find, every action causes a reaction later in the story, this is Breaking Bad's greatest feature(in my opinion), they set up something and pay it off brilliantly. Other than that, the show's other strengths are the characters, who are brilliantly acted, the action, the tension, the writing, the cinematography, the production design and much, much more. I recommend that you watch this show and also go watch it's sequel film, El Camino, and it's prequel series, Better Call Saul.

Breaking Bad is as ominous and poignant as it is amusing and flippant, the escapades of the Chemistry Genius High school teacher gone rogue with an ex student is as comical as it is meaningful, but what really provides is how striking this series is as an enigmatically exceptional production that ceases to amaze on both levels of scope and scale.

From the beginning to the end Breaking Bad exceeds to captivate and involve the audience cognitively and materialistically, each episode holds equal to importance and intrigue; the choreography illustrates masterful simplicity in coherence with the plot. Throughout the series the audience is played emotionally. Empathy and apathy play fundamental roles in the portrayal of characters that never once become a tedious appendage to the bigger picture, even less significant roles are imposed as impacting and spur charisma and diversity into a story line that at first glance seems rudimentary.

Walter White, the main role in Breaking Bad is acted and directed in exemplary fashion, his pitiful situation reflects a superlative in character development and provides an ample perspective to the resultant outlet of his intentions. The family of Walter, while being implied as implicitly innocent actually come into interaction with the dark side of Walter White often, this continuity and differentiation between clandestine and regular give not only Walter White two sides of a coin but also his lifestyle and the subsequently subversively progressive nature of the plot.

Breaking Bad holds true to the realism and philosophy of ethical and morale situations, while also making these situations entertaining in a perversely farcical manner. It's this often uncannily insinuative implication of life's misdemeanours that makes Breaking Bad such an unimpeachable, refreshing and original achievement.

Starting with the story, when you hear about a drug dealer makes drugs "methamphetamine" and kills souls, you will hate him without knowing him of course, and here comes the philosophy of the writer and the way he writes which made me sympathized with that durg dealar in this series and with the other side at the same time, that thing revealed to me how the writer is genius !!

The superb thing in this series when it comes to the writing is each and every character had their own impact on the story in a way or another, the writer put so many details to make sure that "death isn't the end" so that even if the character dies it's affect will appear in the series sooner or later ..

And the last thing is the family, the great message that made me fall in love with this series is the family in which the main character of the series became a drug dealer and he knows that thing is illegal but he did it just for his family so when he dies he will ensure his family future and even if he died his family will always remember him and what he did for them.. for me that message was enough to make this series one of the best in tv history..

If you're a series fan and haven't watched Breaking Bad yet, you're missing out the BEST series ever created.

One of the most interesting points in the series is to observe the evolution of each characters, the formation of character, what is considered ethical, the involvement between them, their standards of acceptance, in short, a great evolution that allows the viewer to understand the reason for each decision taken.

The way the plot is done: breathtaking!

Simply: WATCH.

And don't forget: watch the movie right after the last episode.

So, back in about 2010, I (living in Europe) stumbled across this series. After seeing the first episode, I had to immediately call my movie-buff-friend to tell him to go watch it right away! (Normally, we would wait until our regular meet on Sunday to tell each other about good new stuff we'd seen).

. He was also immediately hooked and we discussed the developments of our now shared soul journey every week. In awe of the next level writing, cinematography and high production values.

. I never re-watch series, but at the hint of another friend I have started re-watching Breaking Bad from the start. In the first 2 episodes, I spotted some questionable decisions. But hey, they are not hardenend criminals at this point, I'll continue.

. I just saw S01E03, with Walter sitting opposite of Domingo. The heart-wrenching struggle, sorrow, fear and consequences sunk in to the core again.

. I know now I'm going to watch this masterpiece all to th end again. And it will again not be easy. Breadking Bad is rightfully the all-time top of *multi-season* series on IMDB. Simply the best TV every made.

There's no denying it, this is the most fascinating show I've seen since I was born. I just found out about this show in 2014, and every day I watch many episodes continuously, then watch it again from the beginning. BB is like a delicious dish that you can eat forever, never get bored. It was perfect in everything, the content, the music, the setting, the production design, the cinematography, the acting, the characters, the twists, and the ending. Walter White is perhaps the most memorable and distinctive character in the history of movie and TV show characters. He is special not only in his position in the film (as the main character's transformation from good to bad) but also in his transformation in psychological depth. He makes us wonder why we support bad things so much, and we find all sorts of excuses to justify them. Since when have we been hypnotized by Heisenberg?

As the title says, Walter is really talented. And he is a good man. But no one is perfect. Walter simply doesn't accept that. To be more precise, he was allowed by society, the law and the people around him to not accept his own incompetence. Given his ability and what Walt did, he deserves more than he has, he deserves to be honored and admired, and appreciated more than that. And he knows it. The problem is, the things around him, his friends, his colleagues and his wife, always give him the feeling that he is just a normal person like everyone else, even a bit shy and easy to bully. Or at least that's how he feels and accepts that reality. A person who is inherently talented and is always proud of it, what would he think? The man of the family, Walt accepts the truth, but his pride does not. And when he realized his efforts were being turned into the success and glory of others, this hurt Walt even more. Lung cancer is just a drop of water that overflows an already full glass. And that evil pride won.

Watching Walter White transform into Heisenberg was truly magical and made me think alot. Does he love his wife? Yes. Does he really want to earn that money for his two children? Yes. But it seems that it is the conscience of a good person, which has long been swallowed up by that evil pride.

Breaking Bad is proof that a movie or TV show can become a classic without spending too much money and creating all sorts of fantasy things and monsters. The more I watch the last seasons, the more I see that the darkness in Walt is stronger and more reckless, at this point the good conscience in him has given up, but it still tries to find something to survive, like a redemption, Jessie-Pinkman. Walt sees him as his student boy, a testament to Walt's talent, Walt also sees Jessie as the son he wants to have, at least from Jessie's personality. Walt has always wanted to protect Jessie, just as the part of Walt's soul wants to save itself. However, even that is not enough.

It can be said, Breaking Bad is a gem of movies and shows, the greatness of the experience, the thing that can turn pride into tears, and turn those tears into emotions filled in the heart. You don't cry, your heart cries.

And I mean, Walter White is both a victim and a villain, a strong man, a weak one, an inspiration and a sinner. What a character! What a show! I don't want to say anything more. Should we sympathize with Walt and give him love? Or will we judge him for the evil things he has done? Maybe it's one person's point of view, or it's two streams of thought in each person. I respect all those thoughts. Anyway, I love this show very, very much!

The ending of Niubi proves that the play is an insurmountable drama. When Mr White finally admitted, "everything is for himself." It has exposed the hypocrisy of the family thought that the United States has always advocated, and slapped those hypocritical mainstream dramas loudly. Human nature is selfish.

I'm on my 7th time around for Walt, and it's not lost its (crystal) sparkle. I don't know how it could be more perfect. I think even writers across this wonderful planet would have a game adding to this masterpiece.

It's such a lean story line, virtually no fat to cut from it. The only episode I'd happily skip is that bloody fly. Other than that......a joy.

The characters are so rich too. For me, the best kind of characters....you can't pigeon hole! They all seem to evolve into something completely different, not just Walt.

Even after 7 times around, it still makes me nervous to watch, and excited to see the next episode. You forget parts, then magically remember them.

Breaking Bad will not be knocked off its mantle any time soon. Bravo Vince!!

An amazing series about a Chemistry teacher diagnosed with cancer who decides to make drugs. At first Walter's decision to make drugs is to make money for his family to pass away, but the real reason why he keeps doing it, is because those years that he spends making math are the times that he has felt most alive, ironically despite the fact that he is dying. What makes this series so good is Walter's character, watching him progress from this person who has never had any excitement in his life, to doing "new" things due to the fact that he is living as though it was his last day. I rooted for Walter through the end, despite many of the monstrous acts that he committed, due to the admiration I have for this amazing character. There are many other very well fleshed out characters who are all amazing, but not on the level of Walter Hartwell White. Also, every single soundtrack which is picked in this series fits in perfectly and suits the scene which it is put in.

Vince Gilligan is a genius. The story telling is just awesome. The direction is just perfect with Bryan's contribution to it. I hear people saying that it's a slow story. I don't know how can they think this way. I think the story telling of Vince is a gift from God. The way he focuses on every detail is an art. I mean, how can you love or hate a character if you don't pay attention to details. How can you think it's slow and boring! Better call Saul is another must watch show for breaking bad lovers. Another masterpiece. ‚ù§

One of the best shows ever made. I dont even know if something like this will ever be made again. Its gonna affect you mentally, emotionally and in many other ways you cant imagine. The writing is superb, not to mention the acting from its two main stars, Bryan Cranston and Aaron Paul. Everything you already heard about this show - is probably an understatement.

The acting in it is truly amazing. It probably is the best acted TV series of all time without a doubt. Bryan Cranston delivers one of the best acting performances ever, but the supporting cast is almost just as good. Usually, there is a dropoff in tv shows in movies; you'll have one or two great performances, but the rest of the smaller supporting cast is basic and average, but in Breaking Bad, there are truly excellent performances and the roster runs deep. This is the kind of show or movie where even the smallest roles are memorable. There really isn't one bad actor in any part of the series, and that's part of what makes it so good.

Once you are finished watching this masterpiece, watch it again because there is so much attention to detail that you can't pick up on in your first watch. There are all kinds of foreshadowing, symbolism, references, and little details that will make you appreciate it even more. This is not a show where one watch is enough. It gets better every time you watch it. Also, be sure to learn about the making of it, behind the scenes, the story of how it got made, all the Emmy awards and other awards it won, the records it set, what other prestigious names in Hollywood like Anthony Hopkins said about it, and all of the greatly written articles on it. It will really help you cope with it ending. But a warning: it is so addictive and good that you will probably find it difficult to let go, and every other show in the future will pale in comparison.

If you haven't seen Breaking Bad yet, do yourself a favor and experience this once in a lifetime classic. Avoid any spoilers, and it will be ten times as good like it was for me and first time viewers during its airing.

Breaking Bad is a show about two men deciding to make crystal meth, but what is magical about the story premise is that is what it feels like watching Breaking Bad. You can not help but be hooked and want to watch more and more and more and more. Aaron Paul is phenomenal as Jesse Pinkman, Pinkman is very, very dumb, but he is so lovable and despite being a drug dealer still stands up for what is right at times. The amazing thing about Jesse Pinkman is that he clearly he has a consciousness when it comes to killing people or ruining people's lives. He does not mind when they are drug dealers, but when they are good, normal people he cares and stands up for what he believes in. Cranston is amazing as suburban husband and teacher Walter White. The audience sees White morph from a wonderful, thoughtful husband into a cruel, callous drug lord. White becomes an entirely different person and even gives himself a new name for this new persona, but I will not spoil that. The writing is absolutely superb, the only bad episode that I can remember is called "The Bug". Breaking Bad may be the best show of all time, but that has to be one of the worst episodes in the history of tv shows. Please skip that episode, but otherwise it is absolutely amazing. I watched this show for the first time at a very young age and it definitely had an impact on me as to whom is involved in the drug world and erased any curiousness I had as to how drugs would make me feel. I suggest this for teenagers, adults, or anybody who wants to watch amazing television while discouraging drug use at the same time. Breaking Bad definitely does not glorify the world of drugs, it simply states what the drug world is like. Please, please watch it, you most certainly will not regret it!

I'll keep it short: Each episode may not be better than the last, and there are certaintly "filler" moments in the show like any other, but never has a show been able to get you so invested into its story and characters like this one. Each season is better than the last and each big moment will have another to one up it till its finale, which isn't the best of all time, but certaintly better than Game of Thrones. Don't care who you are, you have to watch this show. It may be slow at first, but it is so worth it till the end. No matter what.

The adventures of Jesse Pinkman and Walter White are legendary. These are some of the most masterfully crafted characters to ever be created by a pen on paper.

I can't stop praising the acting and cinematography. I was seldom distracted by the acting since some of the shots are complex pieces of art. The performances are so good that it seems inappropriate to call them performances.

Overall, Breaking Bad is able to retain the level of interest and technical excellence seen in only the finest of movies, and in terms of tone, every episode is constantly engaging.

It's no secret that "Breaking Bad" is one of the greatest television series of all time. The show's captivating plot, brilliant cast, and masterful directing all contribute to its well-deserved acclaim. At the heart of "Breaking Bad" is the transformation of Walter White, played to perfection by Bryan Cranston. White's journey from a mild-mannered high school chemistry teacher to a ruthless drug kingpin is nothing short of riveting. Cranston's nuanced portrayal of White makes it easy for viewers to become invested in his story, even as his actions become increasingly reprehensible.

The supporting cast is equally exceptional. Aaron Paul's portrayal of Jesse Pinkman is a standout, imbuing the character with a raw vulnerability that makes him both sympathetic and endearing. Anna Gunn is also noteworthy in her role as Walter's wife, Skyler, adding depth and complexity to a character that could have easily been one-dimensional.

The show's creator, Vince Gilligan, deserves much of the credit for the show's success. Gilligan's writing is taut and suspenseful, while his directing brings a cinematic quality to the show. The use of color and framing is particularly notable, with each shot contributing to the overall narrative.

"Breaking Bad" has received numerous awards and accolades, including 16 Primetime Emmy Awards, 2 Golden Globe Awards, and a Peabody Award. These accolades are a testament to the show's lasting impact on the television industry.

One of the most impressive aspects of "Breaking Bad" is the way it explores complex themes such as morality, power, and corruption. The show is not afraid to take risks, pushing the boundaries of what is acceptable in mainstream television. It is a bold and uncompromising series that demands the viewer's attention and rewards them with some of the most memorable moments in television history.

In short, "Breaking Bad" is a television masterpiece that will stand the test of time. Its captivating plot, brilliant cast, and masterful directing make it a must-watch for any fan of the medium.

This show was absolutely brilliant. Wonderfully written and beautifully carried out by the actors. I was hooked after just the first episode and could NOT stop binge watching. There is never not a time when it's boring in any way, it kept my attention throughout. Truly an "edge of your seat" kind of show, and that's just an understatement. Watch it now!!! And be prepared to have lots of spare time as you will definitely want to binge watch.

Bryan Cranston is the best actor on this show but I have got to say Aaron Paul comes profoundly close to being nearly as good as Cranston, both of their characters are are amazing and what complete this show of course along with all of the other actors.

I know I'm probably writing this review for no reason, as there are already hundreds of thousands that you could read, but I needed to express my admiration for this utter work of art. In my opinion - and many others - Breaking Bad is the best TV series ever created. The basic plot greys the lines of morality by making the protagonist the villain. This has been done before, but never have I related to a criminal like this. The story structure is completely solid and the progression always works to further the main plot. The writing from Vince Gilligan is phenomenal; I can't remember an episode of the series that I disliked. The story was always furthered in each episode. Aaron Paul and Bryan Cranston portrayed their roles flawlessly, I don't remember a second thinking something was unrealistic or cheesy from them. But while Cranston was entirely spectacular, I never felt the same connection with Walt that I always felt with Jesse. Aaron Paul absolutely blew me away with his performance, portraying Jesse Pinkman as a pitiful addict who you just want to comfort. Overall, this series has no flaws. I will recommend it to everyone of my friends until they all love it as much as I do. 11/10 stars, thank you Vince Gilligan for making history.

Breaking Bad was an amazing show. Once you start watching Breaking Bad from Season 1, it will feel a bit slow but gradually as the story progresses, it becomes strongly addictive and gets very interesting. Everything was perfect about this show in my opinion: The acting was perfect, the storyline and script of the show was very good; the way everything takes place and how the plot suddenly thickens when something significant happens is certainly very good. The plot twists were very surprising and interesting. The VFX of one of the major plot twists was surprisingly good. The art/props department certainly made the famous half face well. The soundtracks of Breaking bad implemented and highlighted the key points and storyline very well. Another thing I really like about this show is how Walter changed from a poor weak high school teacher to the biggest meth kingpin of America running the largest meth manufacturing operation in US history. I also really liked how the relationship of Walter and Jesse forms over time and how they go through all these situations and continue cooking with each other; they have this connection between each other like father and son; like the child Walter never had. The things they go through and how they are there for each other is very amazing. Besides, Walter and Jesse were a really funny duo and made me laugh a lot during the show. The funny thing is that Jesse was originally set to be killed off during season one! In my opinion this show was quite funny at times. Overall, it was a very well thought out drama TV series and I think it was amazing. Breaking Bad also achieved 92 awards and 248 nominations and it has also been nominated for numerous accolades, winning five American Film Institute awards for Television Program of the Year. I am thinking of re-watching the whole 5 seasons again at some point in the future. That's how good it was.

While the second season was somewhat weak (compared the rest of the show, that is), every episode of Breaking Bad is an achievement in entertainment as we know it. Despite its slow start, this show does a brilliant job at transforming Walter White, a sad, dying man who wants nothing more than the good of his family, to Heisenberg, the only man to rival Gustavo Fring in the methamphetamine business. Every actor in the show, Brian Cranston, Aaron Paul, Dean Norris, Anna Gunn, R.J. Mitte, Betsy Brandt, and so many more show themselves to be heroes of the acting craft. From every monologue to every look to every hysterical breakdown, the cast is mind-blowingly good. The same can be said for writing. Ingenious action sequences as well as quiet, heartbreaking interactions. Nobody can emulate this dialogue. It is a treasure. without getting into spoilers, I can really only say to watch this show now if you haven't already. The greatness of this show can not be overstated.

The middle-aged male teacher, who is poor and down-to-earth, with his genius and courage to see the dead as the end, has made an exciting career of poison teacher under the surface of a quiet life! Full of tension plot, natural and appropriate interpretation, full score work.

Breaking Bad is almost perfect The only thing that puts people away is its slow pase, I hated it too, especially in the first two seasons (It took me over a year to finish Breaking Bad because of it) but I began to apprieciate it because it built up tension, gave the viewer more reason to care about the show's main characters, because the slow "nothingness" that happens throughout episodes is mostly their day-to-day life and without fancy camera angles you could buy this as recording of actual real life people, because the show keeps things realistic especially in these slow moments.

The story? It's almost perfect (Once again it gets a bit rough around the edges in the first two seasons) The acting? It's almost perfect And overall it is a really fun and emotional experience.

It really toggles the problems of society, masculinity, war on drugs and the criminal world. If you like these subjects you will really find something intresting in what the show has to say on each of them.

Definitely recommend I just wanted to write about the slowness of Breaking Bad because that's the only thing that keeps it from being a 10/10 That's why I give it a 9 Go watch it if you didn't!

I have watched around 25-30 TV shows and I couldn't take my time or I didn't had any intension to write a review. But this show made me write. Yes!
