I've been watched this many many times, makes me feel like home.

Breaking bad is a good show but fails to achieve greatness on multiple levels due to a combination of bad acting, unrealistic writing and lack of grit.

Brysan Cranston plays Walter White who is terminally ill high school chemistry teacher who decides to leave his family with a substantial sum of money to support them in the future by cooking meth. There is no denying that Cranston is fine actor but the supporting cast and where the show gets let down the most.

The supporting characters do not come across as believable either with their dialogue or actions and sadly their acting is less than desirable. Like so many before it the show strives to show "true" grit but fails like so many American shows, I don't know whether it is the lighting or make up but everything is too shiny and clean and this is a common problem with American shows compared to British shows, which do often capture the rough and crude far better.

Breaking bad is good show but nothing special but worth a watch is nothing else is on.

Breaking Bad could have gone down in history as one of the greatest television shows ever if it had ended on a high note.The logical place to end it was at the end of the fourth season when Walt killed Gus Fring.Not only was it the greatest on screen death ever, they couldn't possibly ever create a more realistic and terrifying bad guy.The next season was spent trying to tie up all the loose ends and it was very unbelievable.Even worse, they decided to insult your intelligence by cutting the season in half and making it two seasons.That's a bitch move.They knew they had jumped the shark but they weren't done taking your money.So they forced a last season on us and it had a lame story and disappointing end.They went with the old tactic of bringing in Nazis to make the real bad guys look good.A last ditch attempt to win over anyone who thought Walt or Jesse weren't great people.All they succeeded at was ruining a great TV show.One good thing is that I never saw that end coming, because it was stupid.I'd recommend this show to everyone, just stop after the fourth season.
What a freaking serie!!! Haisenberg is one of the best performances I've ever watched in tv or movies

I love Breaking Bad but honestly it is a bit over hyped. For my liking it's one of my favorite shows ever but I would have never expected it to have such an amazing rating. 8.5 IMDb rating sure but 9.4 is surprising. There are way too many filler episodes that build up for some epic craziness in the episodes following so you have to get through them. Also, I would have thought the acting, which I think is amazing, would hurt the shows rating. The actors play the characters so realistically that it might be mistaken for bad acting, especially Bryant Cranston playing Walter White. In real life, people in tough situations people tend to struggle with decision making. I believe that people who don't like this show, which I thought would be a greater number, don't understand that we are watching the characters from 3rd perspective. For us observing the events, it seems so obvious to how the characters should react, but put yourself in one of the characters shoes, lets say Walter's wife Skylar, and you would react SO SO similarly to how she did/does. The story line progresses so much throughout the seasons that it's hard to believe where it started. The build up to the main episodes is so great that it gets pretty predictable to what is the big thing that is suppose to happen but these main events are so crazy that even when we know what's going to happen, they are still surprising. If that even makes sense. You have to watch the show to understand what I am talking about. I highly recommend Breaking Bad. Try taking into consideration what I mentioned above when watching and you will be one of those people that understands the show and wont be skeptical of it.

First of all, I really liked this series, and think the direction and acting was excellent. That said, I must ask "why the hell couldn't they get a native Spanish speaker to play the part of Gustavo Fring?" It is more than apparent that first, he is not a native Spanish speaker, and second, in no way resembles or speaks like a Chilean. I mean, c'mon - some 16% of the population of the U.S. is Hispanic, and in the huge pool of people they couldn't find a good or even great native Spanish- speaking actor, maybe even a Chilean? Even the main chemist in the lab in Mexico did not appear to be Mexican. To name just a few candidates for the Gustavo Fring part known in the U.S.: Edward James Olmos, Jimmy Smits, Andy Garcia, Benicio del Toro, Hector Elizondo, Alejandro Gonz√°lez I√±√°rritu, Raul Julia, etc. Probably any of these very fine actors could have been coached to have a convincing Chilean accent. H√©ctor Noguera, one of the many fine Chilean actors, could have done the part without breaking a sweat. This is without considering that the character may or may not really have been Chilean, but that's another discussion, and in any case, he was SUPPOSED to have been Chilean, so he could at least speak like one. None of this is to disparage Giancarlo Esposito's work, which wasn't bad, although he only seemed to have a few facial expressions. Perhaps that was what the director wanted, given the character, so I'll give him the benefit of the doubt there. In any case, great series.

Few times I've become addicted to a TV series. I started with Breaking Bad just randomly, and I don't regret it. Just watch the first episode and you will know what I mean.

Although the main subject may be a little bit unpopular for wide audiences and perhaps unsuited to kids and youngsters, I would recommend this show for the rest of us. The story goes about an underachieved high-school chemistry teacher and family dad, that one day is diagnosed with terminal lung cancer. Since then, he will try to gather as much money as possible to sustain his family for whenever he is gone and to pay his cancer treatment. He finds a gold mine when he applies his knowledge to the meth business (chemistry freaks may enjoy the technical stuff in the episodes), and he finds himself and his business partner in a number of kafkian situations that will keep the audience tied to their sits.

Cranson and the rest of the cast make a hell of a performance (note: Cranson got 2 consecutive emmys for the leading drama role beating Dr. House and the Lost guy). In my opinion, special mentions are also due to Hank, the DEA officer, and Saul, the attorney; they make outstanding performances in their secondary roles.

All in all this is a TV series with a very fine balance between suspense, drama and even some comedy, with an original plot and with an outstanding crew.

2 closing comments: Do not feel guilty if you find yourself with the need of watching 4 or 5 episodes per day, and yay!, they are coming back in July 2011!

Have you ever experienced a life changing event which has turned your complete world upside down. I can't say I have, but I know someone who has. His name is Walter White: Loving father, true husband, dedicated chemistry teacher, crystal meth master chef. "Wait a second!" you think. Something in that sentence didn't fit in. You're damn right it didn't, and that's what makes Breaking Bad fit in perfectly in the series hall of fame!

50 year old Walter White has a teenage son with cerebral palsy, trying his best to fit in, and a pregnant wife not afraid to speak her mind. When Walter learns that he has lung cancer and probably hasn't got very long to live, he decides that he must do Whatever IT Takes to secure the future of his family. As far as I am concerned, producing crystal meth serves perfectly well as the IT and Walter seems to share my view on that. He's got the brains, he knows the chemistry but lacks the street experience. Better gain some.

Breaking Bad is all about conflicting opposites with an antihero leading the way by erasing the fine line between right and wrong, good and bad. How long can you keep keep a double life double? How much bad is acceptable in the attempts to achieve something good? There are many questions to answer, but there are no clear answers to be found. Once the iron chains of the law have been broken there ain't no easy way to mend them again, unless you want to play the part of the missing link. Walter sure doesn't and is driven further and further down the path he has chosen, transforming into someone no-one had expected. As long as I can be the spectator watching from the other side of the screen I'll cheer it all on with eyes big as steering wheels screaming: "Break that law! Break it bad!"

Oh, did I mention that Walter's brother-in-law works for the drug enforcement administration?
Love this show. Walter white is a genius in everything he did. True master mind.

A rave review of Breaking Bad doesn't do the show justice. My words have been said by many, but I'll say it again, Breaking Bad is the greatest show of all time. It goes to another level. The story is intriguing and, in the sense that many men with little income are diagnosed with the financial and physical burden of cancer, quite relatable. The use of symbolism is evident and is done in such an intelligent way. The show is written with such versatility and excellence. Vince Gilligan is able to write each of his characters in the own way; he uses wit and humor, while also effectively writing dark, dramatic scenes and lines. The acting is - for the most part - unbelievable, which is mostly a testament to the show's star, Bryan Cranston. He captivates audiences with his dilemma that they sympathize with, and he presents a dramatic, and sometimes laughable character, which he brings to life. Supporting roles filled by the likes of Anna Gunn, Aaron Paul, Dean Norris, Giancarlo Esposito, Bob Odenkirk, and Jonathan Banks are performed brilliantly. The show is directed in such an interesting and unique way.

What really goes a long way with Breaking Bad is its standalone nature. You'll never watch a show similar (except its spin-off, Better Call Saul, which is also phenomenal). WATCH THIS SHOW AND WATCH IT NOW.

First of all: Breaking Bad is easily the best show ever made, great story, brilliant actors, 10 out of 10. Only one thing is a bit puzzling.. what is the point about all those allusions to Germany? Many characters (an they are not all nice guys) have names of German origin: Family Schrader, Ted Beneke, Gale Boetticher, Mike Ehrmantraut, Gretchen Schwartz, Dan Wachsberger etc. Walter White calls himself "Heisenberg" (a German physicist). Jessy uses terms like "Adolf" and "Hitler" to show his disrespect to certain people. Hank says things like "we are not in Nazi-Germany" or "there are enough Germans here to invade Poland". Last not least the company "Madrigal" that controls the drugdeals is located in Germany. To much for coincidence, or not. Anyways, the makers seam to have a special affinity to our country:)
Personally it changes behaviour and it attracts who are helpless and weak.

When straight-laced high school chemistry teacher Walter White is diagnosed with cancer, he turns to cooking meth hoping to sock away some big money for his family before he dies. But the cancer might not get a chance to kill him after all... his new profession might just do it faster.

From frame one... of episode one... of season one... this series will grab you by the soft and hard parts and not let go. You will be drop-jaw-wowed by the production quality, scripts, acting, and execution of this stand-out series.

True artistry and brilliance is transparent in writing and filmography so that what appears to come through is real life in all its gritty, ugly glory. Breaking Bad delivers in a way few series ever have. The casting is superb and virtually every actor is stellar. The twists and turns of the plot are delicious and the ride is as intoxicating, unpredictable and addictive as the killer meth Walter cooks up.

This AMC gem is every bit a premium cable channel production from start to finish. You will swear you're watching HBO or Showtime. If only every show on TV was even half as good! Breaking Bad deserves every industry award and accolade to be had.

It says something about a TV show when even the episodes could be called, 'filler' are entertaining and do something great. Breaking Bad is a show where no episode, scene or moment is wasted. Everything about it is brilliant, the writing is masterful, handling characters and plots with ease with each season building on the next. Delivering both funny, profound, shocking and heartbreaking moments. The directing is superb especially considering they film each episode in only eight days. It always tries to do different things while always serving the story. Visually it is wondrous to behold. The acting is top notch, Bryan Cranston delivers Walter Whites slow decline into villainy wonderfully and Aaron Paul will only be remembered for his role as Pinkman.

This show delivers, when people say it's great, they mean it. It is one of the best shows I have ever seen.

I watched Breaking Bad after seeing Cranston was in it. I never previously searched for stuff with him but love Malcolm in the Middle -- only Cranston could have played Hal. Likewise, I felt he really made the show for Br Ba, although alone it is a tremendous piece of work. By any definition Br Ba set a new standard for dramatic thrillers. There's still nothing like it. On a personal note, I give a thumbs down to any review calling it a comedy-drama. Though there may be some humor behind the idea of a science professor becoming involved with meth, with Pinkman's incompetence in very serious situations, or with Saul's persona the series itself is not meant to be funny, imo. I've watched the series a number of times and I'm just trying to understand what could be such a humorous thread as to call the series itself comedy. Unfortunately, there is no specifics in those reviews so I'm at a loss, but hoping those people will seek help with their depraved sense of humor. For me, it is a very gritty and profound story that shocks even the most worldly viewer just when you start to feel safe. In the trivia section (with lots of great tidbits), we learn that Gilligan had used Cranston in an episode of X Files where he played opposite of his comedic persona, and states Gilligan knew from there only Cranston could play Walter White. He also is quoted as saying he wanted White to go from a Mr. Chips type to Scarface. I actually was rooting for Heisenberg (a tribute to Werner Heisenberg, who formulated the uncertainty principle) and disliked the ending initially. But as Anthony Hopkins stated, Br Ba is so amazing it can be compared to a Shakespearean tragedy. I was also one of those who strongly dislike Skylar, played exquisitely by Anna Gunn. Not because she was a "strong female lead" as she once claimed was the reason so many disliked the character, but because she was -- probably very intentionally -- the main antagonist to our lead guy, Walter White. Another interesting note is that Showtime, TNT, and HBO all declined the series when it was pitched & FX picked it up but dropped it for the show Dirt (I bet they all regret that now). Truly a mind-bending series that introduced us all to the overthetop facial & verbal expressions/emotion that are now so predominate in every genre. If there was ever a spin-off worthy character from the series, you would think it'd be Saul, however for me that series was so detached from Br Ba that it was relegated to my "maybe later" list. I think the series died with -- well, you know...

You know Hype? Yea It can be a beach. I've been following IMDb for a while now and I can honestly say that there's a certain demographic that votes for TV shows and movies on this site. In this new millennium there have been new shows with great ideas like Game of thrones,Dexter and of course Breaking Bad taking over modern television, but unfortunately all of these shows are overrated. I don't want to bash breaking bad-The show definitely has some good qualities and ideas going for it, but I just cant feel underwhelmed by most parts on this show. The writing and duologue are just average and the characters personal lives are about as interesting as my next door neighbors(which I can actually care about).

Compared to the witty and thought provoking duologue of dramas like six feet under, Oz, Sopranos, Shameless,Walking Dead and The Good Wife-Breaking Bad can just not add up. Don't get me wrong I wont doubt Vince Gilligan as a decent script writer,but this show has too many pot holes for it to be called the best thing on television. To elaborate the show has a lot of dead time that just leaves it to meander. The characters are unconvincing and the duologue cannot support them and just falls by the waste side.There are people that I respect that love thisshow, but I just cant help but feel a personal tragedy that I cant get into Breaking bad.

I remember seeing the score on IMDb, metacrtic and hearing about all of the accolades the show has gotten. So I decided to watch the show from the beginning to catch up with the loyal fans. I really didn't like season 1 and 2 and found the rest was thoroughly enjoyable, but earlier today during the amc marathon I wanted to show my mom,sister and grandma breaking bad. Sadly they weren't into it and unfortunately neither was I. For some reason the spark was gone that was once there from season 3-5. All the episodes seem boring and pointless. It almost seem like I was watching a boring Tarantino movie with no plot or duologue(And we all know that's what makes his movies special.

In the Top 20 alone there are shows with violence,drugs and sex.Breaking Bad has all of the above and im not saying that's a bad thing, but it seems like breaking bad is relying on its shock value to keep people intrigued. Breaking Bad is a show that clearly has a lot of hype and a cult fanbase backing it, but the acclaim for this show is baffling to me..People act like its the best thing since sliced bread .There are better TV shows out there than this(An average 99 average score on metacrtic and loads of nominations/Awards!! are you fuggin serious??) This show is average at best, but hey that's my opinion. Dexter,Mad Men and Breaking Bad they all have one thing i common: Their all overrated and rely on style instead of actual substance, but they do have their moments which deserves some consideration of checking them out.

It's freaking great to see the idea of a show like breaking bad taking off on regular cable television and I'm worried that the hype has affected my opinion for the worse, but I felt it was kind of necessary to make a review for people looking for a little more elaboration,and possibly a dissenting opinion. Thank you for your time. This is just my opinion.

Disgusting, hyper-realistically gritty, painfully frustrating in that "I don't want to watch but I'll look through my fingers" kinda way . . . yet eminently watchable and extremely funny. I don't know how they get through the situations they do but fate always lends a hand, albeit digging a bigger hole each time.

Every single aspect of this production is a little quirky - plot, script, casting, acting, cinematography, music. Nothing is straight laced which makes it endearing. But that's not likely to be the adjective that comes to mind after the pilot episode . . . think Tarantino does Weeds.

Just remember not to eat anything beforehand.

I watched the whole five seasons in just a few days and words cant express the way the show made me feel about how shows should be made. I could just imagine the love viewers must have over the years for the characters. You just can't forget the characters unlike other mediocre shows.

The acing is top notch, the directing is pretty flawless, the writing is genius, the editing is so tight that if you skip five seconds you might miss a major twist.

To see Walter White grow from an ordinary teacher to a criminal drug lord is worth every bit of your precious time. The themes of Family, Loyalty, Greed are explored and displayed on screen with such precise accuracy.

If I have to recommend a show to a person on his or her deathbed, this is it. In the words of Jesse Pinkman: What you waiting for... Bitch.

This's a serious story which indeed looks so realistic that in many ways it resemble how people really falls into crime! Rise in the story is scripted so well that in end if you would have been asked to resign from your job just to watch the remaining series, you would do that and think of yourself later :)

It's a masterpiece. I highly recommend this as the most watchful series. I'm a serious fan of Bryan Cranston, so I won't say that he has done role of his lifetime :) but he surely did a class act in this epic series for which he would always be remembered for and without him as "Walter White" "Breaking Bad" would have not been THE "Breaking Bad".

Aaron Paul has also done a classic role I enjoyed it but the real deal is Bryan's character "Walter White". Story revolves around him. Once you start watching this series you'll feel for all characters, you'll develop emotions for him and in end when everyone else hates Walt you'll become his greatest supporter!!

I have almost completed watching it in its entirety for the second time. It's the best TV show of all time, and it will probably have that distinction for decades to come, like the Beatles. I actually continue to like movies much more than TV shows, but I cannot even think of a movie that I like nearly as much as this show. The Beatles of movies has yet to be released, I guess. :)

I have seen the series Gomorra, that made a real impression and impact for me. I do not think you can compare these 2 shows, but I think because of that I am not too much impressed with this series.

I have watched many episodes a day. Not always to know what will happen and sometimes I did not want to see it anymore. The acting is great, the camerawork is nice, the characters make mostly logic choices and there is not much luck involved. It looks like a raw show, just like in real life.

But that is why I do not like some parts of the relationships and how the characters are communicating. Sometimes they look like some children who have lost their toys. Maybe that is the point, but I did not like it. And when they almost come to an understanding, it will go wrong again with full force. I do not think that is realistic.

I have also the feeling the series wants to be a lot of things together and that is why I am a bit confused. There is almost no gore, yes sometimes a few body parts are flying around, but suddenly you see half a face. Not shocking, but I thought: why? And that only happens once. And the balance between serious stuff and comedy is tipping over as the series progressing. I think Fargo did a better job at that. Is it realistic how the drug world operates? Not really, you only see the top of the iceberg. The violence the drug world is using then? I have not seen so much about the all powerful kartel, but suddenly it is gone... So it is action? Yes there is enough action. It also likes to show you what the actions do to other people related to the main characters, but also not too deep.

What I am trying to say is, I am left with a bit of an empty feeling, because I did not know exactly what I saw. So I think it is a drama/soap/action and it is a good one. I am not sure that I can relate to the main characters fully. It is difficult to know what is going on in the heads of the characters. Or maybe I am the idiot here...

So wanted to watch the next episode, I do not want to see more if it. It is good like this. It was a nice ending of a good series.

No wit, No humour, and definitely NOT suitable for the kids! Breaking Bad (2008) feeds the hungry self-centred know it all's by having its protagonist be most selfish and foul to his accomplices! How can anyone find this enjoyable? Not to mention the poor attempts at comedy, it's clear they're trying to imitate the greats such as "The Plank" and "Breakfast at Tiffany's". Brilliant. JUST BRILLIANT. Well done Hollywood, yet another failure. Oh, for Petes Sake! There is NO commitment to actually entertaining the kids whatsoever, which is highly questionable for its PG rating! Don't get fuddled up, the acting is gorgeous, completely beyond my comprehension. But do not waltz around and spit and sneeze on kids hopes and dreams with such twisted episodic concepts! The kids were very disappointed with this one, and I concur. Definitely skip this, for the sake of your children - At least the writers are self aware of how "breakingly BAD" their show is!

Non-stop adrenalin-rush crime-drama following the story of Albuquerque chemistry teacher Cranston turning into a methamphetamine kingpin in order to secure his family's finances after being diagnosed with inoperable lung cancer, calling upon ex-student Paul to assist in the streetwise aspect of the drug business. Cranston is perfect in one of the most mind-blowing hero-to-villain transformations, backed by unforgettable recurring characters like Saul Goodman (played by Bob Odenkirk), Gustavo "Gus" Fring (played by Giancarlo Esposito), Mike Ehrmantraut (played by Jonathan Banks), Todd Alquist (played by Jesse Plemons), Lydia Rodarte-Quayle (played by Laura Fraser), Gale Boetticher (played by David Costabile), Victor (played by Jeremiah Bitsui) and the Salamanca Family (played by Mark Margolis, Raymond Cruz, and twins Daniel and Luis Moncada). Unfortunately, the major supporting roles played by Paul, Gunn, Norris, Mitte, Brandt and Quezada all take their turns at being incredibly annoying or ridiculously codependent on the despicable main character. The show's intensity ends up overshadowing some great themes and symbols involving moral consequences and family devotion. Also, for such a nail-biting show, the ante isn't actually raised all that much in hindsight. Still, and most importantly, it's an overall excellent show‚Äîactually one of the few series that literally gets better and better as it progresses. High recommended.

***¬Ω (out of four)

I have been glued to the screen for five seasons - approaching the end of Season 5 with reluctance. This is one of the best series I have ever seen with stunning acting. One flaw has kept me from giving it a ten. Everything to do with Skyler's pregnancy and with tbe baby just doesn't ring true, as if it was written by someone remote from the subject. Women of forty - however, glamorous - do not sail through pregnancy problem- free, occasionally stroking their bellies to remind us of what's going on. As for Holly, she must be the most unobtrusive infant in the history of mankind - occasionally someone shoves a bottle in her mouth or dandles her on their knee but she is simply not a presence in the family and seems happy to spend her time sitting in a baby chair looking demure. She also doesn't seem to be aging at the right pace. As I said, the only flaw I found.

It's a series that has several genre (police, drama, thriller and black comedy) The country of origin is the United States. The original language is the American language. There are 5 seasons. There are 62 episodes. Breaking Bad is the story of Walter White, 50 years, a professor of chemistry at a high school in New Mexico. To support Skyler, his pregnant wife, and Walt Junior, his disabled son, he has to work twice. His already gloomy life becomes downright black when he learns that he has an incurable lung cancer. Doctors do not give him more than two years to live. To quickly raise a lot of money to protect his family, Walter sees only one solution: to use his knowledge of chemistry to make and sell crystal meth, a synthetic drug that pays a lot. He affers Jesse, one of his former students who has become a small second-clss dealer, to team up with him. The improvised duo set up a traveling lab in an old motorhome. This unexpected association will lead them into a series of adventures both comical and pathetic. What i like in this series is that there are a lot of adventures and that a lot of things happen to the main actor (the chemist), sometimes it's surprising, sad, funny, and sometimes even horrible, it is the mix of emotions that can be felt in this series that i love the most. In addittion the universe is quite special and the story is really intriguing, which interests me a lot. I will give the series a score of 9/10 because i would have liked it to continue.
Awesome, brilliant, emotional, and every amazing things

Well first off, What the hell is there to say about Breaking Bad that hasn't already been said. Even though Better Call Saul is now in it's 4th season and is due to air at some stage this year, Breaking Bad is still very much at the forefront of AMC's hit list and hands down one the most addictive show I've ever seen in my life .

The first season starts off simple enough. Set in Albuquerque, New Mexico, Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher, discovers he has stage 3 lung cancer (despite being a non-smoker) and after discovering how much money can be made in the drug trade he teams up with Jesse Pinkman, a former student. It's there they begin manufacturing Methamphetamine as a way of financial security for Walt's pregnant wife and teenage son who has cerebral palsy.

Later on in the first season, Walt and Jesse get introduced to Tuco Salamanca, an extremely unpredictable and violent psychopath (played brilliantly by Raymond Cruz). Walt and Jesse sell the first batch of their product to Tuco and make their first fat stack of cash by doing so. The last scene of the first season really sets the standard for the rest of the series and gives you a solid idea of what's ahead.

I won't spoil anything for those of you that haven't had the chance to experience this masterpiece of a tv series yet, but the later seasons of Breaking Bad introduce more high profile figures of the underworld, shows A grade character development of the main cast of characters and shows the dire consequences and toll it takes on families who are caught up in the dark world of crime.

Of course, this series probably isn't for everybody, that's understandable considering it's content but Breaking Bad is hands down one of the best series ever made. The first time watching it, I couldn't believe how quick i got through the first season. It's just that kind of show. Brilliantly written. Brilliantly acted. Dangerously addictive, just like meth!

10/10

I felt compelled to write because I really enjoyed breaking bad, not all of it, but it had its thrilling moments, ones really memorable are the turtle scene, bombing Gus and the second encounter with Tuco.

What I really need to say, the fact that Walter is victimizing himself in way that you can relate to is well crafted. He has a grandiosity dementia which is the product of his acute intelligence, yet sometimes, he is sensitive and breakable by the least of emotions. Severe paranoia mixed with psychopathic morale is the actual trade mark of Heisenberg.Creating such a character is really a job well done! We are almost days away of the final 8 episodes, and let me be frank for a moment, the first 8 were not up to par. The absence of a powerful adversary kinda took away the magic of Breaking Bad, Walter is going down, one way or the other, but I hope his fall is going to be as memorable as the fall of Hitler, if you know what I mean.

P.S: Spinning off Saul, eh, fed up with corrupted lawyer drama, I would rather see a crossover between Hannibal and Heisenberg.

I started watching breaking bad whilst in university. My friends told me how great it was for years and I didn't really care to watch (and I watch a lot of TV shows). After the first 2 episodes I was hooked. The relationship between Walt and Jesse is unmatchable, the introduction of the other characters and the role they play such as Gustavo keeps the series interesting and exciting, the constant plot twists and action, even Walt and Skyler's marriage is just so damn funny. The storyline, the writing, the drama, the action, the way this programme has you glued to your seat is like nothing else. I nearly failed my degree as I watched the entire series in 3 weeks and flunked my exam due to spending too much time on breaking bad but it was worth it. Since watching I've tried to enjoy other programmes and don't get me wrong there is many fantastic TV programmes but everytime I finish another I just sit back and say to myself "wasn't as good as breaking bad though".. It has ruined TV for me but do I regret it? Absolutely not. Greatest TV series ever to exist and I don't think anything will beat it. If you haven't already, sit down and watch it immediately, you will not be disappointed!

Bryan Cranson and Aaron Paul deliver on this legendary series that will go down in history as one of the best. It's the perfect anti-hero story - a science teacher who finds out he has lung cancer and inadvertently finds a way to make drugs that can earn him some faster cash to live his final years the way he wants to. But naturally, this is a dark path that leads him into some dark choices. The twists, turns, dark comedy and ultimate tragedies will keep you captivated and wanting to binge this entire series in one sitting. There isn't a single dull moment in this series and you'll often find yourself laughing and shocked within the same episode.

It is impossible to think of every adjective to describe the epic story that is Breaking Bad. The show from beginning to end is probably one of the most incredible rides in the history of television.

This series doesn't just dive into the drug trade and the criminal underworld that cooking crystal meth delivers, this show also dives into the lives of each character and makes you see the moral complexity of each and every character in the show.

So why is it that I also said it is one of the worst series of all time too? Well it's pretty simple really. Once you see this show from beginning to end, you will be amazed... better yet so astounded, that you may not be able to watch ANY other show on TV because of it. No matter what you do, or what you say to yourself, you will almost always compare every other TV show to Breaking Bad and find that you will not find anything as incredible as this show is. The show is that amazing. I only watch Game of Thrones, True Detective, and Sons of Anarchy now because of it, and they still pale in comparison to this show.

And in fact, upon another binge worthy viewing of the show, it may actually be better the 2nd time around since you can actually see the changes that each person goes through without wondering what will happen next. I keep saying it to anyone that I'm friends with and others as well, you are doing yourself a disservice by not watching this amazing piece of art that truly will stand the test of time.

This is a show that leaves me hanging, hangover, having that void of a feeling when it ends and it lasts for quite a long time. Vince Gilligan is a name that's hard for me to forget, and I often forget names. Easily one of my favorite shows of all time with a perfectly crafted ending.

Breaking Bad. Where do I start with this masterpiece? This action-packed, beautifully written, incredibly shot, work of art known as Breaking Bad is the most beautiful, most incredible, most excellent show someone could ever hope to watch. It's expert written creates unbelievable tension that will grip you. This is a tale of love, betrayal and change that deserves the hype and awards. It has the greatest story, character arks, cinematography, characters, writing and more of any television show ever! The only other competitor is Better Call Saul(the prequel) which is also unbelievably excellent and is worth a watch after this. Some may find both of them boring for the first season or two but when you get to season 3,4,5 it becomes even more incredible! 30/10.

The. Best. TV. Show. Ever.

It's been 5+ years since I watched the masterfully put together finale of Breaking Bad. The fact I'm writing this now shows the profound impact it's had on me.

It's very rare for a series to nail everything - casting, acting, writing, directing, plot and character development, entertainment value and the all-important - knowing when it's time to end and doing it in style. Breaking Bad does this like none has ever done before it and will likely ever do again.

It's said the writers wrote the ending first and then worked backwards, and it shows.

Everything that happens in the four series leading into the final series (and the final episode) was perfectly put together to enable this masterpiece to finish with the crescendo it deserved.

It's only after you've been punched in the guts by the final episode that it becomes clear that everything you've been watching for the past 5 years was done for this very moment - the last perfectly shot and acted last 10 minutes of the finale.

Watching the last episode was at the same time satisfying and yet there was an empty feeling straight after knowing Walter White would no longer be in my life.

Breaking Bad has set the gold standard for TV series. It's like watching 62 hour long feature films which you never want to end. It's the Mona Lisa of TV - it will never grow old and the more you look at it the more complex and beautiful it becomes, while still being something which on face value looks so simple.

If I could give the 1 billion stars I would - but IMDB only lets you give it 10, which just doesn't represent the masterpiece it is, and will always be.

I had to admit, when I watched the first few episodes of "Breaking Bad" I was quite unsure of what I thought because the characters appeared to be very predictable and the story wasn't immediately that interesting. I just took it to be a saccharine drama involving a man who ends up selling drugs with his younger stereotypically "comic relief" stooge.

HOWEVER, as the story develops it completely reversed the initial view that I had of it. I found it very gripping, completely unpredictable, moving and, generally, it is unlike anything I have seen from this kind of genre. Nothing feels forced or overdone. I think this is because the series starts off in ordinary surroundings and in a typical environment. Every character has a real depth to them, which shows how much thought has been given to the detail of the overall series and the direction it will take. Once you start watching you are very unlikely to be able to stop watching! If you're watching with anyone you will be both be heatedly debating what will happen.

What an awesome change of pace for Bryan Cranston, who is best known for playing the goofy dimwitted Homer Simpson like dad from Malcom In The Middle(2000-2006). But this character is not goofy or dimwitted. Walter White is your everyday man, who is a high school chemistry teacher, and has a loving wife and handicapped son. On the verge of his 50th birthday party. He begins having a mid life crisis, to make matters worse, he is diagnosed with terminal cancer. But not wanting to leave his family with nothing, in a quick way to make a lot of money. He teams up with a former student named Pinkmam(Aaron Paul) who is now a drug dealer, to make the drug called Crystal Meth. You don't like what Walter is doing, but at the same time you try to understand why he is doing it. I like watching the transformation he is going through, like Mr.Chips turning into Michael Douglas from Falling Down(1993). This series is quite enjoyable, it's a good dramatic series, with some humor moments. Cranstons performance in the show is memorable, and at times heartbreaken to watch. And he and Aaron Paul play off each other so well. I hope it will last a little while.

This is without a doubt the best TV drama I have ever seen. I have now watched this show three times, and I am sure I will watch it many more. The plot is the so incredibly interesting and entertaining, filled with characters so well constructed, and dialogue that can be heartbreaking but also darkly funny. I would recommend to everyone, but I would also recommend watching it again even if you've seen it. This is because, even though there are many dramatic and exhilarating moments throughout, it is quite something to look at this series as a whole and see how it all comes together in the end. It is so clever and so well thought out, which is missing in so many otherwise good series on tv today. The acting is so incredible. Aaron Paul gives an outstanding performance as Jesse, and enables you to sympathise with and love a character who usually you wouldn't. What is most amazing is the detail put into the growth and evolution of Walter White. It astounds me how you can initially feel sorry for and be worried for a character, but there are points later on in the show where you actually despise that same character. I haven't seen anything like it, and I doubt I ever will again!

Many times throughout the show you "think" you know what's about to happen but things take a split second turn. I was satisfied with the ending but would have been more stoked to see how one other character that drives away ended up. I wont give away who it is but it would have been gratifying to see how his life turned out since we saw how his partner ended up. Or at least have seen what was next for him. Either way the best show I have seen in my life. It's basically an extremely long movie thats about the best way to put it.

*taking a deep breath and slowly exhaling *

So a few years back I was, much like today, a really enthusiastic fan of music and cinema and stuff like that, and much like today I was up and ready to talk with just about every single person who was ready to listen about my favorite albums, TV shows and stuff. Yeah, the spirit of the reviewer has been in my heart for quite some time now. I was much less broad when it came to the genres I consumed, I didn't try to analyze things as thoroughly as I do today, and I'd say that I generally took less time with each experience I had in that regard. Indeed, these were different times, and I was a fairly different person in some senses.

That was the time when Breaking Bad had entered into my life, and boy oh boy, was my mind absolutely blown to pieces. For years I used to tell people that it was the best TV show I've ever seen, and I really can't overstate the impact that it had on me in the time. It was an emotional rollercoaster, and even though, like I said earlier, I wasn't much of a deep-dive guy when it came to TV shows, the experience was so amazing that I truly wasn't feeling like I was missing on anything.

Fast forward. I'm starting out to review stuff online, and I come upon this YouTube channel called The Take, which has some really solid film analysis content. After a while I discover their Breaking Bad analysis series of videos, and something about it just opened my eyes. There was one video and particular, regarding father-son relationship and some religious symbolism, that really hit hard for me, and yes: I cried while watching an analysis video of a TV show I've seen several years ago, and I guess that with all the hype around Better Call Saul it was enough for me - I wanted to re-experience Breaking Bad. I wanted it as a preparation for Better Call Saul, I wanted it so I could review it and share my opinion with y'all because that's what I do, here in my tiny platform, and most of all I guess that I just wanted to try and re-experience this series, now that I've seen more stuff and feel like I have a deeper understanding when it comes to these matters.

Alright, then. Breaking Bad. Let's do this.

Breaking Bad follows this high-school chemistry teacher, Walter White (Bryan Cranston), who lives his gray and ordinary life in the shadow of all the opportunities he has missed in his life. After he gets a lung cancer diagnosis, and influenced by an idea that was sparked in him during an interaction with his DEA agent brother-in-law, Hank, Walter decides to start cooking and selling meth, so his family will be financially stable even after he dies. In order to achieve that goal, he reaches out to Jessie Pinkman (Aaron Paul), a former student of his, now a drug dealer, with a partnership offer. What could possibly go wrong?

The most common complaint I've heard about this series from people is that the pacing is way too slow, and that it takes ages until something even remotely interesting happens. To that I say: guys, you trippin', Sorry not sorry. Alright, yeah, some chunks of the series have a slow-burn type of thing going on, but come on: things are really intense and explosive even from the get-go, and I feel like there's always something interesting that's happening on screen. I just can't see how one might start season one and think it slow or boring, but you do you. And you know, even beyond that: some sections of this series were so intense and immerse for me, that even in rewatch I was on the edge of my seat. I would say that it speaks to the power of the plot here.

The second thing that I'd like to praise is the casting here. The cast is absolutely PERFECT, all caps. Each actor and actress feel like the role was tailored just for their size, and I feel like you could literally look at any random character on the show, pause for a second and then realize just how they embody their character in a flawless way. Not just the main characters, too. You'll get what I mean when you watch it, but yeah, it's amazing.

When it comes to the themes that are explored in the series, I find the dive into festering emotions that just eat you from the inside really interesting, and also the exploration of toxic masculinity in many shapes and forms. Walt also goes through a major metamorphosis throughout the series, and I don't wanna spoil anything but I'll just say that the shift is so slow and well-crafted and it feels very, very real, and it's probably the thing that makes Walter White one of the roundest characters I've ever came across. By the way, changes that characters go through in this series in general, like, not only Walt, are always really slow and meticulous. One event here that changes them slightly, one event there that does something in the same direction, and slowly but surely things shift in a very effective way.

Cinematography-wise I think that every episode is at the very least well-directed, even though different directors have worked with Vince Gilligan throughout the show, so it's pretty understandable that there are some episodes that are better directed than others. The dialogues differ sometimes in their level, but most of the time the dialogue is, again, at least very solid, and most episodes have several highlights when it comes to the dialogue. One thing I can pinpoint that I always find brilliant in Breaking Bad, even though it might sound a little funny, is the montages. They are always so satisfying, used to propel the plot in a very fluid way and have something extra memorable about them. Cheff kiss, every single time. Like, wow. Music choice, editing, pacing - it's always on frickin' point.

It's worth mentioning that the series has really effective villains, and I won't get into details so to avoid spoilers, but trust me there. Great bad guys for a great story.

One last thing: even though I was indeed immersed in the series to an extent, and I'd definitely say that it was pretty great rewatching this show, Breaking Bad doesn't have an insane amount of rewatch value imo. No rewatch will be better than the first time with this one, probably, and that's why I'd definitely recommend letting yourself fall into it completely when watching for the first time. I hope that Better Call Saul will really make Vince Gilligan's strength as a storyteller fully shine again for me.

So even though there are some parts here that could have maybe been better paced, and despite the first time watching being stronger than my rewatch, there are so many great things in this series. There's so much attention to detail, impactful writing whether we're talking about main characters or side character, a plot with twists and turns that can be extremely intense, and a deep-dive into toxic masculinity and festering emotion. If you can manage more bloody and drug-related stories, watch it. Definitely one of the best shows I've ever seen. Feeling a 9.2/10 on this one.

In my opinion this is quite simply the best non-Sci-Fi drama series of all time. It starts off pretty slow in the first and second season, but by the third and fourth you can't stop watching. I watched the entire series in the week between a Christmas and New Year on an AMC marathon.

In addition to impeccable writing, direction, and acting, it is actually very realistic unlike all those CSI-type shows. The drugs and drug-prohibition businesses both work exactly like this in reality, and other than a few simple substitutions (it's actually quite easy to obtain methylamine in bulk; pseudoephedrine and P2P are the chemicals that are very difficult to obtain in large quantities), the science is on point as well. It's also the most accurate portrayal of the behavior of meth addicts I've ever seen in fiction.

"Breaking Bad" is a groundbreaking TV series that captivates viewers with its interesting story, filled with suspense, drama, and action-packed scenes. The show delves deep into the criminal underworld, showcasing the transformation of a seemingly good man into a dark and twisted character. As the plot unravels, viewers are drawn into a world of mystery, betrayal, and moral ambiguity. The series masterfully portrays the inner conflicts and external pressures that lead to the protagonist's descent into the criminal world. With strong character development and intense storytelling, "Breaking Bad" keeps audiences on the edge of their seats, delivering a riveting narrative that explores the consequences of one man's journey from good to evil.

2 words into the review and I didn't know what to say, I am really astonished by this series. It has everything, great actors, brilliant plot, the idea in itself was so simple yet created such epitome of perfection. 5 Seasons, they are, but you won't feel it, you will get addicted to it.

Breaking Bad is simply a phenomenon that won't re-occur, because in its ingenuity, it is so unique. It's so genius, comedic when necessary. There is Action, Drama, Humor, Joy, Melancholy, plot-twists, cliff-hangers and everything.

It feels so unfaked, the way it's all set up, it feels like a real story, no place for supernatural events. You will see yourself as part of the series.

Breaking Bad cannot be judged by one or two episodes, it's a puzzle of 62 episodes, won't unravel 'til gathered.

I recommend this to everyone, and I mean, everyone.

Breaking Bad is one of the best TV shows to ever air in history. Now for me, this is the best TV show I have ever seen. Just seeing this guy go from being all nerdy and timid to this tough and self absorbed man is truly incredible. I have to give it up for Bryan Cranston. He is one of the best actors living right now. He was born to act. I mean his face just has so much emotion in it. Most actors have to try and get the right facial expressions to play that character right. But Bryan's face can make a wide range of expressions without even having to do much. And oh my goodness... Aaron Paul... When I first saw this show, he didn't seem like such a good actor. To me at least he didn't. But as the show goes on, his acting becomes phenomenal! Like when he gets mad in the show, it makes you think that he's in full rage in real life. It's truly amazing. Everyone did an amazing job on Breaking Bad. Every single character in the entire show was incredible. Breaking Bad is the gold standard of television.

No review is gonna do it justice. I first watched it in the later years of airing, getting a hype that made it really addicting. After the series ended, I didn't want to lose that sensation and ended up listening to that Gnarls Barkley's song again and again until I got tired. For a long time, I wanted to watch again. This 2019, I finally watched it again and all I'll say is I got a different experience mostly. The series is full of so many details that I sense I'm gonna watch it a third time after another 5-7 years or so, maybe 10.

This is the best storytelling of all time. hands down. the writers of this series put on a clinic on how to tell a story.

i understand that there is a mystery as to what good storytelling actually is. but the bottom line is this: a story must be rich with irony. this is what makes breaking bad so good. a high school chemistry teacher cooking meth. after getting diagnosed with cancer, he pursues this goal to provide for his family after he dies. meanwhile, his brother-in-law is a DEA agent who pursues drug traffickers such as himself. all of this is extremely ironic and it plays across the whole series.

i've never seen such good storytelling from any other TV series. some movies come close. but nothing really touches the scope of breaking bad. the character arc of walter white. watching him transform from a meek man to a murderous, vengeful drug kingpin is fascinating. jesse pinkman is also a revelation. he is the most tragic character in this story. his inner conflict is heartbreaking.

nothing comes close to this TV series. the sopranos is a joke compared to breaking bad. with time, TV and film historians will look back and agree that breaking bad is the best television series to ever be made. that's guaranteed. walter white is the best protagonist to be ever portrayed on the big screen. other television series like Lost, The Sopranos, The Wire, Mad Men, and others have shown flashes of brilliance .. they've even had many seasons in a row that were brilliant. however, they fell apart at one point or another. Lost really dropped the ball at the end of their series. however, breaking bad maintains an incredible quality throughout. the ending is like no other. ironic. palpable. captivating. one of my favorite episodes is the 2nd to last episode of the series. i'll never forget the closing scene of the 2nd to last episode.

This s a masterful exploration of moral decay, following the transformation of Walter White from a mild-mannered chemistry teacher to a ruthless drug lord. The show is brilliantly crafted, with meticulous attention to detail and a narrative that builds tension to almost unbearable levels. Bryan Cranston's portrayal of Walter is nothing short of iconic, as he brings depth and nuance to a character who is both terrifying and tragic. The supporting cast, especially Aaron Paul as Jesse Pinkman, adds layers of complexity and emotional weight to the story. "Breaking Bad" is a slow burn, but it rewards patience with some of the most memorable moments in television history. It's a gripping tale of ambition, power, and the consequences of choices that resonate long after the final episode.

First off...I do not write a reviews on many things. Only at a time at which I truly feel that compelled to do so will I take the time to write out a review. It was probably 2012 when I had first heard of this show just in passing...it was one of those "Man you need to watch this show" type of statement that someone told me. Of course people say these types of things all the time trying to sell other people on good shows to watch so I didn't think anything of it and continued on my merry way.

The day had finally come when I was searching tirelessly on Netflix for something to watch and by this time Netflix had just added the first 4 seasons of BB so I decided to actually sit and watch the pilot episode. Right away after hitting the play button on my remote the show snatched up my brain and grabbed a hold tightly...the creative genious that is Vince Gilligan really put together a picture perfect pilot episode which could really stand along as its own animal. The Cinematography is brilliant, the show's opening title sequence is picture perfect (Not too long, not too short and currently serves as my phone ring tone btw) and just over all feel of the show is very real in tone. You don't feel like you are watching a "tv show" but rather experiencing the lives of these people.

So after watching the pilot that was it...I couldn't pry myself away and I then binged the entire 4 seasons up to that point taking breaks only to sleep and eat...Everything about this show is perfect from the pacing, the character development, the acting and the creative attention to detail in the story telling...it is all so perfect and amazing to experience. Bryan Cranston has become my new favorite actor after watching this show...he is so relatable and everyone knows someone like Walter White in their life but he does an absolute amazing job in this role, it is no wonder why he has won so many awards.

What is great about this series and is something rarely seen is how it progressively gets better and better right up until the finale...there are no weak moments or weak episodes, everything has a point and purpose to the story telling and every episode gains momentum from the previous...its like a giant rolling snowball just waiting to hit something. The reason I am writing this now is because for the 3rd time I am re-watching the entire series simply because nothing is out there for me in the form of the same good entertainment I can find. I watched the series for the first time by myself, then I watched it again with my girlfriend a couple years ago, and the just last week I was bored one night going to sleep and thought what the hell I'll just watch the pilot episode again just to fall asleep to...Guess again, just like the previous 2 watches I got hooked again and was up til 3 am watching 4 episodes (That I had already seen 2 times) that is the effect this show has on people... it is as addictive to view as Heisenberg's baby blue Meth is to consume. I find myself with this stupid vindictive grin on my face when I finish watching these episodes even the 3rd time around...I catch new details never seen before.

In conclusion, if you have read this all the way to the end and are in the unfortunate group to have not watched this masterpiece of a show, please reconsider your time over the next couple of weeks and take a seat in front of the flat screen, pull up Netflix and enjoy what is probably going to go down as one of the greatest pieces of television in all history.

I love media and entertainment. Movies and video games tend to be my favorite but one form of media I don't really like nowadays is television. I used to love TV series as a child but growing up I've lost a lot of interest. Despite this I actually thoroughly enjoyed one show, and that show was Breaking Bad. I've always heard about this show from everyone saying how awesome it was, but I never really had any interest until I saw my uncle watching it. I was hooked on just one episode.

The series is all about a chemistry teacher named Walter White who is diagnosed with lung cancer. His future looks bleak but he decides to get treatment for the cancer anyways which would be expensive and probably put his family into debt, so he decides to do something crazy just to support his family. He had two jobs already but being a teacher and car wash worker alone could not do the job. He teams up with the second main character, Jesse Pinkman to synthesize and market methamphetamine. This point is where the series takes off and gets much more interesting. Walter White and Jesse Pinkman turn from zeroes into successful and rich drug lords.

Everything about this show was just fantastic. My favorite aspect of the entire show though had to be the characters. All of the characters, even the minor ones were three dimensional and exciting. I loved this show so much that I even liked to see the characters I didn't like, because they still added something amazing to the story. There was also loads of character development and even character derailment. All of the characters' relationships and interactions made sense and tied together. The main character Walter White, who turned into a monster, I still supported because he was just so well written that I couldn't help but love him no matter what he did. If anyone wants a show with great characters they would really like this show.

Another aspect about this show I like is the theme and dark tone. This show was intended for mature audiences and nothing about this show was sparkly or innocent. I love morbid TV series and everything about this show was morbid. I was on the edge of my seat every episode. It was almost as if I could feel all the suspense and nervousness the characters felt. Usually it's very difficult to pull off dark themes, but Breaking Bad did it with perfection. I do admit though that the first couple of episodes were really hard to watch but it turned out to be worthwhile. Let's just say the whole thing about drugs, murder, sex, families being torn apart, and etc. was pulled off marvelously.

This show just had everything. Although my favorite parts of this show were the characters and tone, I still liked everything else such as the plot, music, visuals, and writing. I don't think I'll find another show that can hook me like this one. If you couldn't already tell I highly recommend this show to all adult viewers who like something edgy. If you don't really like edgy shows try this anyways because it's just that good.

In this gripping show, the characters are all complex and flawed, and they all make mistakes and sometimes make baffling choices based on their circumstances. The line between "good" and "bad" is undefined in Breaking Bad; nobody looks particularly likable, including Walt's brusque brother-in-law, Hank (Dean Norris). But Cranston's performance is its best quality. The spacey, clueless dad of Malcolm in the Middle transforms into an iconic anti-hero. In addition to Cranston, Paul, Giancarlo Esposito, and Gunn also shine. Despite amoral characters, the show has tight direction and intelligent writing.

Firstly and foremost i'm not going to blabber on with a comparison of other successful television series i.e, GOT, SOA, LOST, DEXTER and the rest of these brilliant projects. This is a series in an entirely different and unique realm of TV.

After hearing through the internet/tabloid grapevine that Bryan Cranston would be taking the lead in a new AMC series it got me very excited and anxious,..anxious with regards to the fact that this fresh series would be conveyed in a ''Black Comedy Drama'' setting, to which I felt intrigued whether Mr Cranston could pull it off? not only does he 'Pull Off' the role of Walter White in this 5 series bonanza, he moulds walter white into one of the biggest on screen marvels of ALL TIME, Bryan Cranston is a truly terrific actor who deserves nothing but praise and commendation for his electrifying performance as the power hungry, ruthless Meth Kingpin...Just for the record his display of Walter White is so good it grabbed the attention of Hollywood legend Sir Anthony Hopkins who personally wrote an email to congratulate Bryan Cranston on his depiction of Walter White.

Obviously the show isn't glorious purely on Cranston's acting ability, huge credits have to be awarded to the brilliant cast namely Aaron Paul Anna Gunn, Dean Norris, RJ Mitte, Betsy Brandt, Bob Odenkirk and many other worthy actors/actresses who brought this series to life.

It would be scandalous of me not to mention the brain behind this project, Vince Gilligan, a insanely talented and imaginative screen writer/producer/director who injected the show with a shot of pure class.

Overall I just can't describe how perfect this series is, there just isn't enough words, even with the 1000 characters I'm allocated for this review.

Bottom Line, just watch it, it will probably be the finest thing you'll ever set your eyes on. It certainly was for me.

Great show, great story in general. However, Walt and Pinkman are the most annoying leads of any series ever made. Pinkman is a disaster in the 1st half, but turns into a great guy in the 2nd half. When Walt has not much time left to live because of his cancer, even his only son tells him on the phone why he is calling him, that he is an ashole and that he should die already. Because of what he has done.

Walt is indeed a bastard. But that doesn't mean it's a bad series. All the characters are fantastic characters, played by great actors. Hank, the Salamancas and many more.

But one thing is really badly done. A crucial part of the story is not believable. Look here: ".... Hell yeah. I won against the Mexican drug cartel and the drug lords of New Mexico. I am Heisenberg. .... But wait....there's still evidence against me that would put me in jail....damn it. It is a laptop with sensitive data against me. This laptop is being kept at the police station in a secure room with armed guards. Damn it. There is evidence against the mafia, all kinds of criminals and drug clans. But hey, no problem.... nothing easier than that. All I need is a magnetic crane from the car crusher.... We'll take it to the guarded vault and have a bit of World War 3. Isn't that a great idea?". They did it, and it worked. This sounds like a story written by a 7 year old child.

Breaking Bad is a television series that left a profound impact on me. From its gripping storyline to its masterful acting, every aspect of this show is executed flawlessly. As I watched the show, I was sucked into the world of Walter White and his descent into the drug trade. I felt like I was experiencing the highs and lows alongside the characters.

One of the things that made Breaking Bad so successful is its ability to evoke a range of emotions. From sadness and despair to excitement and adrenaline, the show kept me on the edge of my seat. I remember feeling a sense of dread as I watched Walter White struggle to balance his double life as a high school chemistry teacher and a drug kingpin. His internal struggle was palpable and made me question what I would do in his shoes.

The show also utilized dark humor and sarcasm to great effect. There were moments where I found myself laughing out loud at the absurdity of the situations the characters found themselves in. The juxtaposition of the humor and the darker themes of the show made it all the more impactful.

The acting in Breaking Bad was also exceptional. Bryan Cranston's portrayal of Walter White was nothing short of brilliant. He brought a depth to the character that made me feel both sympathy and revulsion towards him. Aaron Paul's performance as Jesse Pinkman was equally impressive. His character arc was one of the most satisfying aspects of the show.

The cinematography and soundtrack of Breaking Bad were also noteworthy. The show's use of color and lighting to reflect the mood of the scene was masterful. The soundtrack was also perfectly curated, with songs that perfectly complemented the tone of the show.

Overall, Breaking Bad is a show that will stay with me for a long time. It's a masterclass in storytelling, acting, and filmmaking. It's a show that made me feel a range of emotions, from the highest highs to the lowest lows. It's a show that I will continue to recommend to anyone looking for a thrilling and emotional viewing experience.

I have never watched a show that is as consistently genuine and engaging as Breaking Bad. This is undoubtedly one of the greatest shows ever, and it consistently improves as it progresses.

The Journeys of Walter White and Jesse Pinkman are unforgettable. These are some of the best-written characters to ever come from a pen-hitting paper.

My praises for the acting and cinematography are unending. Some of the shots are intricate works of art, and I was rarely distracted by the acting. The performances are excellent to the extent that it feels improper to refer to them as performances.

Overall, Breaking Bad is able to consistently maintain the engagement and technical quality seen in only the best of movies, and in terms of tone, every intense moment is executed with excellence, and always achieves the impact it reaches for.

I feel like the show's plot in the early seasons lacks a certain level of complexity due to it not having a vast amount of plot threads, and the start is a bit slow-paced, but Breaking Bad is an absolute must-watch. If you have mixed feelings towards Season 1, trust me, it is only uphill from there.

A willing suspension of disbelief and reluctant mindset is an absolute requirement to enjoy this drama. It is completely and utterly implausible to believe that anyone similar Walter White could succeed as a meth chemist for even one season without being killed or caught within the 62 episodes the series has. But the tight, virtually seamless story, and the sympathetic relatable characters, who nearly all resonate with most watchers, allow you to willingly set aside any differences with plausibility (which, commonly, the show does not mind doing). For the most part, all the seasons are very well put together, with each having some of the greatest episodes of any show I've ever seen. Though season 2, as it is, is pretty bad compared to most of the other seasons. Now don't quote me on this because when I say bad I mean Breaking Bad levels of bad, which compared to other TV series is much less of a considerable insult. Like most shows I recommend not watching this out of order; More then any other series, huge changes in plot, story and character arc take place so excruciatingly fast you are likely to be completely lost if you skip episodes. And the show is the proverbial roller coaster, taking you to the low points and peaks right along with your favorite characters, you won't want to miss a second. So yeah, go check it out.

I HATE roughly 95% of all television shows that I've ever seen. It offends my intelligence, my world view, and pretty much everything else I hold dearly. Breaking Bad is still television...but its *good* television. Sure, there are some cringe-worthy moments. The presentation of the Salamanca brothers was down-right uncharacteristically cartoonish and silly, with their melodramatic silence and oh-so-menacing expressions. But I forgive Breaking Bad. Jesse is irritatingly familiar, the scumbag bro you hoped you wouldn't see at parties, played to perfection by Aaron Paul (I'm hoping its not one of those "Keaneau Reeves" scenarios, where he is actually ALWAYS an airhead). You just wanna smack a bro, at times. But I got over it, even grew to like this character at times. Funny, the way the writers play with us, so deftly injecting and removing our sympathies at the drop of a pork-pie hat. Without spoilers, I've had issues with some of season 5 as well, as some of the subtleties in Walt's development, some of his lines, seem to have been exchanged for the more predictable and cheesy TV/Hollywood tropes. And yet...I am still counting the months until July, when we'll all be put out of our collective, suspenseful misery. Hopefully, in a good way. Because, despite these and a few other missteps, I haven't been this engaged in a TV show since I can remember.

For some reason, likely a surplus of spare time that we won't go into, I've now watched the first 4.5 seasons, twice. I am notoriously picky, and an infamous hater of most things that appear on the small screen. Why? Because TV most often lacks the focused creative genius that is allowed in film. There is no independent venue for TV, as there is for film. Either you're palatable to the larger American audience, or you don't make it past the pilot episode (assuming you aren't shooting for the dreaded network TV stations, where creativity and intellect are sacrificed at the whims of advertising dollars. I think I've vomited on the keyboard.) Amidst all of the prerequisite cartoon violence and melodrama, there are some absolutely poignant moments--and having watched a father of the same age (and similar life situation) encounter cancer--with a less spectacular outcome--I quickly noted that Walt's experience, sans descent into Scarface, was hauntingly realistic. The struggle of each character's encounter with existential malaise and disappointment, the will to survive, and the will to power, amidst all of the fantastic fictional elements, are incredibly real--and not just for Walt, but for almost every single character on the show; from Hank to Marie, Gus, Skylar, Mike, etc. Though I may not even agree with Gilligan's philosophical premises about the nature of morality (or maybe I do...I'll see how this ends!), I applaud the refreshing way in which it is being explored. Our protagonist constantly makes the wrong choices. Or were they wrong? We aren't exactly sure. Is there redemption? We don't know that, either. Now, again, you can bicker about the merits of this quandary, but the point is that this show is engaging enough to keep us guessing.

I have never seen such deeply developed and charismatic characters.

Breaking Bad (2008-2013) is a series that I recently completed on Netflix. The storyline follows a chemistry teacher who discovers he is dying of cancer and wants to earn money for his family before passing away. He decides to become a meth cook with one of his students. He will need to keep the operation hidden from his wife, disabled son and detective brother-in-law while adjusting to dealing with some unsavory characters in this line of work.

This series was created by Vince Gilligan (The X-Files) and stars Bryan Cranston (Argo), Aaron Paul (The Last House on the Left), Giancarlo Esposito (The Usual Suspects), Anna Gunn (Sully), Bob Odenkirk (Nobody), Dean Norris (Total Recall) and Jonathan Banks (Gremlins).

This has to be the most consistent series ever created. This literally feels like one long movie more than a series broke up into seasons. There's a consistent feel and pace to every episode, season and storyline. The characters are worthwhile and you can find yourself rooting for and against them at the same time. The main character is great but also annoying and arrogant. Jesse is a dumbass at times, but you also feel sorry for him and hope he succeeds. The side characters are also remarkable - Hank, Gus, Walter, Saul, Skyler and Jr are all tremendous. This is also one of those series where even the finale lives up to expectations.

Overall, this is a remarkably consistent series from the first to the last episode. An absolute must see. I would score this a 10/10 and strongly recommend it.

This is a powerful and evocative story of resentment, ambition, greed, and despair.

I have little more to say on this show that has been so well-reviewed in so many places over the past several years. It is the rare combination of being both an ambitious and artistically successful story and also an entertaining adventure that pulls no punches.

Both mundane and terrifying, "Breaking Bad" is the triumphant icon of our golden age of television.

Enjoy it. I know I have.

(I have seen this many times, most recently binging it in September 2017)

And if to say in general for the whole series: Although not everything in this film is very cool, it is beautiful, well shot and presented. But still, very vital and with the most open moments. When you watch a film and understand that you are watching someone's real life with all the life circumstances that cannot be ignored, from which the plot is further woven. It is very concentrated and at the same time balanced. That is, the filming and the actors' performances in a talented and balanced way cannot help but touch the viewer with their frankness and sometimes realism. When realism, it is more correctly presented situation. When the viewer is warmed up with curiosity about the environment and is shown by this environment that it is really alive and could be and is. And that's what makes the series so exciting... Those who have seen it and those who filmed this movie product will understand. Very big well done, well done. But in between, there are also miscalculations - a very frequent phenomenon in modern cinematography, when certain tangential moments in the script and plot are blurred. And unfortunately, this series also has moments with an unpleasant aftertaste. A very vivid example. This is a series with an air traffic controller, when the father of the girl Jesse, could not bear the death of his daughter, and made a mistake that led to the tragedy. In this series, as in the previous one, there was great potential for a full disclosure of the problem and what happened to his daughter, from the father's side. But the creators of the series, for some reason, sharply hushed everything up and did not allow these moments to be revealed.
